PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations and arises out of a question I asked him yesterday. I refer to the Government's submission to the Remuneration Tribunal recommending a 6 per cent pay rise for senior members of the Industrial Relations Commission. I note what he said about the present status of that submission, so I will not go back to that. I ask the Minister: On what grounds was that submission based? Does the Minister agree with the Prime Minister that an increase of the sort that has been referred to could totally destabilise the wage fixing procedures and that the discussions that the Minister will have, or is perhaps now having, with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Commission are to avoid that outcome?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The grounds on which the application was made were consistent with an undertaking I had given the Industrial Relations Commission following upon the breaking of the nexus between its rates of pay and that of judges. The undertaking I gave was that the Government would conduct an inquiry into that issue, that is, the proper level of remuneration and how it is to be fixed in the absence of a nexus, and a series of other matters which relate to the fact that this Government has succeeded in achieving an agreement with the States that heads of tribunal of the State industrial relations commissions would be appointed to our bench and vice versa-members of our bench to their bench-to integrate the State and Federal systems into one national system. That gave rise to a series of matters relating to remuneration and conditions of service.

ANSWER.PARA: The inquiry that we have now announced-the Gleeson inquiry-is to examine the right and proper ways of resolving those issues. I indicated that, were the inquiry not to have completed its deliberations by the time the next adjustment for judges was due, I would put before the Remuneration Tribunal a proposal for Industrial Relations Commissioners and Deputy Presidents. There is nothing surprising about that explanation; I have read it myself today in the newspapers. Maybe Senator Durack does not read the newspapers or maybe he prefers this medium of information exchange, and I do not blame him for that. That is the short explanation in reply to the first part of his question.

The second part of his question asks whether I agree that this claim would totally destabilise the wages system. The Prime Minister is right to make the observation that major increases, coming at a time in which ordinary wage and salary earners in Australia were expecting a wage increase based on the September quarter consumer price index, could have a serious effect on wage stability in this country. That is a fair enough and quite proper and correct observation to be made.

The reason why the Government has chosen, in the circumstances of the 0.7 per cent September quarter CPI figure, to review the situation with respect to the application to the Remuneration Tribunal for Industrial Relations Commissioners and Deputy Presidents is that we are given here an opportunity to continue trending down inflation rates. It seems to us that that is an appropriate thing for a responsible economic manager to do.

I can report that in the last six quarters we have presided over a successive drop in levels of inflation as measured by the consumer price index. In June last year the quarterly return was 2.4 per cent; in September last year, 2.3 per cent; in December last year, 1.9 per cent; in March this year, 1.7 per cent; in June this year, 1.6 per cent; and in the September quarter this year, it was 0.7 per cent. That is a quarter on quarter succession of the levels of inflation moving downwards. It seemed appropriate to us that, since September was marked as the quarter in which the general wage earning population was to achieve its first increase under this accord and as we have a low return, it was entirely appropriate-in fact, quite responsible-for a government to examine all of the pressures on wage fixation and to take the time to consult with the parties in relation to wage fixation to see whether we, as a government used to making creative economic decisions and taking the hard choices about industrial relations, could generate a further reduction in inflation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Cook, this answer has gone for six minutes, I ask you to conclude it.
—I will, Mr President. The Government is seeing whether it could generate the further reduction in inflation for the benefit of all wage and salary earners and industry in Australia.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BUREAU OF STATISTICS: INDUSTRIAL DISPUTES

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations whether he is aware that the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) has recently issued its figures on industrial disputes throughout Australia for the month of July. Do these figures show that industrial disputation continues to be at record low levels? Can this magnificent result be included among the achievements of the Government's accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have consistently said that, of all of the measures of lost time to industry, the level of industrial relations disputes is probably the least important because the time lost owing to accidents and disease in industry ranges about 10 times more and the time lost through labour turnover and absenteeism is about 10 times more. Not withstanding that, the Australian Bureau of Statistics has reported in its latest bulletin on industrial disputes in Australia, published on 27 October, that the level of industrial disputation has dropped even further. Briefly, some of the main features of the report as recorded by the Bureau of Statistics are:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . A total of 910,000 working days were lost. This is the lowest twelve month figure since this measure was first published on a regular monthly basis . . .

Of the industry groupings, the Construction industry, and the Metal products, machinery and equipment manufacturing industry each reported the lowest level of working days lost since this measure was introduced on a regular monthly basis . . .
The report also goes on to say:
New South Wales, Western Australia and the Northern Territory reported the lowest level of working days lost since this measure was published on a regular monthly basis . . .

In terms of working days lost per thousand employees, the overall figure (142 days) and the figures for the following industries and States were the lowest levels recorded since the measure was first introduced on a regular monthly basis--

Those industries concern construction and metal processing. That is, indeed, a pleasing return. For the month of July, 37,500 working days were lost in 102 disputes. For the year ended July 1990, 910,000 working days were lost, the lowest, as I have said, according to this measure, since it was introduced and the lowest since 1968. I point out that the work force is now 65 per cent larger than it was in 1968, when we had the same number, in gross terms, of days lost.

I table for the interest of the Senate a table I have compiled of the number of working days lost per 1,000 employees for the 12 months ended July each year, from 1982 to 1990. It shows 603 in the last year of the Fraser Government, and in this current year 142. The table shows a consistent fall, except for the year 1998. I table that for the information of the Senate and say that the one feature of the statistics that I--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a point of order. This is now turning into a debate. It certainly would have been more appropriate for the Minister to have put down a statement which can be debated in the proper way. Consistent with the attitude you adopted in relation to the extra long answer to the first question, I ask that you ask him to complete this answer.
—I think the Minister is completing his answer.
—I am, indeed, Mr President. The one displeasing feature, perhaps, of these statistics is to go back to the bulletin published by the ABS, when it says:

ANSWER.PARA: Of the States, New South Wales had the highest level of working days lost . . . accounting for 51.7 per cent of all lost time.
There is a Liberal government in New South Wales, which just proves that Labor does it better.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from Western Samoa led by a very good friend of Australia, the Speaker of the Parliament of Western Samoa. I might also point out that the delegation includes the first woman ever elected to the Western Samoan Parliament. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome you to the Senate. I trust that your visit to Australia will be both informative and enjoyable.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Can the Minister explain the basis of redundancy payments? Are they meant to be offered to employees to take early retirement because their jobs have become superfluous? If so, how does he explain the relatively large number of redundancy payments which have been made to the drivers of Comcars? Why have redundancy payments been made to drivers who are on the eve of their retirement anyway? Why have new drivers been engaged to replace those drivers who were supposed to be redundant? What influence has the Transport Workers Union had on this quite blatant waste of taxpayers' money?

—Once again we get Senator Parer coming in here with his own view of history and his own view of the facts. Redundancy payments, of course, do have a specific purpose. In respect of the matter Senator Parer raised in respect of Comcar, there was a review of the functions and delivery of services of Comcar. That review was conducted earlier this year and towards the end of last year. Out of that review came some proposals for the reorganisation of the service side of Comcar. As part of that, the Department of Administrative Services decided that redundancy payments should be made available to a number of drivers in order that, as part of a package of reforms, new shift arrangements and new working structures could be put in place.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer and I would like to ask him: if redundancy payments were made because jobs were becoming superfluous, why were those people who were paid those redundancy amounts replaced by new drivers? Again I ask the question: to what extent did the Transport Workers Union have an influence on this blatant abuse of taxpayers' money?

—It is very easy to allege the blatant abuse of taxpayers' money. Of course that charge is denied. In all reforms of this sort where industrial matters are involved the relevant union is involved, as it has been in this case. The redundancy payments were made available on the basis of a number of criteria, one of which was the length of service.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to reports today that the Republic of South Africa is closing its consulate in Sydney and scaling down the operations of its embassy in Canberra. Accordingly, I ask the Minister: Is this some form of protest against Australia's supposed lack of recognition of reforms claimed by the Pretoria Administration? If so, what are the implications for current and future political and diplomatic relations between Australia and South Africa?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As reported this morning, South Africa told us officially yesterday of its intention to close the Sydney Consulate and to scale back its Canberra Embassy representation to an ambassador and two diplomatic personnel by March next year. It appears clear, especially from statements made by Ambassador Tothill, that the main motivation for this has been financial-the need to make savings in order to accommodate new pressures for upgraded representation elsewhere, especially in eastern Europe. That is a familiar problem for governments-one that we are wrestling with ourselves-and it is a response that causes us no difficulty whatsoever. But it does seem that South Africa could not resist the opportunity to try to score some political points in the process to make a propaganda virtue, as it were, out of its economic necessity.

ANSWER.PARA: It seems clear that there is an element of diplomatic punishment involved for Australia as a result of our continued active support for sanctions, through the Commonwealth and elsewhere. The most explicit indication of this is, I guess, in the terms of the South African note that we received which states not only that there is a `diminished level of mutual interest prevailing in relations between South Africa and Australia' but also that it is the `view of the South African Government that Australia's representation in South Africa should be reduced to a commensurate level by 31 March 1991'.

There is of course no principle of reciprocity in international relations which requires a country to downgrade its presence in a second country in response to that country downgrading its own presence in the first country. If it were really accepted by the South African Government that we were about to greet the dawn of a new era in South Africa's domestic circumstances and in its international relations, this is hardly the time to be diminishing the opportunities for contact between us. That hardly squares with the South African Government's own stated commitment to making that country more open and accessible to the rest of the world.

Australia makes no apology whatever for the stance that we have taken and continue to take on South Africa. The Prime Minister and I have warmly welcomed developments to date and we have both congratulated President de Klerk on the statesmanship that he and his senior leadership colleagues have shown in breaking the awful impasse of the last 40 years. We have both expressed the hope that it will be possible to wind back sanctions sooner rather than later, but we will not move unless we are satisfied, in consultation with our Commonwealth friends and with the most representative black voices within South Africa, that there is clear evidence of profound and irreversible change.

It is the case that President de Klerk's sincerity seems to be clear and that the commitment to change by him and his senior colleagues may well now be irreversible. But the process of change itself has as yet only just begun, and it is simply too early to state with any confidence that that process of change is irreversible. What has happened to date has essentially been talks about talks, and the clearing away of preliminary obstacles. Substantive negotiations have not begun. Only one of the basic pillars of apartheid-the Separate Amenities Act-has to date been dismantled. The other basic pillars: the Groups Areas Act, the Land Acts, the Population Registration Act-not to mention the Constitution itself-all remain.

Australia is not looking to sustain trade sanctions, financial sanctions or sporting sanctions for a moment longer than they are necessary, but we are determined to maintain them for just so long as they are necessary to ensure that apartheid is destroyed once and for all and that South Africa does at last become a genuine non-racial democracy.

I conclude by expressing the hope that the South African Government will recognise the sincerity and consistency of Australia's position and not now embark on a course of diplomatic action which will make more difficult than it needs to be the task of rebuilding relations between our two countries in what we all hope will shortly be the post-apartheid environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I preface my question by reminding the Minister that Australia's electrical power industry is responsible for $32 billion of Australia's foreign debt as a result of the installation of generating capacity to meet demand forecasts which failed to materialise and that the ability of the Queensland Electricity Commission (QEC) to predict demand has been particularly poor, leading it actively to encourage the wasteful use of electricity in order to increase revenue. Is the Minister aware that in just six years from, 1982 to 1988, forecasts by the QEC exceeded reality by 1,000 megawatts? Is the Minister also aware that the QEC is now proposing to spend $550m on the 600-megawatt Tully-Millstream hydro-electric scheme, 25 per cent of the cost of which will be spent offshore on generating equipment? Is he aware that the debt of the QEC is growing at a rate of 15 per cent per year? Has the Federal Government considered insisting on the States controlling electricity supply and directing utilities towards demand management and readily achievable energy efficiency? Will the Government consider placing a cap on foreign borrowings by State electricity utilities and if not, why not?
—That is an example of the long questions which I complained about the other day.

—It will be a short answer, Mr President. I am aware of all those things in Senator Coulter's question now that he has asked me the question, but for the first time I am aware of all those things. The topic of the activities of State electricity generating authorities was discussed at the recent Premiers Conference and will be discussed again at the next Premiers Conference in April. In so far as Senator Coulter's question seeks information about various things, I cannot supply that at the present time but I will seek to provide the honourable senator with an answer. Of course, the general issue of electricity generation came on the agenda for the Premiers Conference as a result of concern about the price of electricity, the management of electricity authorities and a number of the issues inherent in Senator Coulter's question. I will try to obtain some information for the honourable senator as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Did the Minister see a report in the Sunday Age of 11 November that the Opposition trade spokesman, Mr Alexander Downer, said he would lead a trade mission to South Africa next year? Given the clear position on sanctions which has been spelt out by the international community in general, and the Commonwealth in particular, what is the Government's reaction to Mr Downer's comments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw the report on Sunday that Mr Alexander Downer, the Opposition spokesman on trade, said that he will lead a trade mission to South Africa next year whether Australia has lifted its sanctions by then or not. It will be fascinating to see how Dr Hewson reacts to this particular triumph of expediency over principle, and whether he will disown this exercise by his trade spokesman-which I now invite him to do-or whether he will regard this as just another illustration of the kind of `selfish' foreign policy that he recommends for Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: What Mr Downer has done cuts completely across the policy of successive Australian governments since the mid-1970s which, for all the reasons I outlined a moment ago in response to Senator Loosley, has been to maintain a united, consistent approach on the question of sanctions-to use them to bring South Africa not to its knees but to its senses, and not to lift them until the process of the destruction of apartheid is irreversibly under way. Mr Downer's statement is one which sends exactly the wrong signals to Pretoria at this stage. Come what may, however slowly the reform process now moves forward, however long it takes to address and remove the basic remaining injustices of the apartheid system, the Liberal and National parties will be in there cheering.

It is a signal, moreover, that will be read with dismay by all those around the world-not least in black South Africa and in the Commonwealth-who know that the battle is not yet over and that it can be won only if principles are maintained, if international solidarity is maintained and if international pressure continues to be maintained so long as it is productive, which at the moment it undoubtedly continues to be. It is the case, and I say it again, that apartheid is a monstrous evil. It is still overwhelmingly intact in South Africa today. This Government will not be dissuaded, whether by crude and unprincipled behaviour now foreshadowed by the Opposition, or by some not very much less subtle diplomatic pressure from South Africa, from doing everything--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I think that is a reflection on a member in another place.
—Mr President, I put it to you that that is entirely within the familiar argot of this Parliament, and entirely appropriate in the circumstances of this particular matter.
—I do not think it is unparliamentary.

—I repeat that under those circumstances we will not be dissuaded, whether by crude and unprincipled behaviour from the Opposition or by some not very much less subtle pressure of the diplomatic kind from the South African Government, from doing everything we possibly can to ensure the destruction of apartheid and not resting until that destruction is complete.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to his statement last week that our less than satisfactory relations with Malaysia are due only to the media program Embassy. In fact, did not our relations with the Malaysian Government badly sour over the handling of the seizure of documents by Australian Customs Service officers in 1988 when such officers acted in contempt of the Malaysian High Court by refusing to return documents as per an order of the court dated 16 September 1988? I ask whether the Minister agrees that the perception that our attitude to Malaysia is both arrogant and insensitive is heightened by the sorts of comments made last week by Senator Bruce Childs in response to my tabling of affidavits from Malaysian nationals relating to the same matter alleging coercion by Australian Custom Service officers, when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: The question is at a certain point whether we believe officers of the Australian Government or whether we believe anything that is said in a foreign country.
Does the Minister accept the implication in Senator Childs' statement that a Malaysian's word is somehow less worthy than that of a Australian?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there were three separate questions in that tirade and the answer to all of them is no.

—My brief question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I ask the Minister whether he can inform the Senate whether any progress has been made on negotiations with the States and Territories to allow courts sentencing Federal offenders to impose a community based sentencing option rather than a prison sentence in appropriate cases.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to tell the Senate that as of yesterday the Commonwealth has now successfully negotiated with all the States and Territories to allow for magistrates and judges to award a community service order instead of a term of imprisonment or a fine in cases where a Federal offender, having been convicted, is to be sentenced. I believe that this is a most important arrangement, and to have it concluded with the Attorney-General of New South Wales, Mr John Dowd, agreeing only yesterday is to put in place an Australia-wide system which actually began in Tasmania some years ago, with the now Sir Max Bingham introducing community service orders in that State.

ANSWER.PARA: We have reached a situation where all governments and jurisdictions in Australia in relation to Federal offenders will now have available the alternative of the community service order. In the case of New South Wales this is certainly a sensible move in relation to the costs of administering the Corrective Services portfolio because, whilst it costs around $40,000 a year to keep a person in prison in New South Wales, it will cost some $1,800 a year to administer a community service order.

The great advantage of community service orders from the Commonwealth point of view is not to provide a more lenient sentence in the case of those engaged in major drug trafficking or in relation to major fraud against the Commonwealth or tax evasion; but particularly in cases of social security offences where, for example, a woman has got caught up in a series of offences, is brought before a magistrate in relation to those offences and ought to be convicted, but where it would be a tragedy for the family and would cause greater costs for the State if that woman were to be imprisoned in the absence of an alternative such as a community service order being available.

This sentencing option will enable the community to indicate that what is done in those situations is wrong and unlawful, but not such as would warrant the disruption of a family and perhaps putting children into care with all the consequences for their upbringing. Without condoning a deliberate fraud in relation to social security, one has a situation now Australia-wide where magistrates will have the full range of sentencing options available to them. I am very pleased that that has come about. I would pay tribute in this regard to Daryl Melham, a member in another place, who has played a particular role in New South Wales, drawing on his experiences as a public defender, in bringing about this very satisfactory final arrangement with one of the States to complete this Australia-wide program.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I refer to the Minister's answer to my question of 6 November in which he indicated that he was briefed on the contents of the blue file marked `Govt' on six occasions in 1988 and that matters concerning the Western Australian Premier, Mr Burke, arising from the file are the subject of ongoing inquiries by the Western Australian police. Was the Minister briefed that the file included evidence to suggest that Mr Burke was party to an arrangement whereby Mr Smith was investigating Liberal politicians at Government expense? Did the Minister bring that information to the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade prior to, or subsequent to, the appointment of Mr Burke as Australian Ambassador to Ireland?

—I have no intention of revealing the contents of briefs to me from the Australian Federal Police in relation to these matters, particularly because many are under investigation by Commissioner Bull of the Western Australian Police.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The Minister said that he was briefed six times by the Australian Federal Police and that he has been advised that there are ongoing inquiries being conducted concerning Mr Burke and his former staffer, Mr Shervington. I simply ask whether he advised the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade of this fact before Mr Burke was appointed Ambassador to Ireland?

—I believe I did not say that Commissioner Bull had been briefed in relation to matters about Mr Burke and Mr Shervington. That is Senator Knowles's inference. What I think I said was that the matter of the contents of the blue file were handed over to Commissioner Bull for his perusal with a view to examining whether indeed there was some evidence in there which would indicate the commission of a state offence.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Is the Minister aware that the New South Wales Government is threatening to close the Broken Hill gaol? Is this consistent with the findings of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator West for this question. It indicates her very real interest in the people of New South Wales living outside the major cities and urban centres. She is well known for her extensive coverage of the western areas of New South Wales, in particular Broken Hill. She has rightly indicated her concern because it appears that the New South Wales Government is threatening to close the Broken Hill gaol.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that, while that is a matter for State authorities, I would ask those State authorities to consider very carefully relevant findings of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. It is quite clear that to have a gaol at Broken Hill certainly permits Aboriginal inmates to keep up the very important contact with their families and close relatives and kin. Isolation from such family and kin can have very serious consequences for the Aboriginals concerned.

For example, in the report of the inquiry into the death of Malcolm Smith, Commissioner Wootten discussed the desirability of maintaining family and kin contacts and the problem of corrective institutions being located a long way from centres of Aboriginal population. I quote extensively from the report, Mr President, because I think is very important. Commissioner Wootten said:

A valuable exception to the remote location of gaols is Broken Hill Gaol. It is a relatively small gaol and one can imagine in days of economies of scale it may be under scrutiny. However, its existence is of great importance to the Aboriginals of the western areas of New South Wales, who supply many of its inmates. Although Broken Hill is 262 kilometres from Wentworth, 111 kilometres from Menindee and 195 kilometres from Wilcannia, it is at least within an area in which Aboriginals are used to moving, whereas eastern gaols might as well be in another planet for many Aboriginals. Imprisonment in Broken Hill Gaol gives some opportunity of maintaining family contacts: indeed with the large extended families in the area such contacts are to some extent maintained within the gaol.

The closure of the gaol and the movement of prisoners would seriously diminish the opportunities of relatives to visit and would make contact between the prisoner and his or her particular Aboriginal community almost impossible. Therefore, I make a plea and I certainly hope that State authorities will consider action to mitigate these consequences in view of the findings of the Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Following Senator Cook's abuse of Question Time again today, I ask: Is it a fact that in May this year the Prime Minister told his Ministers to clean up their act, to lift their game, to abandon time wasting tactics at Question Time and to answer double the number of questions? Why is the Prime Minister's authority over his Ministers such that the average number of questions per day in this chamber is still only about 18-14 below what it should be if the Prime Minister's instruction carried any weight? Why, when we have passed only 20 Bills in the first six weeks of this session, are we being asked to deal with 32 packages with 66 separate Bills in them in the last four or five weeks of this session?
—I do not recall any such instruction from the Prime Minister and as the honourable senator's question is based on--
—Here it is. `Clean Up Your Act'.
—Order!

—I can understand Senator Vanstone naturally being attracted to a headline such as `Clean Up Your Act'. I understand how that caught her eye, but the fact of the matter is that I do not recall any such injunction by the Prime Minister. As the honourable senator's question is structured on the basis of the assumption of the Daily Mirror article being correct, it falls to the ground. There is nothing else to say.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Given that the Leader indicates that he does not recall the Prime Minister's instruction, which gives us some indication of what weight he put upon it, I ask him to address the latter part of my question, which was: Why, when we have passed only 20 Bills in the first six weeks of this session, are we being asked to deal with 32 packages with 66 separate Bills in the last four or five weeks of this session? What that translates to, since the Minister avoided the question, is simply this: Is the late introduction of so many Bills an indication that his Government is not able to decide what it wants to do, or is it simply a further attempt to evade parliamentary scrutiny?

—I think that, if there is any fault, it can be laid at the door of the Government. It is being too indulgent in allowing those opposite to pursue Estimates committees week after week with repetitive and frivolous questions. That is a matter which we will have to look at. That goes to the question of parliamentary scrutiny. Those opposite have Senator Bishop sitting in front of them. Why do they not have a word in her shell pink ear about the time she wastes of public servants and Ministers in Estimates committees week after week?
—That is an excellent response.

—What does the Minister for Social Security think the implications would be for the social security system in Australia if proposals published in a paper by the Centre for Independent Studies for privatising the Federal welfare system by allowing individuals to earmark their social security contribution through the tax system for a particular charity were to be implemented? In particular, does the Minister believe that such a proposal could allow for the necessary research, planning and accountability that is currently required of expenditure in the social security area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Childs will no doubt recall, it is only a few weeks since Dr Hewson and Senator Alston floated some proposals about privatising social security. They were sensible enough to drop off. If one asked Dr Hewson's office now, one would simply be told that it has been referred to the policy making bodies and that they have no further comment.

ANSWER.PARA: Unfortunately, however, it would seem that somebody who works for Mr Downer-a person by the name of Alistair Nicholas-is the co-author of the report to which the honourable senator refers. The other author is a fellow called John Goodman, who is the President of a United States organisation called the National Centre for Policy Analysis. In fact, this document is a steal from one that it introduced.

I really worry about these kinds of lunatic proposals because they are the exact way that Australia ought not to go. If we want a lesson in how to go, we should have a look at the latest report on social security and service delivery in the United States by the Brookings Institution, which is, of course, I think as all honourable senators would concede, a very respected institution. The Institution makes it quite clear that the devolution of social security responsibility from central authority has led to very serious and very large holes in the safety net for Americans who are struggling. In fact, the Institution reports that some States have actually reduced benefits so that they can stop poor people from settling. That is not the way that Australia needs to go. We have a targeted, equitable, central system which delivers 140 million payments a year with 99.9 per cent of them on time.

One wonders how the charitable institutions would go about getting their money. Would we have all singing, all dancing advertisements from the Salvation Army competing against the Smith Family, the Brotherhood of St Laurence and St Vincent de Paul to see who gets a quid? Since when did income become the barometer of compassion in this country? Since when did we decide that the richest people can say to which poor people they particularly want to allocate their money? This idea fundamentally stinks. It is unworthy of--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. Quite clearly the Minister is debating Opposition policy. He wishes to use this as a forum for making a statement. There is another time and place to do so, not at Question Time. He is out of order.

—Order! It is a matter within the Minister's portfolio. The Minister was asked whether the Government would implement these policies. I would ask him not to debate the question and to take notice of the length of the answer.
—The answer has been going for only a couple of minutes and I intend to conclude it now, Mr President.
—Disrespectful.

—I am acknowledging to the President that I am taking account of the time. So I am actually paying more than due respect, Senator Hill. I would have hoped that we could avoid a situation where agencies were forced to advertise in the Business Review Weekly or the Australian Financial Review to chase corporate benefactors. That is not the way Australia needs to go. What I hope is that we can avoid the term that this report uses-it refers to a behavioural approach to the problem of poverty. The report states that welfare payments are not a right. I would have hoped that ideas as unworthy as these are not adopted, even by the Liberal Party which has adopted so many unworthy ideas in recent times.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General, refers to recent media comment by the Attorney-General reporting his commitment to the 1 January start-up date for the Australian Securities Commission (ASC). Is the Minister aware that in Western Australia the application of laws legislation is yet to be introduced into the State Parliament; that the office fit-out for the Australian Securities Commission's one acre of office space has yet to commence and cannot be completed before March or April 1991; that no Corporate Affairs Commission staff have been made job offers by the Australian Securities Commission and that, therefore, no staff have been trained in the use of the computer system? Will the Minister inform the Senate whether there are any contingency plans to overcome these problems? If not, will the Government consider setting a later and more practical start-up date to ensure a smooth transition to the new national scheme and proper consideration of the legislation in the State and Federal Parliaments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell is referring to a scheme which has received the endorsement of all governments throughout Australia, including all State and Territory jurisdictions of all political persuasions. With that support I am confident that they will make every effort in their respective parliaments to ensure that the various enabling pieces of legislation, after proper parliamentary consideration-that does not necessarily require a lengthy deliberation because these matters have been discussed over a long time and all participants in the process are familiar with the principles involved-are passed before the end of this calendar year. The various parliaments will have their own timetables and programs, but the Federal Government remains confident that, with that goodwill which has been exhibited since the meeting in Alice Springs which brought all the parties to support this scheme, those timetables will be met.

ANSWER.PARA: As to Senator Campbell's question about the logistics involved in renting out space, in training staff and in making appropriate job offers, I am sure that the Attorney-General is aware of those matters and, together with the Australian Securities Commission, is endeavouring to ensure that the earliest possible steps are taken in regard to those matters to have the scheme up and running on 1 January. It still remains the Federal Government's goal that 1 January be the implementation date. I believe that Mr Hartnell of the Australian Securities Commission shares very passionately in the view that we should achieve that objective on that date. As I say, with the cooperation of various governments, the Federal Government remains committed to that implementation for the good of the corporate and securities sector in Australia and in order to enhance our international reputation in these matters as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support to a question I asked him last week relating to an air incident involving a Qantas 747 jet. I ask the Minister: Given that the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation report on that incident states that the plane suffered an autopilot malfunction, climbed 1,650 feet during the incident and decreased its air speed by 45 knots, is it his opinion that the plane was sufficiently under the pilot's control? Does the Minister still maintain that the flight crew made an immediate and appropriate initial response to the situation? Finally, what information, if any, regarding this incident has been provided to the seven people seriously injured and the 58 who received minor injuries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am well aware that Senator Kernot is not raising this question again from any motives of raising alarm or scaremongering. I know that Senator Kernot and a number of other honourable senators have received representations from constituents regarding this matter and that she is raising the question quite properly.

ANSWER.PARA: I would like to put beyond doubt-in respect of the actions of the Qantas crew-what I have done since receiving Senator Kernot's first question. I advised Senator Kernot and the Senate at that time that I would be checking with the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA)-I had not had time to do it at that point but have since done so-as to the action it had taken. I also asked the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation to go back to the flight data recorder, the actual records taken from the aircraft, in order to put this matter beyond dispute. I am aware of the sources of some of these allegations.

I advise the Senate again, to put the matter beyond question, that the Bureau of Air Safety has done that. The allegation that has been made that the aircraft was out of control for two to three minutes is totally false. The flight data records taken from the aircraft show quite clearly that the entire incident of the altitude excursion that the aircraft suffered lasted for a total of 19 seconds from start to finish. But for the first eight seconds of that excursion the change in altitude was so slight and so gradual that the air crew on board that aircraft would not have noticed it. So the extreme excursion of altitude suffered by that aircraft lasted for a total of 11 seconds from start to finish-not two to three minutes-until the aircraft was again in level flight.

I also point out that the air crew, not unnaturally, when the incident first occurred assumed that it was a meteorological problem, that they had run into a serious clear air turbulence. The fact that the aircraft was back in level flight 11 seconds from the time the excursion started should put to rest completely the allegations that I know are continuing to be made, that the answer I gave in the Senate during the last week of sitting was not correct.

I also say that the CAA has confirmed that the action that Qantas took was appropriate in the circumstances. I will advise of one slight correction-the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation advised me that the aircraft had three auto pilots. In fact, the particular aircraft involved had two. That is not a particularly important issue. I just take the opportunity to correct it. The rest of the answer that I gave was absolutely accurate. As I said, the entire incident lasted 19 seconds from start to finish. The air crew behaved in precisely the way they had been trained to do. At no stage was the aircraft out of control.

In response to the last part of the question as to whether the people injured have been personally advised of the details of that incident-that is a matter for Qantas. I do not know the answer to that question. I will inquire. If they have not been so advised by Qantas I will personally make sure that they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer: Is the Government's decision to break its 1988 promise and extend the use of the tax file number to the checking of government benefits based on an assumption of the tax file number's integrity as a means of identifying individuals? How will people who set up false identities to obtain benefits be prevented from using false identification to obtain a tax file number, thus using the tax file number system to further their criminal activities? Will the data matching proposal that was announced in the Budget be effective in stopping such fraud?

—There are a number of assumptions in Senator Patterson's question which I do not necessarily agree with. As it requires some detail, I will obtain an answer from the Treasurer and get it for her as soon as possible.

—My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Australian Government doing to encourage the military regime in Myanmar or Burma to adhere to the results of the May elections? In view of the recent further human rights abuses in that country, what measures has the Government taken, including consideration of economic sanctions, to persuade the military regime to transfer power to the democratically elected government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I informed the Senate on 14 September, the Australian Government has consistently called for a democratic government to be established in Burma or Myanmar. In addition to all the specific bilateral representations and policy statements made here and multilateral activity, as recently as yesterday the Australian delegation to the General Assembly, in a joint statement with New Zealand, expressed our concern over the failure of the Burmese authorities to make any serious move towards the transfer of power to a democratically elected government.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government has been considering possible economic sanctions against Burma. We would join any broadbased international move to impose economic sanctions but would wish to evaluate the likely effectiveness of such a move in conjunction with the United States of America and other like-minded countries before going down that track. It appears to be a general view in the international community, at the moment anyway, that sanctions would be unlikely to have much effect, especially as Burma's regional trading partners, who account for most of the country's trade, would be unlikely to support sanctions, at least at this stage. We wish to continue consultations on this issue with other like-minded countries and will do so.

The more general situation in Burma has continued to deteriorate with the ruling State Law and Order Restoration Council, or SLORC, unfortunately increasingly dependent on intimidation and repression. The number of political arrests has increased markedly. As I think I mentioned last time, on 7 September the spokesman and acting leader of the National League for Democracy (NLD), the main opposition party, and four other party leaders were taken into detention. Two have since been sentenced to seven years gaol. It has now been reported that another, arrested on 25 October, has died in custody. I am very concerned about that report. I have asked our embassy in Rangoon for more information about it. In addition, during October security forces entered monasteries, as was widely reported, and arrested a large number of monks in response to the monks' religious boycott of the military. We strongly condemn these intimidatory tactics.

While it is the case that the National League for Democracy just a few days ago, on 9 November, made a majority decision to agree to SLORC's very gradual process for writing a Constitution and a transfer of power to a new government at an indefinite time in the future, the position of the NLD was, to say the least, complicated by the continuing detention of a number of its most active leaders and the clear possibility that refusal would have led to the complete exclusion of the NLD from the political process or even its forced dissolution. The Australian Government deeply regrets these latest developments. We will continue to do all that we can to maintain pressure through bilateral and multilateral representations to achieve an early transfer of power to a democratically elected government and for an improvement in the human rights situation in Burma.

Perhaps I can say by way of footnote that the Senate will have noticed that I have used more or less throughout this answer the expression `Burma' rather than `Myanmar' to describe the country. This follows some consideration that I have been giving recently as to what should be our practice so far as the names of the country and its capital are concerned. The standard practice is, of course, to accept, for both formal and informal purposes, the English language version of the name that a country gives to itself. But occasionally some variations are justified by circumstances. The present military regime, SLORC, advised us in June 1989 of its desire to change the familiar names `Burma' and `Rangoon' to `Myanmar' and `Yangon' respectively, and we have been following that practice hitherto. However, it remains the case that these names have not commanded widespread acceptance in international usage, particularly in the United States and Europe, or by Burmese expatriates abroad, or by the opposition NLD, which was so overwhelmingly supported by the people in the election of May this year. For all these reasons, while we will still use `Myanmar' in formal communications with the present Government, for all other purposes we will henceforth revert to the more familiar and much more widely understood and accepted `Burma' and `Rangoon'.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MR ROBERT SMITH: ALLEGATIONS OF IMPROPER CONDUCT

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to a question asked of him on Tuesday last week relating to the relationship of gaoled phone tapper and disgraced former detective, Bob Smith, with Australia's Ambassador to Ireland, Mr Brian Burke, the former Premier of Western Australia. The Minister will recall that Smith helped to dig up political dirt on Opposition politicians and police while working for the Burke Government. He described himself as Mr Burke's street level adviser. Has the Minister now satisfied himself that Mr Burke was not involved in nor had any knowledge of investigations carried out by Mr Bob Smith on Liberal politicians? Has the Minister taken the opportunity to discuss the matter with Ambassador Burke during the past week when the Ambassador has been in Australia and in Canberra, in particular?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Such discussions as I have had on this subject since Senator Crichton-Browne raised it have not altered my initial judgment as conveyed to him and to the Senate. I do not think there is any foundation for any suggestion of improper behaviour on the part of the former Premier, and certainly nothing that I have seen would lead me to think for a moment that there was any inappropriateness about his appointment as an ambassador. All I would be prepared to say further on the public record is to quote from the relevant passage of the advice of the Western Australian Commissioner of Police to the present Premier, which was put on the public record, I think, a few days ago, in the following terms:

ANSWER.PARA: A file was provided to the Commissioner of Police and inquiries were made, some of which have concluded. These inquiries, which have concluded, indicate no evidence of any offence having been committed by the then Premier. These matters are not new, the then Premier made a statement to the Commissioner of Police at about the time the file was given to him by the Australian Federal Police. At the time, the then Premier's legal representative was advised by police that there was nothing in the matter which required any action. In view of the trial having concluded, consideration will be given by the Commissioner as to whether any matters were raised which have not already been investigated.

That is a fairly comprehensive reaction by the Commissioner of Police and I believe that this matter deserves to be buried, and not attempted to be resurrected in the clearly politically motivated way that it continues to be by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I accept that any question that Senator Evans finds difficult he finds to be politically motivated. But I ask him to acknowledge the last two lines of the statement, which he clearly had not read previously, that, subsequent to the conclusion of the trial, it was appropriate that further investigations now take place. I ask Senator Evans: Did he, in the light of that, make inquiries of Ambassador Burke while he was in Australia?
—What was the last bit?
—Did the Minister or did he not have discussions with Ambassador Burke while he was in Australia?
—Whatever discussions I may have with ambassadors on this or any other matter remain a matter between us.

—I address my question to the Minister for Administrative Services. Given the Government's support for employer-based child-care, will all future new government buildings make provision for child-care in accordance with the Government's commitment to ratify the International Labour Organisation Convention No. 156, Workers With Family Responsibilities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first point I would like to make in response to Senator Reynolds's question is that employers are increasingly recognising the importance of child-care to the achievement of a more flexible, productive work force at the enterprise level. To this effect, the Government is keen to support employer sponsored child-care to further our social justice objectives and labour market objectives. As a consequence, in 1988 our national child-care strategy included 1,000 places for a new industry initiative. There has, of course, been some interest in that.

ANSWER.PARA: In 1990, in our election statement, we included further commitments to facilitate employer sponsored child-care. Changes which will take effect from 1 January 1991 include the extension of the improved fee relief scheme to all employer provided long day care and amendments to fringe benefits tax legislation to exempt payments to secure places in commercial centres. These measures, of course, all add up to a major boost to the provision of employer-provided care. For the first time, public sector employers will be able to establish child-care for their employees and will also be able to benefit from increased fee relief levels.

The Government has taken a number of actions. Firstly, on 30 October Mr Peter Staples, the Minister responsible in this area, released an information kit. Together with that, a video produced by the Department of Employment, Education and Training will also be made available. The video will be entitled Child-Care: the Management Challenge in the 1990s. As well as that, further information kits and a booklet on taxation issues relating to work-based child-care will be available later this year. We are also sponsoring in April 1991 a high profile national seminar on employer provided child-care. That will be held in Melbourne.

As well as that, relating specifically to Senator Reynolds's question and the issue of whether employer provided child-care will be made available in public sector buildings, with regard to new government buildings both I and my Department support the concept of child-care facilities in Australian government buildings. Of course, there is great potential in terms of social justice and market flexibility issues. We will promote to client departments the inclusion of child-care facilities in new Commonwealth offices. Where these facilities are requested by client departments, we will assist them in pursuing the achievement of them. In respect of existing government buildings we will also consider, on a case by case basis, requests from departments to locate child-care facilities in such buildings. Of course, considerations that are relevant here are the availability of space in the buildings, the legal requirements and the provision of facilities such as access to open space, suitability and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I would like to point out that I have received a number of complaints about the behaviour of some sections of the Press Gallery during Question Time. I have spoken to representatives of the Press Gallery Council. A circular will be issued soon. I would point out to those members of the Press Gallery that we expect the same behaviour from them as we get from the public galleries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented during Question Time. Senator Button, during his tactically diversionary answer to a question from Senator Vanstone, somehow implied that my questioning during Estimates committees had lessened the time available for debating legislation. This is a complete misrepresentation. The Minister implied that Estimates hearings are heard during the period when ordinary sitting days would normally take place which, of course, they are not. Certain days are set aside with the provision to sit on non-sitting days to complete the period of Estimates. I certainly took the opportunity, as did colleagues during that period, to scrutinise proposed Government expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: The record set out by Senator Vanstone is quite correct. During six weeks only 20 pieces of legislation have been dealt with, whereas in the remaining 4 1/2 weeks we are supposed to deal with some 68 pieces of legislation. This is a clear example of Government mismanagement of the handling of Government business.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The honourable senator has probably concluded, but she was certainly straying from a personal explanation. It would have been appropriate to call her to order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 November I was asked a question by Senator Calvert on the mechanical problems being experienced by the Aurora Australis. The Antarctic Division of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following information: Aurora Australis has two main engines to drive a single propeller. These engines can be operated singly or in tandem to meet requirements for speed in open water or icebreaking capacity. On Saturday, 27 October, while Aurora Australis was breaking heavy pack ice about 400 kilometres from Mawson, a flexible coupling drive between the port main engine and gearbox was damaged. The reasons for this will be investigated by a team of specialists when the vessel returns to Hobart.

ANSWER.PARA: P and O, however, advises that the damage was not associated with the propeller or the rudder and that fitting or non-fitting of skeg or ice knives is unrelated to the problem. During the design phase of the vessel, some advice was provided supporting the use of a skeg while other advice was not supportive of this. Considerable ice tank tests were conducted prior to finalising the vessel design and, based on the results, skeg and ice fins were judged to be unnecessary. In fact, expert advice was received that the fitting of a skeg and fins would be detrimental to the performance of the vessel.

The spares carried on board the vessel are in excess of those required by the classification society and voyage register of shipping. The spares holding for the vessel was reviewed by the classification society which found that it complied with its rules and regulations and were adequate for the vessel's Antarctic service. There has been no damage to the starboard engine coupling and the vessel is operating in single engine mode. In this mode its operating capacity is similar to that of other vessels which have been chartered by the Antarctic Division. It is therefore misleading to describe the Aurora Australis as limping around the Antarctic continent or to suggest there are safety concerns. I should like to point out that the Aurora Australis is presently running two days ahead of schedule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Calvert on 7 November 1990, relating to Australia's Antarctic vessel Aurora Australis.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted: debate adjourned.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens shows:
The United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
wide rights to children in Articles 12 to 16, including the right to privacy and freedom of association;
gives only qualified rights to parents in Article 5;
fails to recognise the prior right of parents to determine the education of their children;
could if ratified by Australia, result in government-assisted rebellion against parents who want to set limits for their children in their children's best interests.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will:
request the Federal Government not to ratify this potentially damaging Convention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Alston (from 425 citizens) and from Senator Foreman (from 184 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: States Grants Schools Assistance Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

that the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act, 1988 includes legislation. Part 111-Changes to Non-Government Schools, designed to inhibit the establishment, growth and development of these schools in Australia by the imposition of restrictive provisions in the areas of funding, enrolments and approval criteria.

Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should: reconsider the application and implications of this legislation in the light of justice, equity and freedom of choice for parents and have the unfair sections (Section 8(2), 8(15) and 11) repealed.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469,274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed air landing fee for regional and commuter airlines landing at Sydney Mascot Airport during peak times discriminates severely against people in rural Australia and will force many airlines to either revise their schedules, cancel flights or increase passenger fares to cover this additional financial impost of the Federal Labor Government. This will result in less accessibility for country businessmen and travellers alike, will increase the costs of business for rural people and threatens the viability of many smaller airlines who provide valuable services to rural towns. We therefore call on the Federal Government to abolish all plans for the introduction of this discriminatory fee and allow commuter airlines to continue to provide their full range of services to towns throughout New South Wales.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Otway Forests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Leader and members of the Senate of Australia, the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that the Governor of Victoria has set aside 219 hectares of Reserved Forest in the Apollo Bay water catchment forest to be the West Barham Big Trees Flora Reserve.
We humbly pray that you consider protecting a larger area of the Otways from logging by listing it as National Estate forest so that botanical, water and tourist values may be preserved.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation Administration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned elector respectfully showeth:

1. That a petition on certain matters of taxation administration and legislation from your petitioner was presented to and received by the Senate on 31 March 1987 (Senate Hansard 31st March 1987, page 1513 ff).

2. That subsequently your petitioner forwarded a copy of his said petition to the Commissioner of Taxation with a request to re-examine and correct such of the matters complained of as were of an administrative character within his competence.
3. That the Commissioner of Taxation refused to accede to such request and refused to correct such matters.

4. That subsequently your petitioner forwarded to the Federal Treasurer a copy of his correspondence with the Commissioner of Taxation and requested the Treasurer to refer the matter to the Auditor-General for investigation and report pursuant to his powers under the Audit Act.

5. That subsequently the Treasurer informed your petitioner that he would not refer the matter to the Auditor-General as he could see `no useful purpose being served in referring the matter on to the Auditor-General for further consideration'.

6. That your petitioner disagrees with the views expressed by the Commissioner of Taxation and the Treasurer and claims that the relevant conduct of the Commissioner, the subject of the petition, is erroneous in fact and in law, involved a misinterpretation and misapplication of relevant provisions of the Act, and the provisions of the Act under which he operated in the particular matter were and are unconstitutional and void at law, are oppressive and prejudicial to the peace, order and good Government of the Commonwealth, and ought to be corrected in the public interest and in fairness and natural justice to your petitioner and other taxpayers similarly affected.

7. That the Auditor-General has power under the provisions of the Audit Act, to investigate and report on the matters complained of, to call for documents, take evidence, and form his opinion independently of the Commissioner of Taxation and the Treasurer, who are or purport to be judges in their own cause.
Your petitioner therefore humbly prays:

1. That the Senate do refer the subject matter of the petition presented to the Senate by your petitioner on 31 March 1987 and the subsequent responses of the Commissioner of Taxation and the Treasurer to the representations of your petitioner on such subject, to the Auditor-General for investigation and report to the Senate under the provisions of the Audit Act.
2. That the Senate take such further or other action in the matter as it thinks fit, either in accordance with the said petition or otherwise.
And your petitioner as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Consumption Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:

That a Consumption Tax would be ruinous for rural Australians already paying more for goods than city dwellers. In particular a Consumption Tax would place an unfair burden on people on fixed income, families, the wine and tourism industries and farmers. Further a Consumption Tax would substantially increase inflation.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should unanimously and immediately reject any proposal to introduce a Consumption Tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

The Commonwealth and Defence Force Ombudsman is an office in which I have always maintained a close interest. The citizens of Australia are perhaps not quite as aware as they might be of what an important person the Ombudsman is to them and to their rights when it comes to dealing with the administration of this country. As a parliamentarian, I find the Ombudsman's Office extremely helpful and very important in scrutinising what goes on behind the doors of Commonwealth Government departments.

I am particularly interested, as the shadow Minister for Defence Personnel, in the work of the Defence Force Ombudsman because often the Ombudsman is able to get to grips with documents to which I, as the shadow Minister, am not privy. Often, between the two of us we can achieve some influence on what is happening behind the scenes in the Department of Defence which is in the best interests of individuals in the Defence Force. The Ombudsman also covers a wider area than that, including veterans' affairs, but I am especially interested in defence.

As I have only a little time, I intend to concentrate on a few matters. One is the question of delays. The other programs in this report have a section on delays, that is, how long it takes to finalise a claim, an appeal, through the Ombudsman system. The freedom of information program notes delays, as do the programs for both the Australian Federal Police and the Commonwealth Ombudsman. In fact, the only program for which I have not been able to find a statement of what the delays have been is the Defence Force Ombudsman program. I am afraid that is rather worrying because historically the defence area has experienced the longest delays. That is not meant to be any reflection on the most professional job done by the Ombudsman, but rather on the lack of resources given to the Ombudsman to carry out his tasks adequately and efficiently.
The matter of delay was raised in May this year by the Ombudsman, Professor Pearce, who commented publicly while addressing the Australian Institute of Administrative Law, that his office was:
. . . probably the worst-resourced Commonwealth review agency in the world-despite the fact that it dealt with many more people affected by Government than any other body.

Professor Pearce also said at the time that the saddest feature of his two years in office was that he had been unable to carry tasks through in the way required by the Ombudsman's legislation. He said that the `parsimonious approach' to the resourcing of his office affected its capacity to perform its statutory functions. I think that is something which the media should be concerned about, as should the Parliament. If our Ombudsman is so under resourced that he cannot effectively do his job, it is the Parliament's right to know and the citizens' right to redress that are affected.

Professor Pearce said that in his role in examining complaints involving the Australian Federal Police and the Defence Force, he found both organisations very cooperative but their processes very slow. He said that the serving members of the Defence Force had to go through an `extraordinarily elaborate' internal complaints procedure before a matter could even be referred to him, or before he could deal with it. Other matters he raised included the fact that his office was obliged to conduct its inquiries almost exclusively on paper. He said that it was paradoxical that the review body which could most readily assist the attainment of good government administration and could do so in the least threatening manner was the most neglected.

The Ombudsman in the last year has been looking at administrative matters outside the redress system in the Department of Defence. He has been looking at issues concerning the return of service obligation for service personnel who have been given training for which they have to give a return of service; at the conditions of service for members without family, who certainly have been disadvantaged, I believe; and also at a number of other matters that are important to the forces regarding removals, drug abuse, civil convictions and those sort of things.

I was especially pleased when he gave the example of how finally after three years he had been able to achieve something on education allowance, because the Defence Force had been slow in realising that the determination was not being properly interpreted. That is something which I have long had concerns about and tried to take action on, and I welcome his success. I only wish that he was financed and resourced by the Parliament as an officer of this Parliament, and then perhaps he would better be free to scrutinise the actions of the administration of this country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

In scanning this annual report of the Australian Safeguards Office, I note that the introduction refers to the technical measures applied by the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and I commend the Director of Safeguards, John Carlson, for having the honesty to point out that for the IAEA to have a preventive role it would require far more extensive powers and resources than the world community has yet been prepared to give any international organisation. I have always argued with regard to safeguards and non-proliferation that it is ludicrous to expect a body to take effective measures against transgressors when it was set up to promote nuclear power in the first place and, as the Director admits, could not possibly be effective even if it wanted to be.

On page 30 there is a reference to participation in the Australian delegation to the fourth Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT) Review Conference in Geneva. That fourth review conference of parties to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty finished on 15 September and Australia was one of the 84 parties represented out of the 142 countries eligible. The conference ended without any agreed conclusion when disputes over the importance of a test ban for the future of the NPT prevented the adoption of a final document. Of course, one should not suggest that just because there is not a final document the whole exercise was a waste of time, but it certainly does highlight one of the major problems with the NPT review process, that is, that the nuclear weapons states are highly reluctant to actually get on with the business of concluding a ban on the future testing of nuclear weapons. There are many experts who feel that the treaty will not last beyond 1995 because the nuclear powers refuse to put a stop to testing, although they expect other countries to pledge that they will not develop nuclear weapons.

It is worth noting that, under the treaty, non-nuclear states renounce the right to acquire nuclear weapons and accept international inspection of their nuclear facilities. In exchange, the three nuclear weapon states which are signatories-and it is probably important to point out that neither France nor China, also nuclear weapon states, is a signatory to the NPT-vow to negotiate a nuclear test ban and nuclear disarmament and, along with other industrialised states, to cooperate with non-nuclear weapon parties in the application of nuclear energy for peaceful purposes.

The Australian Government, of course, has worked hard to achieve a comprehensive test ban, but time and again all progress has been blocked by the opposition of our great powerful friend and ally, the United States. The very hard work and good efforts of our two Ambassadors for Disarmament so far have been stymied by the United States. I can only hope that the holding of the amendment conference of parties to the 1963 partial test ban conference to be held in New York next January will result in more progress towards the goal of a comprehensive test ban than was evident in Geneva in September. It is absolutely crucial that the world moves towards this ban on the testing of nuclear weapons.

On page 13 of the report I note a section on nuclear non-proliferation, repeating the nonsense about nuclear materials not being diverted to nuclear weapons. I must admit that I thought this myth had been demolished with the admission a couple of years ago that Australia's uranium might well end up in French nuclear weapons. In fact, the Government cannot categorically say that Australian uranium does not end up in French nuclear weapons or the nuclear weapons of other nations to which our nuclear materials may be transhipped. This is particularly the case as the monitoring of yellowcake transfers consists only of shuffling paper. In fact, the safeguards are not the worth the paper they are written upon.

Recently I visited the embassies of France and China to discuss the test ban review conference scheduled to be held in New York in January. The representatives of both these countries assured me that they needed nuclear weapons for their defence, but seemed oblivious to the fact that, if they felt they need nuclear weapons, why should other countries not have similar feelings or `needs' to have nuclear weapons also? Already, in the past month, we have seen the United States Congress seek to punish Pakistan because it has not been honest about its nuclear weapons capability. We hear about Iraq's nuclear weapons potential a few years down the track if Saddam Hussein is not stopped now and deprived of his military capability, which includes nuclear, chemical and biological weapons programs. Israel, another non-signatory to the NPT, like France and China, took steps against Iraq's nuclear potential some years ago, but now Israel appears to have gone underground to hide its new facilities as well as to decentralise them.

One might well ask how countries like Iraq ever got hold of the technology in the first place, let alone the relevant materials. The answer is quite obvious because although many countries, such as Australia, pay lip service to safeguards, as this report does, in the end there are no effective safeguards, bar one, that is, to make a decision to have no part of the nuclear fuel cycle and to devote our efforts to developing renewable energy alternatives, energy efficiency and conservation.
