In relation to the quest that I have engaged in to arrive at the employment figures for 1989-90, Defence, according to one set of figures, was employing 23,922 civilians and, according to another set, 25,017. So there is a discrepancy of 1,095 people who may or may not be working for Defence.

SPEECH.PARA: I was also interested in the numbers for this year as to whether civilian employment is growing or decreasing. In Budget Paper No. 1 civilian numbers are said to be increasing by 83 for the current financial year, but when this matter was pursued in Estimates committee hearings a Defence official informed me:
This financial year--
that is 1991, of course-
we have also programmed a one per cent reduction in civilian staffing right across the Department, which produces a further net saving of something like 250 over the course of this financial year.

Here again, we have a major contradiction: a claimed increase of 83 and a claimed reduction of 250. It is extremely difficult for us when we are unable to get clear and consistent figures on a matter of such importance or to get consistency between answers which are received in relation to this matter. I am bringing this to the attention of the Minister-it is something of a cri de coeur-so that he might follow up the difficulties that I am having and see whether they are justified. If not, can he give a firm figure as to the level of civilian employment in 1989-90, the level this year and whether it is in fact increasing or decreasing?

TALK.START.PARA: — Sometimes there is confusion between actual staff numbers and staff years allocated to departments. The figure of 83, I am told, is a figure that was under-achieved the year before, so it is not really an increase-it was not achieved the year before. I will endeavour to get some precise figures and precise definitions, because a variety of definitions is used by different people on these matters. I will try to give the honourable senator the fullest picture on employment-where it was headed last year and where it is headed this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The next matter I want to raise at this time in the consideration of the defence estimates is a question in relation to the capital procurement program. Of course, I am very concerned about the commitments in relation to this very large program and the extent to which it is driving the defence budget over the next decade or more.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also registering a complaint about the fact that I have not been given the amount of information that I was seeking to get in relation to it. I asked a question which was taken on notice. That is fair enough. I did not expect the information to be ready to be tabled. For each of the projects listed under Major Capital Equipment Expenditure, I asked:

. . . please provide data which indicates landmark dates in the evolution of the project as the projects are anticipated to develop over the coming . . . years. Landmark dates would include such things as progress of projects through major committees, letting of contracts and subcontracts, completion dates for major components of projects, major stages for payment of monies and final completion dates.
The answer was a total brush-off:

Given that Appendix 7 of the Explanatory Notes contains some 44 of the more significant major projects, extensive research in compilation of data would be required to provide the information sought. I am not prepared to direct resources to respond to such a blanket request.

That appears to be the Minister's own decision in relation to this matter. It does not actually say that the Minister directed it but there is the term, `I am not prepared' and I presume it is a ministerial decision.

In fact, there may well be 44 major capital equipment items in this list in appendix 7. That is no mean amount, of course, but that is one of the reasons why I am interested in the question. It is a very large program. The questions I asked on landmark dates, which seemed to me to cover only a very bare outline of such major programs, covered the letting of contracts, completion of major projects, stages for payment of moneys and so on.

I would have thought that running information of that kind in relation to any project-much less major capital projects-would be there on hand as a management tool of a most elementary kind. The fact that the answer to me is that extensive research would be required to provide this information is, in itself, a matter of great concern. If extensive research is required to provide what I have requested only as landmark material, then there seems to me to be a major lack in management control over such projects.

Hopefully, I am wrong in that assumption, but the fact that it could not be provided to me, presumably because it does not exist, is the major concern. However, it seems to me that, if the material is there now in a readily extractable form using modern computers, it would not require much work for it to be put together and provided to me on the public record. Matters of commercial-in-confidence, and so on, are other problems which I will refer to following this discussion. But I raise the question of what information does the Department itself maintain in order to keep the most elementary tab on what is going on in each of these major capital equipment projects and why it would be such an enormous task to provide such basic information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, we keep information in particular forms but not necessarily in that prescribed by the Opposition and the Opposition defence spokesman. What he may regard as information that should be readily accessible may be accessible in our own terms but not in the terms that he is stipulating.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason why the question was not answered is that it is simply too big. We are talking about over 150 major projects, 44 of which are in Appendix 7 in the supplementary Estimates. It would have taken several man weeks to have any chance of compiling that particular answer. The document would have been several hundred pages thick. After all, some of these major projects have hundreds of subcontractors dealing with them.

There has to be a limit, sooner or later, to the amount of detail that can be provided in answers so that resource problems are not created for particular departments. In our judgment-and I endorse that particular judgment-this question was far too broad, going back over many years and involving a massive amount of research. I do say that, if Senator Durack has a particular concern about specific projects, we would be willing to dig out information on those projects and provide the information to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for going some way to meet the request. It seemed to me that the only difficulty that the Minister has raised is perhaps in relation to subcontracts. Admittedly, I asked for landmark dates, which would include such things as the progress through major committees and that would not be difficult, I would have thought; the letting of contracts and subcontracts, and subcontracts in major projects can be very many indeed and may be something which would require an excessive amount of detail to be extracted; the completion dates; the major stages of payment of moneys, and note that I asked only about major stages, of which there are not a great many; and, finally, completion dates for 44 projects and, presumably, that information would not add very greatly to that burden.

SPEECH.PARA: I specifically asked my question in relation to Appendix 7 of the explanatory notes, that is, the major capital equipment expenditure, which contains 44 projects, not in relation to the 100-odd that the Minister mentioned. The question only relates to them. As I said, I left it very much in my question to the discretion of the Department itself to determine what would be meant by landmark dates. I have not seen the documents, so of course I do not know exactly the way in which this information is retained in relation to each project, but setting aside the question of subcontracts, which I can see may have caused a problem, I cannot see why the rest of that information could not be supplied in relation to these 44 projects.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I believe Senator Durack is underestimating the amount of resources required. If for any reason, or no reason at all, he wants information on a specific project, we will provide it. To ask for that sort of amount of information is not simply a fishing expedition, it is long line fishing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can say is that it absolutely amazes me that the Department does not have, for its own management purposes, readily available information of that kind in relation to its major capital equipment expenditures. I think that is a matter of very considerable concern, and it ought to be.
—It is exactly the same as when you had the Ministry of Defence over your side.
—If I had had it I might have shaken it up a bit and had more management techniques in place than the Minister or his predecessor seem to have.

SPEECH.PARA: I asked some questions about the Anzac frigates-the Australian Marine Engineering Consolidated (AMECON) project-about which I received a good deal of information. I thank the Minister and the departmental officers concerned, but here again I ran into a problem with principal subcontracts. One can make an interesting comparison with this and the non-answer I received to the question I asked in general terms that we have just been discussing. In relation to the Anzac frigates project and Collins-class submarines, I asked for details of each contract: when it was let, et cetera. I will not read all of them. I received answers about the prime contract and answers under the heading `Principal subcontracts let by AMECON'. It was a reasonable exercise of discretion by the Department to select principal subcontracts and give some details.

I was given an answer in relation to price which was that, due to the fixed price nature of the prime contract, price details of subcontracts let by AMECON are commercial in confidence and not available to be released. I make the comparison that at least there was some reasonable attempt by the Department to answer the question I had asked in general terms. As I said, the question related to each of the contracts and I asked the Department to provide information in relation to subcontracts which were clearly selected by the Department. I make no complaint about that.

But in view of the fact that the price details are not to be supplied because of commercial in confidence, it raises in my mind a number of questions about the role of the Department in relation to a fixed price contract, which is the nature of the prime contract. I know that letting contracts of a fixed price nature is an important development and I support it. I am not in any way critical of that. But in view of the fact that these contracts are very large and cover a very long period, and will no doubt involve the engagement of a number of subcontractors, I would like to know to what extent the Department will have in place a control over the performance of contracts by subcontractors.

Presumably, the departmental officials who are responsible for the performance and oversight of the contract do not leave the performance of subcontractors to the attention of the prime contractor. What is the departmental policy in relation to ensuring the prime contractor is, in fact, keeping a very close eye on the extent to which his subcontractors are performing, because this must be closely related to the timely completion of the contract and the cost of the total project? In addition, I would like to know whether or not subcontractors are able to meet various deadlines for completion of their work during the various stages of the prime contractor's performance of the contract.

I would like to know whether there is any form of administrative oversight by the Department in relation to the subcontracts and whether or not it lays down any particular guidelines on subcontracting. For instance, to what extent is there any policy of having a percentage of work performed by Australian industry? For argument's sake, the major development on the North West Shelf gas project has cost many billions of dollars over many years. The percentage of Australian work in the development of that major project in both its stages has been able to be stated.

Can the Department of Defence provide an estimate of what percentage of that contract price in each of the cases of the Anzac frigates and the submarines will be performed by Australia? Does the Government have a policy on this? Does it take an active interest in ensuring that its policy is carried out?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is really a case of the old saying of not keeping a dog and barking yourself. We do specify some requirements but, essentially, it is up to Australian Marine Engineering Consolidated (AMECON) to provide the specified performance. It is its job to look after subcontractors and to deal with them. AMECON monitors for quality control systems. We look at those at all times because we are interested that the right outcome is met. If the right outcome, as specified, is not met, it is on AMECON's head to fix it. There is an expectation via the contract that has been signed that 70 to 80 per cent of the work would have Australian content. That is a contractual obligation that AMECON has to take out.

SPEECH.PARA: Essentially, the system that has evolved has been to leave the major management decisions to AMECON to bring in this contract. It is not up to us in Defence to do so. We are obligated to pay for it. AMECON is obligated to deliver a product of a specified quality. That is its job. I do not think that Defence should be duplicating it too much.

TALK.START.PARA: —How is the Government proposing to assess the contract? We are talking about a contract that is going to go on for 10 years or more. Over that period, does the Government have any procedures in place to assess it? The Minister says that there is a contractual obligation of 70 to 80 per cent. Is 70 to 80 per cent a variation or is it just a ballpark figure that he is mentioning? Is 70 to 80 per cent the way it is stated?
—It is a specific figure with offsets involved; that is why it could be in that range.
—I see. Does the Government have a system in place for monitoring the performance of the contractor in relation to the work as it is going on, and how is that being done?

—Coincidentally there is a meeting today with AMECON to monitor exactly that factor. It is done by regular meetings; it is not as though the Navy or the Defence Department just say, `You build a ship and we will take it'. There is more involvement than that. This comes up regularly and is monitored regularly. Honourable senators must also understand that over a particular part of the contract the percentage may not be in that range, but over time it will get to that range; it may even be higher than that and drop down. It is over the life, as I understand it, of the 14-year contract that we get that 70 to 80 per cent Australian content.

—I have only one question area I would like to put to the Minister, and it relates to a question I left with the Estimates Committee, which was not answered. I thank the Minister and the Department for answers they provided to other questions, but this question was about the 1,600 approvals for defence exports. The Minister declined to answer it because some of the information, he said, was commercial-in-confidence and quite a lot of effort would be required to produce this list. I ask the Minister to reconsider that answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly cannot provide information which is commercial-in-confidence. I recall passing this question. Listing 1,600 approvals is not the normal thing to do in an Estimates committee. I suggest that Senator Vallentine put in a monetary amount so that we can narrow this down to the biggies-the top 200-and we might be able to provide those. However, it is an awful lot to ask in terms of resources to get the 1,600 approvals listed.

SPEECH.PARA: I have just been informed that my suggestion is not very helpful because we know only what was exported and not how much each item is worth. I think it is very unreasonable to ask for that amount. I am not saying the basic question is unreasonable, just the totality of the answer required. In a very tight budgetary situation I must look after resources. I have no hidden agenda because I have no regrets about any of those exports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Somewhere in the Department there must be a list of all the exports that have been approved. I do not see why it should be such a big thing. Obviously, a number of people in the Department work on this issue and make these approvals. Surely the various work portfolios of the officers doing this job could just be collated.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand what the Minister is saying-it does seem to be a big effort, and it is a big list of 1,600, yes-but I want to explain why I want this information. In 1988 a resolution at the Forty-third General Assembly of the United Nations-resolution 43/751-followed on from the United Nations Special Session on disarmament. One of the areas of great concern to people at that conference was the question of arms transfers. In that resolution there was a call for the world community to look at the whole question of arms transfers and in particular, part 2(c.) calls for an examination of the ways and means of providing for more openness and transparency with regard to worldwide arms transfers.

At that time Mr Hayden was still the Foreign Minister and he made a stirring speech to the Special Session and said in part that arms should not become the new cash crop. That line was very roundly supported by many people at the conference. Earlier he had said that Australia should not sell arms to countries at war, preparing for war or using weapons to repress their own citizens. I realise that would cut out a whole lot of Australia's potential buyers. It would certainly have cut out the sale of the Mirages to Pakistan, which I know has been of great concern to the Opposition as well as to me. It would also have cut out the proposed sale of the 76-millimetre shells to Sri Lanka and the proposed sale of aircraft spare parts to Iraq, both of which, I imagine, were cancelled due to high embarrassment.

The present Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) also made a stirring speech recently at the United Nations. It is interesting that these speeches are made there and often we do not hear much about them in domestic consumption. This speech was made on 2 October 1990 and Senator Evans said at the United Nations that the upward spiral of arms procurement and the proliferation of increasingly more destructive weapons was of great concern, and also:

The acquisition of conventional weapons continues at an alarming rate in many parts of the globe. Often scarce resources are diverted from social and economic development to military expenditure. Australia supports measures by all States to reduce military budgets . . .

We have also had signal warning from Barber Conable of the Board of Governors of the World Bank. He made a speech in September 1989 which also talked about military expenditure and the need to explore ways to bring military spending into better balance with development priorities. He said that governments should be realistic and remember the human consequences of the choices they make in terms of arms exports.

It seems to me that we have a real dilemma since the new guidelines were made for defence exports following the Cooksey report. That is when the Department of Defence became the final arbiter in these matters. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade seems to have been squeezed out of the decision making; obviously there needs to be more time for assessment. I think I heard the Minister say recently that the guidelines need to be re-examined in the light of some of the more embarrassing proposed sales which had to be cancelled. It is mainly because of the transparency that the United Nations is calling for; Australia may not be one of the worst offenders in terms of arms transfers, but it is in there attempting to increase its level of defence exports. If we are serious about the comments that our Foreign Ministers make at the United Nations and their support for this transparency in arms transfers, I think it is not at all helpful-in fact it is downright counterproductive-for the Minister to say it is too much trouble and he is not going to provide senators with the list.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other problem with this list is that we can only tell Senator Vallentine what our approvals are for exports, not what has been exported. These are two distinct things.

SPEECH.PARA: On the more general issue Senator Vallentine raised, I just do not happen to agree with her. I certainly think there is a fair bit of transparency in the military equipment we sell in this country. We import more than we sell; therefore, I assume by that that we are making others more immoral than ourselves. The reality is that over the years we have had to import too much defence equipment, and I see nothing, in a moral or other sense, that prohibits exports. We have fairly tight guidelines.

Senator Vallentine referred to three cases. In the case of shells to Sri Lanka, Senator Vallentine is not a gracious person. This matter went to the committee and was defeated. It was never on. It was only because some salesman had approached the Australian High Commission in Colombo that it got into a cable and got out. It was always going to be knocked over. Senator Vallentine should at least say that when she raises this issue. It was not embarrassing; the only embarrassment is the leaking of that cable that brought it to public light at that time. It was always going to be knocked off.

In relation to spare parts, we had a very restrictive policy in 1988 on what could be exported to countries like Iraq. We would not have been supporting offensive matters; these were spare parts for trainers, and they were banned, not on military grounds, but because all trade was suspended with Iraq, including wheat and other commodities. There has been a lot of publicity on the sale of Mirage jets and I still say we were entitled to do that. It had a long lead time. The thing we acknowledged straight after the contracts were signed was the poor timing, but a lot of that is due to the fact that in this country, when things are under way and writs are issued, governments do not intervene and make major policy decisions. Unfortunately, it went to the contract stage and was irretrievable by the time I became Minister for Defence. It was a question of timing and the timing was not good. However, we have not had war in the last six months between those two countries and things are far more stable today-I am not necessarily 100 per cent optimistic-than they were at that time.

I think we have tighter guidelines on the export of defence equipment than most other countries. We are not engaged in an arms race; we are spending only 2.3 per cent of gross domestic product on defence, most of which is on an extremely defensive rather than offensive posture. We will never become a major exporter of arms, we know that. In the current climate, if anything, we may become a reduced seller simply because at the end of the cold war we will be undercut in price. There are certain niche markets that we will export to. We will continue to do so in the same way as we will import certain equipment over a period.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just come back to the matter that I was raising before, although I have asked most of the questions that I wanted to raise. I just give a small example of the problems that one gets into in a contract with subcontractors. It concerns a contract about which I received complaint from a subcontractor in relation to some work done at Maritime Headquarters. I do not know remember exactly what the contractor was doing but he went bankrupt, leaving a subcontractor who was laying floor tiles in the Maritime Headquarters lamenting for payment. He was demanding that the Navy should not continue walking over the tiles that he had laid without paying for them. That is the simple sort of normal attitude that subcontractors take when they do not get paid for work they have done. They often look to the building owner. I do not know what the legal position is as a matter of course in these things.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter was presumably brought to the attention of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) because it was brought to my attention by the person concerned. It is simply an example of the problems that one can face with large contracts and with the non-performance by various subcontractors down the line. That is really a reason why it seems to me that with a very large contract, such as the ones we have been talking about, it is necessary for the Government-or whoever is commissioning the work-to ensure, by having an adequate watching role on performance by a prime contractor, that all is going reasonably well so far as can be ascertained.

I understand from the Minister's answer that the Department really does not have in place any ongoing management role in this situation, but that it has meetings from time to time and gets reports from time to time. Am I right in my assumption, or is there some clear policy being pursued in relation to the question of seeing that the prime contractor is in fact engaging the people who are doing the work, as he would be expected to do?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have suddenly shifted from a subcontract for Maritime Headquarters at--
—I am suggesting that there is an analogy.
—That is an entirely wrong analogy and I think in a clear-headed moment Senator Durack would agree that there is a difference between--
—I am just saying that you can get into this sort of trouble even in small contracts.

—One can get into these problems with subcontracts. This is the life of subcontractors; they get into these problems all the time, and I have great sympathy for them. But if there is one thing that is coming through to me as Minister, it is the desire to stop the Department of Defence overspecifying what contractors and subcontractors should be doing; that is, interfering all the time, delaying, and slowing things down. I think Senator Durack is going in the wrong direction with that particular thing. I hope that tomorrow night, when we have a lot of the Defence contractors there, we both get a bit of feedback. But the thing that they raise with me most often is overspecification, overinterference and oversupervision, and these are putting pressure on them rather than the other way around.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not had that particular case in Maritime Headquarters raised for my attention directly in the sense that people have been to see me or that I know they have applied to come to see me on it, but I am not sure that it is our role to supervise every subcontract that some main contractor has put out. That is why we are putting them out for them to do, not for ourselves to do. Sure, every now and then one of those subcontracts goes wrong or the main contractor goes broke and the subcontractor is left holding the bag. But that is in the nature of being a subcontractor, unfortunately. If we can help or assist or smooth their way, I think we should. If we can help or assist, we do not just leave someone stranded because they have got into some problems. But I do not necessarily think we should set up some massive bureaucracy to supervise every subcontract in Defence. Again, the Opposition would be back here saying, `Why have you spent all the money on consultants, computers and extra staff to do all this?', and we would be criticised on those particular lines. The whole trend in Defence in the next few years has to be for more flexibility, for less supervision and for allowing people to get on with the job, and not overspecifying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: — It is not for me to say what is the final comment but I will make my final comment on this. The last thing I want to see is a great deal of close attention and a total bureaucratic approach to management. That is one very important reason for going down the fixed price road, which I have already said that I thoroughly support. I would not for a moment suggest that the Department should go on supervising the detailed work that is being done, as it would be doing in the past under an old cost plus system or whatever it was doing.

SPEECH.PARA: All I was really wanting to obtain from the Minister-and I do not know that I really had a great assurance of it-is what form of supervision the Department is putting in place in a major long contract such as the Australian Marine Engineering Consolidated Ltd or the submarine contracts to keep an eye on how far the prime contractor is in fact meeting the obligations that he has. I am not suggesting at all the sort of thing that the Minister comes back to me on. I just want to make it perfectly clear that I am simply wanting to know what sort of arrangements, guidelines, or policy-whatever we call it-the Department has in place to manage contracts of such major importance over such a long period of time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —For instance, at Australian Marine Engineering Consolidated Ltd (AMECON) I think we have 12 people onsite. Basically one is doing three things: first of all, laying down initially the specification for what is wanted; secondly, ensuring that AMECON's quality control measures are always up to date; and, thirdly, when the final product comes off, ensuring that it is what was asked for. That is the degree of interference that I think is necessary. Both on the AMECON site and the submarine site Defence obviously takes a day to day interest in what is happening, and if something goes wrong it is going to be reported back to us.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of the work is broken up into several thousand work packages. AMECON has to demonstrate that the results are being achieved before we pay it. But it does not have to explain its own internal arrangements between AMECON and its subcontractors. If Senator Durack is worried particularly about AMECON and the way it has gone on, I invite him-I am not sure that he has-to pop down to Williamstown Dockyard.

TALK.START.PARA: —If we don't sit for three weeks longer than the House of Representatives, I propose to go.

—I will give Senator Durack a day's pair. I am sorry; I see Senator Reid looking this way, so I will not! I think it is worth an on-site inspection to see how it will operate. They are not fully down the track with this particular one because they are still building the two other frigates. The Newcastle and the Melbourne are both being built there at the moment. The same applies to the submarine side.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, the general approach is that we lay down the general specifications of what we want, and it is at a fixed price. We make sure that quality assurance systems are in place and we measure the product at the end. There are people on site and, naturally, if they pick up something that is going wrong on site, they will draw it to the attention of the management. We will pay only when we are satisfied that the product is of sufficient quality to entitle us to pay.

On the whole those two projects are going relatively well. There will always be problems over a particular subcontract or a particular work package. That is inevitable in a project of this complexity and size. On balance, I think they are going well, and I am pleased that Senator Durack is to have an on-site look at what is happening.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. I think I have finally got the information I was seeking. I turn to one other subject. We had some discussion in Estimates Committee B about the guidelines for VIP flights. I have made some comments about my concerns on that subject, and will not repeat them. But the Minister did say that he intended to review the guidelines. I am wondering whether he has done so or when he is likely to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have done so. I must say that I had not regarded it as a high priority, but knowing that the Estimates Committee would come up was a bit of an incentive for me to complete the guidelines. I completed them yesterday. I table the new guidelines now. I have them with me. I also table an explanatory note which will lead Senator Durack in 14 points to see where particular guidelines have been changed. They are not dramatic changes.

SPEECH.PARA: I will give Senator Durack the highlights off the top of my head. I am trying to insist that where journalists go on a VIP flight they pay economy fare in all but exceptional circumstances. In fact, I cannot think of circumstances where they will not have to, and I shall be the one who determines it. In essence, that will apply to journalists or any other passenger who for some emergency reason is put on a flight. For example, if a meeting has gone late here and there is a VIP flight going back to, say, Melbourne and the people from the meeting are put on the flight, they should also be charged the economy fare. That is one of the changes made.

Because there was some debate over the role of parliamentary secretaries, I have specifically written them into the guidelines. They will be entitled to use those planes travelling at the direction of their portfolio Minister. Thirdly, I have added the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate to the list of those with that entitlement. I do not know why that was never there. It seems to me to have been an oversight.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about parliamentary secretaries on this side?

—Parliamentary secretaries in the Opposition can travel if someone else has booked the flight, but no, Senator Patterson is not entitled yet. I have said that parliamentary secretaries may use them, but only at the direction of their portfolio Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: I have added in a new point that allows backbenchers to use VIP flights in exceptional circumstances. At the moment, if one wants to move 10 or 12 backbenchers, unless an entitled person is there they cannot use the plane. There may be cases where we are stuck here with 12 backbenchers wanting to go to Western Australia, for example. If an entitled person is not there one cannot authorise it. I will now be able to authorise it. It is not something that we will be doing every day; it will be done in emergencies.
Those are the highlights and I have tabled the guidelines. I shall probably be writing to all entitled persons on Thursday, and the guidelines will apply from next Monday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any mention of Whips?
—No, there is no mention of Whips as yet.

—I thank the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) for his comments. I am pleased that something positive came out of the questioning at the Estimates Committee hearings. I take some credit for that. I will read the guidelines with interest and I reserve any further comments until I have done that. However, there is one subject about which there is some ambiguity. In the Estimates Committee hearings Senator Ray may remember that I asked about eligibility for the use of VIP flights as it related to the timing of alternative commercial flights. The Minister replied to me that if there was a commercial flight within a few minutes-that was the phrase he used-then the person concerned would not get a VIP flight, and I think that it was extended to half an hour. Is anything fixed on that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a point for general guidance. It is not a rule. There may be specific instances. For instance, if someone was leaving today on the 3.20 flight from Canberra and had to make an international connection, I would not care whether the VIP aircraft left within five minutes of that flight, knowing that the commercial flight could run late and those concerned could miss their connection. They are the guidelines. Ministers and other entitled persons do not always want to abide by them. We are trying to enforce them as much as possible and are tightening that area up as much as possible. As I say, it is not an absolute rule but it is a strong guideline.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE C

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee will now examine the expenditure considered by Estimates Committee C. The first department to be considered is the Department of Social Security.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) proposed:
That the report of Estimates Committee C be adopted.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct the attention of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) to some of the matters in the report of Estimates Committee C. In relation to the Department of Social Security under the heading `Client Privacy' it is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee was assured by the Department and the Minister that, prior to this initiative being taken-
that is, the tax file number proposal-
the Privacy Commissioner was consulted. Further, the Privacy Commissioner is preparing guidelines for this data-matching process.

Can the Minister indicate whether he has given any directions or advice that in any way were intended to, or appear to have had the effect of, discouraging the Privacy Commissioner from making public comments on what he saw as the privacy implications of the present legislation?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is no. I have not asked him to refrain from any public comments. I have pointed out several times publicly that the Government will retain the right to set policy. In my view it is then the Privacy Commissioner's job to ensure that we do not breach his Act in its implementation. I have certainly not at any stage told him that he was unable to comment on aspects of the Privacy Amendment Bill.
— Does that mean that the Minister has no objection to his expressing any views that he might have in public forums on the implications?

—I do not really believe it is within my power to have a view on his doing that or not doing it. As I said to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs last Friday, the Commissioner resides within the Department of the Attorney-General, not the Department of Social Security, so it is a matter for the Attorney-General as to how he sees the Commissioner's role. If the honourable senator has a question of that nature, I will try to get a response from Mr Duffy. It is not my responsibility, so I do not give directions of any kind to the Privacy Commissioner.

—Senator Alston was just talking about the data-matching guidelines. Will these guidelines be finalised by the Privacy Commissioner and the Government before the deadline for public submissions on 30 November?

—The position will be that after 30 November the Privacy Commissioner will, no doubt, examine all the submissions before him and over the succeeding month or two come to some conclusions and perhaps introduce some changes to the indicative guidelines that he had published. To overcome the difficulty, given that we cannot wait until that has been done, I indicated to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs last Friday that the Government would seek to put some guidelines into the Privacy Amendment Bill with which the Privacy Commissioner agrees and have some sort of a sunset clause, which would mean that once he has given us a final report we would come back and tidy it up. I have not got a date from him for his final report, but one would imagine that that would be, say, around February.

—Will new clients of each of the government agencies involved in the data-matching be informed that the information they provide will be used in data-matching and what this data-matching will entail? Will data-matching also be applied to people who provided personal information before the onset of the data-matching proposal who obviously could not have known when they provided this information that it would be used in this way?

—I do not think that there is any plan to write to each of our several million clients on this matter but obviously we are seeking to give as much publicity as we can to the data-matching proposals. New people obviously will be getting information about it and we will be informing them. We are still chasing some clients for tax file numbers and when we ask them we will inform them of the purpose for the request.

— Could I pursue the question of the role of the Privacy Commissioner? I understood the Minister to say that he would seek an indication from the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) as to whether he would have any objection to the Privacy Commissioner expressing in public his views on the privacy implications of the legislation. I am grateful for that indication. Do I take it that the Minister for Social Security is indifferent as to whether the Privacy Commissioner speaks out or not in his areas of responsibility, particularly the application of the tax file number to the social security system?

—I would not define my attitude as one of indifference, but I have always felt that I ought not to be passing comment, unless it was absolutely necessary, on the functions and the actions of those who are not under my direction. If I had a problem about it, it is a matter that I would take up with the Attorney-General. I happen not to have done that but, if I did have a view to express about some action of the Commissioner, I would not do it publicly; I would go to the Attorney-General with whatever complaint I had. I do not have a complaint about his utterances, so I have not made a complaint to the Attorney-General.
— That is not quite the proposition I was putting. Does the Minister have any objection to his speaking out in areas that are directly within the Minister's area of responsibility?

—I think the only answer I can give to that is that so far I have no cause to object to his comments. I do not think I could give anyone in the world carte blanche and say that I will never object to his or her comments. If the Privacy Commissioner's comments or any comments that he may make in the future remain within his charter, then I would not object; if I thought he strayed from it, I would object. I have not had cause to make that kind of objection yet. If I did object, unless it was a totally desperate situation, I would make the complaint to the Attorney-General, not publicly.

—I understand the level of the Minister's pragmatism. I ask, therefore, why he would have a problem with the Privacy Commissioner similarly expressing a view and acting, as he saw it, in the best interests of consumers and those likely to be affected by policy changes and thinking that there may need to be changes or amendments to the legislation that were not necessarily ones of which the Government was particularly enamoured.
—I think the position is that as long as the Privacy Commissioner or any other person in a similar position is proceeding to make comment within his or her purview, I could not object.
—Word of the week, is it?
—If the honourable senator cares to make it so, it may become that.
—Immutable is out; purview is in.

—Immutable is out now, yes. On the basis that the comment the Commissioner made was within his Act, then obviously I could not complain. If there is to be a dividing line between what is within his Act and what is not, that is a matter that I would discuss with him and the Attorney-General.

— Does the Minister take the view that the Privacy Commissioner ought not to express any public doubts about the privacy implications of legislation unless his Act specifically authorises him to do that, and I understand that proposition? Does the Minister regard that as constraining him in any way from expressing public views at present about the privacy implications of the tax file number?

—The Privacy Commissioner has on quite a number of occasions going back over the last few months made comments on this proposed action. As I said, I have not had cause to complain to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) about what he may have said and I do not propose to. I am not sure that there is anything that I can usefully add to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Richardson stated in answer to a question in the Senate some time ago that he would provide any advice that he received from the Privacy Commissioner. I have written to Senator Richardson asking whether I could have that advice. I must say to the Committee that I did so not all that long ago, so it is not a matter of the Minister being tardy in replying. But to date I have not received a reply.

SPEECH.PARA: I am particularly interested in the advice that the Privacy Commissioner provided prior to the date of a matching proposal going to the Expenditure Review Committee before the Budget. Could the Minister inform me when this advice will be provided and whether any other advice will be provided to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was no advice at that time that I can provide to the honourable senator. I think I have said-I am not sure whether I said it in the Senate or in a committee--
—I think it was in the Senate. I can understand why you would not remember, though. We have had lots of discussion on this.

—There have been many discussions about this. I did say that we brought this matter to the Expenditure Review Committee (ERC). There was a discussion there. I then sought the opinion of the Privacy Commissioner. I had a meeting with him and then reported back to the ERC on that conversation. The meeting with the Commissioner was attended by Mr Volker and Mr Murphy of the Department and me. I reported back. But he did not provide any written advice that I could give to the honourable senator. I will certainly be providing anything else that he has given me but I do not have that.

SPEECH.PARA: I should also say that, of course, had he given advice I would not necessarily have provided that advice. It is given to Cabinet-it is part of a Cabinet discussion. It is a very difficult kind of thing to make public.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to move to the question of deeming. In view of the Committee's concern that where money is lent interest free or on low interest to a church there is a question of whether that is investment which is subject to deeming-the Committee said that it will follow the issue-would the Minister care to elaborate on what approach the Government will be adopting in this area?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —First off, Senator Patterson, we have provided some information to Senator Boswell in response to a similar sort of question. I suspect that that may be the information that the honourable senator requires. Perhaps she might check with her colleague. If we need to supply any more, we certainly will.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of loans to churches, we are talking about loans to churches for a number of church-run funds for the building of schools, nursing homes and the like.

TALK.START.PARA: —School provident funds.

—Yes. There were a few churches involved. I wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and suggested to him that we ought to exclude those funds from the deeming legislation. The letter was sent on Friday afternoon. I am told that we have received the reply and that it is positive.
—You will be releasing the letter?
—I doubt it very much. But the honourable senator will see in the Bill that it will be all right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now turn to the job search allowance. The Committee's report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Department advised that social workers had to make difficult decisions based on their impressions of a claimant's credibility.

There is further elaboration on that. Does the Department take the view that anything further needs to be provided to social workers by way of assistance in making those decisions and, if not, how does the Minister propose to make those difficult decisions a little easier to make?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is worth noting that I am having a look at a number of these concerns. I am not certain whether this is exactly what Senator Alston is getting at but I will give the following answer and we will soon find out. I am looking at three concerns in particular: decisions to grant or reject claims for the young homeless allowance based solely on client interview; advice to parents that their child is safe; and notification to other authorities in cases involving criminal behaviour such as sexual assault. I think these three areas provide us with problems. I am certainly looking at ways of settling them but they are still under consideration.

—Paragraph 16 of the report states that the Minister confirmed that, in his view, the guidelines relating to the youth homeless allowance were inadequate. The report also stated that the Minister would advise the results of the departmental review of the guidelines. I take it that that will involve more than the information we have just been provided with?

—I think the Department is in a position to advise me very shortly on how those guidelines might be redrafted. I would hope to have made a decision on this within, say, a fortnight. I will make the decision public as soon as I do so. So it will not be very long. I will probably get a few hours to look at it next week when Parliament is not sitting.

—In relation to social workers who are put in this difficult situation, could you obtain information-not necessarily today-about the total number of social workers employed by the Department; what qualifications they have; what training they undergo once they join the Department; and what numbers of that total are engaged in making these difficult decisions?

—I will certainly have that information provided. I think there are something like 300-maybe 350-social workers in the Department. I will get the exact number for the honourable senator and the other details.
—I am indebted to the Minister. Are those social workers generally distributed throughout regional offices?
—Yes.
—So we are talking about these decisions being made at the coalface?
—Yes.
—On those figures there would be about one social worker per regional office. So we are talking about the local regional office social worker having to make these decisions?
—Sometimes two, often one, would be the answer.
— Just to hark back to the question of deeming, will you be considering possible amendments in relation to charities in terms of the current social security Bill?

—As I understand the position, a discretion will be given to me in the Bill-if Senator Alston asks me which Bill I will have to seek advice because there are three and I forget which one it is in-to exempt churches in the way that we talked about earlier. Charities are covered under the same clause. Honourable senators will see the wording of this clause in the next couple of days. I am concerned to ensure that we do not open this up to abuse. I will not be adopting anything like the Democrats' suggestion of equating this exemption or exclusion to the tax Act, where a range of different groups can be classified as charities. That would open up another area of abuse and I am desperately trying not to do that.

—It is my understanding that one of the Bills-I also forget which one it is-does not define the terms `deposits' or `financial intermediaries'. The consequence of that may be that whether certain charitable or church bodies are regarded as financial intermediaries will determine whether they are caught up in the legislation. Is the Minister able to indicate whether he proposes to further define `deposits' and `financial intermediaries'?

—The amounts of money in question will be either deposits or loans. When the wording comes into Senator Alston's view, which I hope will be tomorrow night at the latest, he will see that I have a discretion under both.
—I move on to overpayments. Why does the Department not monitor the amount of overpayments made as a consequence of administrative errors?
—A computer system has not been in place to do that. As I have indicated, we are rectifying that and will make sure we have one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the risk of flogging a dead horse by talking about the $848 spent on the overpayments letter, I want to make a comment relating to the September Estimates. When Mr Murphy was asked about the contract of work involved in drafting one letter or a series of letters-it was a bit woolly about whether it was one letter or a series of letters but it seemed to be one letter in the first instance-he said that it was the first letter `we asked to have written by a person whom we understood was very good at writing things in plain English'. Later when asked by Senator Walters whether it was for one letter, Mr Murphy said:

SPEECH.PARA: It was for the standard wording of the first letter and if that was satisfactory then we would have gone on.

As we all know-and it has been repeated here a number of times-$848 was paid to that contractor. I assume the matter would have gone on if that letter was okay. What limit does the Department put on an amount before which it would ask for a contract? Would it be possible for someone to get a job and for it to go on without a proper contractual arrangement or a proper tender being called for what might turn out to be a much larger job than $848 worth?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not certain what Senator Patterson regards as a contract. We will write to any people who will be used as consultants by the Department or to any organisation-there are a few from time to time which take on special tasks-to set out what we are asking them to do and the type of payment they can expect if they do it. They write back and accept. We have regarded that as a contract.

—I am asking: How does the Department identify someone who is good at writing things? Was it someone who had worked in the Department? If there was a possibility of an ongoing arrangement and this $848 was just the beginning, would it have been more appropriate to call for people who could write the letter and then get the best person? It seems that it was not to be just a one-off thing; it was to be an ongoing arrangement to produce a series of letters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs was commenting on these matters, it said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is of paramount importance that DSS forms and letters be clear, precise, non-intimidatory and in plain language. The Department's efforts to achieve this goal have to date been manifestly unsuccessful-
I do not necessarily endorse the comments of the Committee. To continue:

The Committee strongly recommends that the Government's response to this report specifically address the issue of forms and standard letters and set out what steps have been taken to achieve the improvements required.

What occurred was an attempt to accept the spirit of that Senate report and to go outside the Department, given that the claim had been that the Department had been manifestly unsuccessful, to see whether someone else could do better. When that happens it is the responsibility of the officers in that section of the Department to find an expert who can advise. That was done on this occasion. My understanding of the situation was that, if this letter had proved to be successful, between 16 and 20 letters based upon it, as variants of that original letter, would go to clients.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will return to my question. How does the Department identify a person who is very good at writing things in plain English? Was the person formerly a staff member or employee of the Department of Social Security?

—I do not know whether the person was formerly an employee of the Department of Social Security. I shall find out. I would not have thought that would necessarily bar a person from being hired. The only point to make is that, generally speaking, in the Commonwealth, if the amount which someone will be paid to work is less than $2,000, the Department does not have to go into great drama as to the method of hiring. I do not think that on this occasion there is a big deal. We merely write to the relevant person and say, `Will you do this and we will pay you such and such if you will?'. They write back and say yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise some answers provided to questions on notice to the Estimates Committee. One of the questions asked was:

SPEECH.PARA: Would the Department please provide a complete breakdown of costs for which the Department was billed by all consultants it engaged during 1989-90.
The answer was:

A list of consultants, their projects and total costs is included in the Department's Annual Report, a draft of which has been provided.... A consolidated breakdown of costs billed by consultants is not readily available.
I ask: Why not? Is a distinction drawn between `readily' and otherwise? Why are we not able to be provided with an itemised breakdown?

TALK.START.PARA: —The main reason that it is not readily available is that no central record is kept. So as consultants are hired to perform tasks and do so their reports go on files in all the different parts of the Department that have used them. There is no central register, if you like, of consultants and their costs.
—Well, how do you come up with a total cost figure? Someone must bring it together.

—All one can try to do is come up with a cost and say, `As far as we know there were 25 consultants and they were contracted to work at these amounts', and total that up. If there was any variant on that one would not know. Some may come in slightly under, some might come in over, but we would not have those exact amounts unless we went to each file. Fifty consultants were listed in the annual report.

—On 16 May this year the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) launched an organisation called the National Clearing House on Pensioner Investments, which is a project for the Australian Financial Counselling and Credit Reform Association Inc. Does the organisation receive any Commonwealth assistance of either a financial or an administrative nature? If so, to what extent is it assisted?
—Yes, there is Commonwealth funding-$100,000 for the first half year and $200,000 for the full year to follow.
—That is the full extent?
—Yes, that is the full extent from Social Security.
-The National Clearing House is fully funded by the Department of Social Security; is that right?
—Yes.
—At the moment it has a staff of about 2 1/2. Do they travel around Australia on a regular basis?

—There are only a couple of them. Generally speaking they are in the one spot, which is not to suggest that they would never have cause to travel. I do not think we have details of what travel those couple of people may have undertaken. I will endeavour to get them for Senator Alston.

—I was really inquiring about whether the Department has made any attempt to have the services that it might provide made available locally rather than having those people travelling from Canberra around the countryside.

—I think the distinction to be made is that the Clearing House's job is not to solve problems face to face; rather, its job is to prepare literature which can then be of general application. I hope that that answers the honourable senator's question.

—I revert to the consultants' reports. The Minister said that there were 50 of them. He is not seriously suggesting that the Department does not know who commissioned each of those, the name of each of those consultants and the individual amounts involved in each of those reports, is he?

—In the Department's annual report there is a list of every consultant and the exact amount he or she was paid. What we do not have is the breakdown of those costs. I cannot tell the Committee-unless we undertake a pretty fair exercise-whether these dollars were for travel or other matters. They could be used for a whole range of things, but we do not have those breakdowns-only the overall costs. The only point I was trying to make was that I wonder whether it is a sensible or helpful exercise to have the Department go back and break down all of those costs.

—I am indebted to the Minister for that answer. The second question was: could all reports provided by consultants engaged by the Department during 1989-90 be tabled? The answer was: Some reports are confidential. I take it by inference that others are not. Is there any impediment to those being made available?

—Quite a volume could be involved here. But there is no reason why something that is not confidential cannot be made available, and it will be. I undertake to do so. While I am on my feet, I advise Senator Patterson that the contractor about whom we were speaking a few moments ago is not, to the knowledge of the fairly senior people of the Department I have sitting on my left, a previous staff member. We will have that further checked to make absolutely sure, but they do not think that she was.

—I ask a couple of questions about the forms unit. Senator Alston, when asking questions on notice, found that the departmental forms unit had a budgetary allocation of $6.85m for 1989-90 and $8.97m for 1990-91. In my estimation that is an allocation increase for the unit of 31 per cent. Can the Minister explain why there has been such an increase in the budget allocation for that unit?

—If the import of the question is, `Why is there a big increase in cost?', the answer is that it is because of the number of changes required. It is not a function of the Department to make up the number of changes required. Mainly, it comes from the changes that are mandated by the Budget and by the February statement each year-February, March or May; whenever it is delivered. As Senator Patterson would be aware, there have been hundreds of those in the last few years.

—During 1989-90 the forms unit introduced 74 forms, redesigned 203 forms and relinquished 305 forms. For the $6.85m, can the Minister tell us what else the forms department does? Does this budget involve the cost of printing the forms?
—The cost involved here includes printing the forms. It also includes whatever transport costs we have in getting the forms to offices around the country.

— Another question on notice asked the estimated cost of the relocation of the Canberra offices of the Department of Social Security to Tuggeranong. The answer said that the relocation `will be subject to tender processes as construction is almost 40 per cent complete'. One would have thought that the tenders would be well and truly let by now. What is meant by `will be subject to tender processes' in that context?
—We will be going to tender shortly, but we have not gone yet. We are still determining the kind of tender that we will require.

—I am not much the wiser, I must confess. On what basis has 40 per cent of the total work been done to date? Is the Minister saying that it is not on the basis of any tender process? If it has been done on the basis of private contract, why the change?
—The contract so far has been about construction. Here we are speaking about tendering for moving, that is, tendering to physically move officers from one point to another. They are separate matters.
—Is the Minister saying that all of the relocation will be subject to tender?

—I would assume that pretty well all of it would be. That is not to say that we will not discourage staff members from picking up a box of relevant files and taking them to the new offices themselves if they have a desperate urge to do so. But we will be tendering the great bulk of the work.
—Presumably there would be no impediment to publicly releasing the cost involved once those tenders have been let?
—There would be no impediment whatsoever.
—I have a question concerning the amnesty. I am not sure how precise the Minister has been on the public record about the final result of the amnesty.

—I actually gave the latest figures to the Committee on Friday. I do not have them with me today. They are not the final figures, but they were an update. If Senator Alston requires them I will get them again now, but they are in the Hansard from last Friday.

—I am content with that answer. When does the Minister expect to have a final result? In view of the fact that the amnesty was meant to be a one-off exercise, what is the purpose of this new card system that will enable pensioners and beneficiaries to repay overpaid amounts at post offices? Is that meant to be open-ended?

—The purpose of the payment card is that it makes it easier for people. It is purely for convenience. Of course, its use is voluntary so it was introduced for no reason other than to make it easier for those people who need to pay at the post office. The other point that Senator Alston made concerned the amnesty and when it will be finished. There are quite a number of calculations that need to be made, because it also depends upon those people who did not use the formal processes of the amnesty but who, nonetheless, came forward. We have seen a rise in that number and we will have to agree with the Department of Finance on that figure. I would say that within a month or so, and certainly before we rise for Christmas, we could give a final figure.
—I hope our rising is not dependent on that. Is the Minister saying that this new card system has nothing to do with the amnesty?
—It has nothing to do with the amnesty.

—So that people who are volunteering by way of card will not be protected in any way from prosecution or repayment obligations? In other words, if they repay a certain amount of money what protection do they have against the prospect of further inquiries being undertaken and further claims being made on them?

—The people concerned here are those who have already had overpayment claims raised against them. The main complaint that I could imagine coming from them would occur particularly in small towns in country areas where there might be a fear that if they were to use the card system through the post office other people would know and that their business would be known around town. That is why we made the use of the card voluntary, so that there is an in-built protection and those people who have a fear about this identifying them in some way that could cause them discomfort, do not have to use it.
—Is it basically a time payment arrangement for agreed amounts?
—Yes, it already is that.

-I have a few more questions about the amnesty. I believe that the Department estimated that approximately 22,000 people would come forward as a result of the amnesty. What downward effect will the amnesty have on the percentage of social security clients who would have been identified through the planned data-matching arrangements? According to my calculations, if approximately 2 per cent of people were in receipt of incorrect payments, the percentage who will be identified by the social security amnesty, which is quite a significant proportion-almost a quarter-will then not be identified by the data-matching process because they will have already been identified. Is that correct? What effect will the identification of approximately 22,000 people have on the data-matching arrangements?

—It will not have much effect at all. I think a bigger concern along the same lines as the question would probably be how to guarantee that data-matching continues to produce the results that we have estimated for three years after we have found much bigger numbers than 22,000 people in the first year. The experience of social security over time is that fraud continues as people come onto benefits and also as people who have been in receipt of them and have not been indulging in fraud tend to get an urge to commit fraud, and so it continues. We believe that the amounts that we have estimated over those first three or four years-as I made the point on Friday, they were the subject of considerable negotiation and discussion with the Department of Finance- are conservative estimates and we are very confident that those amounts will turn out to be real.

-In relation to the data-matching issue, is it the case that the projected savings provided by the Department, of which the Minister provided me with a copy last Friday and of which some others had received a copy at some other committee meeting-assume that everyone who was identified by data-matching will be on full benefits?
—No. There is a calculation made for each kind of payment, be it full or part.

—That is not very clear. Is the Minister saying that there is an estimation of the number of part payments and of the average number of full payments and that they have been costed into this estimate?

—There is an estimate of the numbers of people on full pensions and benefits whose benefits the Department thinks will be cancelled in full and those which will be reduced and similarly for those on part pensions and benefits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: -Given the fact that we were told at the inquiry last week that if the provision to extend the tax file numbers was not permitted by this Parliament the Minister would not proceed with the data-matching procedure, and given the concern that the Minister has about introducing this and the need on his part to have it introduced, would it not seem appropriate to have much better data provided to the Senate or to the Parliament as to the costings? The Minister might know all of that but the data that I received last week does not indicate how those figures are arrived at. I think it would be more appropriate if the Department could produce a much more detailed set of figures as to how it goes about achieving the cost benefit analysis.

SPEECH.PARA: As we agreed last Friday, this is an issue about balancing privacy against the cost of fraud. We all want to prevent fraud to enable those who are in genuine need, and those who really require social security, to get their fair share of the cake. If all of us have that goal, I want to know what the financial costs are balanced against the social costs. I just do not think that the data we have to date is adequate.

It is all very well for departmental people sitting there with all the information at their fingertips, but those of us on this side of the House, and the Australian Democrats, are trying to make an assessment of whether, in fact, there is a cost benefit involved. With all due respect to the Minister, despite the fact that he has asked me to trust him-he asked me last week to trust him; and I said I was not sure I could trust him and he said he trusted me-I would like more detailed figures that would help me to be convinced that there is a cost benefit, because it is a great social cost that we are imposing on people to provide their tax file number and extending it.
When the tax file number was first being used we were promised by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) as follows:
The tax file numbering system will be administered exclusively by the Tax Office for tax purposes.

He went on a number of times to say that the number would not be applied or extended. Now we have been told it has been extended, and the Minister told us again last Friday that there had been changes in technology. We have been given all the reasons. I just do not think there is sufficient reason to convince me totally that it is a great idea. If the Department could come up with better costings, I think that would help to allay some of the fears on this side of the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly there was no intention on my part to hold anything back. I thought that, in providing the costings last week, we were doing what Senator Patterson required. If she is now saying that she wants the calculations behind the costings, then I am more than happy to have all of that given to her. There is no part of this exercise that I want to hide from Senator Patterson, and I want to make sure that she is fully satisfied. Until she is sated, I will not rest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that I am not going to be the butt of withering sarcasm as well. I have only a couple of short questions. One question taken on notice was:

SPEECH.PARA: For all those who completed spells on the age pension during 1989/90, what is their average period of completed spells . . .
The answer was:
. . . cannot be provided as statistics...are not available.

It seems to me that that is a very serious question to be asked, because it has important implications for long term planning purposes. We need to know whether people are staying on pensions longer than they previously did, and whether that is simply a reflection of people living longer or of declining incomes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not trying to be a problem for Senator Alston, but the difficulty is that we just do not keep records of people once they have gone off. Once they are not our responsibility, we do not keep records.
—I am not suggesting you keep records once they have gone off, but why don't you have records of those people as they do go off and then collate those numbers?
—We can certainly give Senator Alston figures for how many are on, and how long they stay on. We are happy to provide that.

— Anticipated rent for the Department for the current financial year appears to have risen in excess of 18 per cent over last year's rental figure. Could the Minister please explain what accounts for that increase, especially as commercial property rentals have, presumably, taken the same dive as the economy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department has a legal obligation to continue with whatever leasing arrangements have previously been entered into until the expiry of those leases. These leases, based on the best commercial arrangements available at the time, will reflect standard industry practice and there will, of course, be regular rent reviews. To break a lease just involves paying dead rent. Sometimes that might have been necessary, but it is to be avoided if possible.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department has very few offices located in central business districts (CBDs) relative to its decentralisation office network. Only 15 per cent of offices are in CBDs. The declining rental market which is apparent in some capital city CBDs will have no immediate effect on our costs because very few of our offices are there. They are much more likely to be in the suburbs and country locations, where we have not, thus far, detected a declining level of rents.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked for an explanation as to an 18 per cent increase. Is the answer that there are more properties being subject to rental, and those are apparently located in outer suburban areas where rents are rising?
—No. I anticipated that Senator Alston would understand that we are opening more offices all the time. That is the main reason why the rent goes up-we have more places to be in.
—I ask one final question in relation to Age Pension News. Can the Minister for Social Security explain why two copies are sent to married couples rather than one?
—They are not any more. As to the last time that occurred, I am not sure.
—It would be shortly after we asked the question in Question Time.
—No, it is quite some time back. This is one thing for which Senator Alston cannot claim responsibility, like most.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for a point of clarification on the justification of those figures. I presume I am going to get them for the $65m for this year and the $200m for next year.
—Yes.

—Thank you. Senator Alston was talking about Age Pension News. I think we have mentioned that in December 1989 the headline read, `Free medication to continue', and in July 1989 it stated, `Govt guarantee: no charges for pensioners'. When the pharmaceutical charge was introduced I was dying to get my copy of Pension News to see how the Government could tell us the good news-how pensioners were going to hear this good news. I thought, `How will they be able to write the headlines in a favourable way?'. What do I find? The headline states, `$2.50 gain to pay for medicine cost'. I have got to give it to those in the Department: they ought to be out there writing for the Age or the Australian because they can make good news out of bad news. It is amazing. It was very interesting to see that the pensioners were told they were going to get a $2.50 gain for their pain.

SPEECH.PARA: I looked further at Age Pension News-and I think I have mentioned this. In the July 1990 edition, we were told about the virtues of Minister Staples and Mr Sciacca-we were told about their caring attitude. It made them look like saints, or angels with wings and a halo. The only problem with a halo is that it has to be polished every now and then and I think Mr Sciacca had forgotten to polish his, because what do we see in the Australian headline in October 1990? It says, `Emissary taps into pensioners' anger'.

It is quite a different headline from what we saw in the Age Pension News. Here is an article accusing Mr Sciacca of accusing pensioners of going dotty. He did not actually say they went dotty, but he used gesticulations. He used things which Senator Richardson has been told not to use in this chamber. He is quoted as saying:
A lot of you won't understand this, I can see you are going . . .
I do not know how Hansard shows somebody tapping his finger on the side of his head, but that is what he was doing. The article quoted one pensioner as saying:
We're intellectual people fighting for our rights and he got up and tried to tell us we're suffering from Alzheimer's Disease.
I think the portrayal of Mr Sciacca in Age Pension News as the caring person who has suddenly developed a great interest in and affection for the aged maybe needs to have been slightly more modified.

One of the things which interests me about Age Pension News is that there does not seem to be any avenue for any of the major pensioner groups. I thank the Department for sending me copies of the letters that were sent to Age Pension News. I presume they are letters which were written; if not, someone had an awful task running around getting letterheads with gumnuts down the side and all sorts of things, and getting various people to write them. I did note that some of them looked like they had been written by older people who had learned a script of earlier years.

Anyway, when looking at those letters to the editor, we see that none of them are from any of the age or pensioner groups, or retired persons associations.
