It interests me that the Age Pension News does not seem to be an avenue through which those groups seem to be expressing their opinions. It seems to me that it is a very biased publication. As I pointed out from the headlines, it is wonderful how bad news can be made into good news.

I would be interested to know whether the Age Pension News has received any letters from pensioner groups expressing either their praise for the introduction of the change in the medical costs for pharmaceutical benefits for aged people or any other changes that the Government has brought about. Have there been any comments on deeming? If they have written to the editor, why have their opinions not been expressed in the letters to the editor section?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will check on which organisation is sending which letter. We have printed letters critical of the Government's position in Age Pension News which proves how unbiased we are. While it may annoy Senator Patterson, Age Pension News has proved to be phenomenally successful and will continue to be.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable senator's mention of the Australian piece on Mr Sciacca is interesting. I have had cause to complain over the years about efforts that journalists have made in writing about me. I can recall in the last election going to a meeting of 300 people in Rockhampton-a terrific meeting with one person causing a scene for two minutes out of three hours. Of course, true to form, that is what was shown in the news. It was suggested that this was an example of how rowdy the meeting was when, of course, it occurred for only two minutes out of the three hours and was the only example of rowdiness at that meeting. This is something we all get used to.

In Mr Sciacca's case, a person in the audience was making a gesticulation to him. He responded. Unfortunately, most of the crowd looking at him had not seen the other fellow doing it. I suppose that is one to put down to experience. But to suggest that Mr Sciacca was trying to paint those in attendance as suffering from Alzheimer's disease is, of course nonsense.

Having mentioned the meeting, it is worth noting not just how successful Age Pension News is but how successful people such as Mr Sciacca and Mr Staples are, because when I attended a meeting of pensioners on the Friday week after the Budget, it was indeed rowdy. Somewhere between 2,000 and 3,000 people assembled at the Sydney Town Hall and they gave me a very hard time. But such were the explanations that I was able to give, that Minister Staples was able to give and that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security, Mr Sciacca, was able to give that the meeting we are now talking about had 160 people attending. The same people organised it and this time they had 160. They knew the issue no longer had legs. They did not even book the hall; they had it outside. In Age Pension News there were some excellent explanations of what has been going on. Because they were excellent explanations, they had been accepted by the pensioner community in Australia. I wish to place on record my gratitude to those who prepare Age Pension News for the very fine job they have done.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question in relation to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders employment strategy. The Department has created a staff position at ASO6 level within the equal opportunity program to implement a strategy designed to eliminate and overcome employment and career barriers for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander staff. I think that in November 1989, $41,000 was spent on a consultant's report. This strategy is being developed within the context of the Aboriginal employment development program developed by the Department of Employment, Education and Training for the Australian Public Service. Is it correct that the Department of Employment, Education and Training has already developed a program to facilitate the employment of Aboriginal people in the Australian Public Service; and, if so, how can the Department of Social Security justify expenditure on consultant staff and a new strategy for the same purpose?

—I think the Department of Social Security has more to do with on-the-ground service delivery to Aboriginal groups than any other department-at times even including the Department of Aboriginal Affairs-because it is our Department which is the payment agency for so many communities. We are providing a range of services to them in a way that no other part of the Public Service can possibly be doing. I think that whatever strategy is in place for the Service as a whole, we need to make special, particular and continued efforts to assist in service delivery to Aboriginals, and part of that must be an employment strategy for them within the Department as well.

— Given the fact that the information I have is that the Department of Employment, Education and Training is also running a program, what consultation was there between the Department of Social Security and DEET to ensure that there was not an overlap and that we were not reinventing the wheel?
—I cannot tell the honourable senator, right now, who talked to whom but the wheel has not been reinvented, only improved.
— As there are no further matters for examination in the Department of Social Security, the Committee will move to the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories.

—We would like to proceed with these sections of the Department in the order that they appear in the explanatory notes, for the convenience of all honourable senators and to save the inconvenience of calling them in.
—There is no problem if you wish to do that. I was proceeding in the order as listed.
—In there it is Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. In the explanatory notes it is Sport, Tourism, Antarctic, Territories, Arts. Perhaps I can give the Minister a copy of this.
—I have one now. I just sent a runner to find Sport and Recreation in a hurry.
—There is no need to hurry. Things should be done in an orderly fashion. If they can be done in that fashion, each of the Whips can see that things flow.
—I think I can give an undertaking that it will be done in the order that has now been placed before me.

—If it is going to help the Committee, I think it is a good suggestion. The first on the list is Sport and Recreation. Before calling Senator Michael Baume, I remind him that I personally made mention to him of the particular reservation that he had. It is very wide because the honourable senator asked that all the issues raised in the Estimates Committee relating to Arts, Sports and Antarctica be further examined. I think this is casting such a wide net that it is almost suggesting that we go back to the Estimates committees themselves. I am not quite sure whether Senator Baume has been able to specify in any greater detail for himself the issues that he is going to raise here, but I would like to see how things go for a moment. I would suggest that to cast reservations in such a wide manner is not really acceptable. I would prefer it in future if the Estimates were a little more specific than they have been. I have no intention, Senator Baume, of trying to curtail debate, but it makes it a little easier for the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, if this year's Estimates are any example, it is not convenient for me to limit in the way you suggested the sort of reservation I made on various grounds. In the first place, when there is a delay of some time between Estimates hearings and the Appropriation Bills debate, many issues arise as a result of both publicity and contact made with people who have knowledge of the matters raised in Estimates committees which put new light on many of the answers provided. That has certainly happened in this case. I have received a large amount of information subsequent to the Estimates committees. For example, I sent the Hansard of the Senate Estimates meetings to interested people. Your suggestion to me-and I take it that it is only a suggestion at this stage-would prevent me, if I did not have a broad description of what I planned to make a reservation about, from raising matters on which I have subsequent information relating specifically to the Estimates and specifically to the debates on which we are reporting.

SPEECH.PARA: In the absence of any discussion-and I concede, Mr Chairman, that you wrote to me on this matter but I have been very busy preparing for, among other things, this debate-with you and with the chamber as a whole, I cannot see that I can accept your recommendation at all. In those circumstances, all I can say is that the Standing Orders clearly set out a situation where I can make the sort of reservation I did. I do not intend to canvass once again all the issues raised in the Estimates. What I seek to do is to raise those issues which merit further consideration because of matters that took place subsequently, particularly in respect of unanswered questions or questions which, perhaps, it has since been established, were not answered satisfactorily in the Estimates Committee itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to see how we go until 6.30, and I will think about the matter over the dinner break. If we see how we go to 6.30, that will give me some indication of how we are proceeding.

—That poses a problem in the sense that your saying `We will see how we go' sounds as though I am on trial to see whether I behave `properly', as far as you, Mr Chairman, are concerned, and yet what I am doing is totally and absolutely within the Standing Orders. In the absence of any ruling on your part that I am outside the Standing Orders, I would have great difficulty in accepting your suggestion.
—The suggestion is there and I am giving you the call.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I do not consider myself under some sort of trial period until dinner time to see whether what I am saying is within the broad reservation I made. To my understanding, based on the advice of the Clerks, the reservation I made entitles me to raise all matters in exactly the same terms as exist in my letter at the back of the report. That advice was given to me by the Clerks and if it has somehow magically changed, I would certainly like to see it in writing. I do not believe it is appropriate that I should be held to be under some kind of constraint and that I am allowed to speak conditionally on my meeting some criteria about which I have no idea. They are in your mind, Mr Chairman, but to my knowledge they are not expressed anywhere formally.

SPEECH.PARA: I wanted to start off by raising the problem of drugs in sport, which was raised fairly substantially in the Estimates Committee. By the way, Mr Chairman, I notice that the clock now says--

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us start the clock again at 15 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Chairman. In the Estimates Committee I asked the Department:

SPEECH.PARA: To what extent is the AIS using East German and other East European coaches, who I understand are in surplus supply at the moment?

I was given a written response which said that only two eastern European coaches were brought into Australia in 1989-90-they were Mr Korner from East Germany and Mr Popov from the Soviet Union-but that the Australian Institute of Sport (AIS) cycling unit was currently negotiating to bring a leading East German coach to Australia to assist the track cycling team to prepare for the 1992 Barcelona Olympic Games. That answer was sent to me in October and related to a question asked on 11 September 1990. It seems curious in light of the answer to a subsequent question. On 16 October the Minister replied to a question I asked about East German coaches not by saying that there were two, with the possibility of bringing in another cycling coach, but that five East German coaches were currently, or were soon to be, involved in programs funded by the Australian Sports Commission (ASC). They relate to cycling and rowing.
The reason for my concern is that there have been serious allegations about the use of drugs in sport in East Germany. I particularly asked the Minister about that in this question. I asked him for:

. . . an unequivocal assurance that no East German sports coaches who participated in this organised program of cheating through performance enhancing drugs have been, or will be, used by the Australian Institute of Sport or any other government-funded body in the sports arena. What assurances do we have that East German sports coaches already here did not participate in this program of authorised poisoning of young athletes?

I am concerned that the answer I got does not seem to meet that question. That question was asked on 11 October and on 16 October Senator Richardson said he had been advised by the Minister, who would, I imagine, be Mrs Kelly in this case, that:
The Australian Sports Commission is unaware of any information or allegations which would lead it to believe that any of these coaches-
that is, those eastern European coaches who are coming to Australia-
. . . have been, are, or are likely to be, involved in providing anabolic steroids to Australian athletes or promoting their use.

That was not the question. The question was: were we confident they had never been involved in the East German campaign-an organised, official campaign of abuse of performance enhancing drugs by the East German authorities? In view of the confusion generated by the replies to the questions on notice from the Estimates Committee and the reply in this chamber-the confusion being whether it is three coaches or five-I would like to know: are we confident and have we inquired into whether these coaches were involved in any way in any sporting activities in East Germany where drugs were used?

I believe it is vital that that specific question be specifically answered, and not only because of allegations by Professor Hermann Buhl about the use of anabolic steroids in East German sports training programs for almost 20 years. I draw the Minister's attention to an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald. I shall quote a couple of extracts from it. It states:

The failure of East Germany's world champion swimmers to qualify last week for the united-German world championship team heading to Perth in January indicated that their world dominance had been drug-assisted, head Australian coach Don Talbot claimed yesterday.
These are not just wild allegations; this is the head Australian swimming coach. The article continues:

While it was shattering for the individual swimmers to perform so poorly, Talbot said that after pitting his swimmers against drug-assisted teams for almost 20 years he wasn't about to shed a tear over the passing of the East Germans.

`I feel no pity or compassion' Talbot said. `It is about time swimming records were brought back to reality. The East Germans have dominated the world for the past few years and then suddenly, en masse, they drop by the wayside. It just shows that something has been going on.

`Some swimmers and coaches have already admitted to using steroids and their failure at the trials doesn't surprise me at all. Since 1972, whether I have been coaching here in Australia, in Canada or the US, I've had to deal with it. At last maybe there is some justice, and the swimmers who have been suspect are falling to the back of the field.

Here we have continuing clear indications of the extent to which there has been cheating in sport and drugs in sport, and particularly in eastern Europe and among eastern European coaches. Here we are importing eastern European coaches to assist Australians in our elite sports program. These East German coaches are not coming here to coach the run of the mill athletes; they are here to coach the top ones.

I ask the Minister again-but this time I would really like a reply that relates to the experience of these people in East Germany-whether any of these coaches have been involved in any of the sports in which drug taking appears to have been the norm in East Germany? Have inquiries been made to ensure that they have been in no way involved in any organised campaigns of performance enhancing drug taking in East Germany? If no inquiries have been made, will they be made?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There appears to be a confusion about the questions. The questions that were asked concern in one case the Australian Institute of Sport and what coaches it might have had. The other was a more general question relating to coaches coming to Australia which would, of course, include what national sporting associations might do in relation to the hiring of coaches. So both answers were correct.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the Australian Institute of Sport is concerned, in hiring a coach it consults with the head coach of the national association and with the national association itself. When one pools the knowledge that the Australian Sports Commission has with what the national association has and the head coach has, if there is a suggestion that there is something wrong with a visiting coach then the appointment would be blocked. That has not been the case on any occasion. When Don Talbot speaks about his views of what might have gone on in swimming he may well be right, but we have not hired a swimming coach, so it has not been a problem for us. We have no evidence of any kind that the East German coaches that we listed for Senator Baume have had any involvement in the use of drugs either in their own country or in this one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Michael Baume, before you make a further contribution, I do not particularly want to open up the matter that we mentioned earlier, but you did mention that you had advice from the clerks that your reservation was satisfactory. Could I ask you which clerks you received advice from?

—Whoever was the clerk advising the Committee. In fact, he wrote the reservation for me. I asked him what would be the correct form for the reservation to be in. He very kindly did it for me, and I signed it.
—Thank you. That was Mr Grundy.
—You mean the Committee Secretary, do you?

—I guess so, if the Committee Secretary is Mr Grundy. I must say I cannot remember who it was but it was done for me by the organisation, the structure, and I presumed-apparently incorrectly, I gather from the note of the inquiries-that the organisation had established some procedure.
—That is fine.

—I am concerned that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) believes that both answers on those coaches were correct. As I understand it from his answer of 16 October, among the programs funded by the Australian Sports Commission involving East German coaches were the Australian Institute of Sport residential programs of cycling and rowing, where the coaches concerned are Michael Hubner, an AIS cycling coach, and Theo Korner, an AIS rowing coach-and he is the only one mentioned in the reply to my question on notice. The others relate to coaches with intensive training centres: in rowing, Stefan Muelberg and Harrald Jahling; and, in cycling, Heiko Salzwedel. The answer to the question on notice mentioned a totally different name, that of a Mr Boris Popov from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, who was simply an eastern European coach. So it does seem to me that there were different people. That is, I guess, by the way.
—There is no difference in his mind.
—They seem to be different people to me.
—No, different nationalities.

—I had asked about both eastern European and East German coaches. I have ended up with five East Germans in the reply that the Minister gave, and one East German in the reply on notice with the possibility of another one. It does not seem to me to add up. Anyway, let us proceed now to the question of drug free powerlifting. I would be grateful if the Minister could let me know when it is likely that the AIS would have made a decision on the review of that matter? Is that the matter that was announced the other day? I would be grateful if the Minister could let me know what the state of play is with the Australian Drug Free Powerlifting Federation's request for recognition.

—As I understand the position, it is still under review. Additional meetings will be sought with the two bodies and we would hope that as a result of those meetings we can get an amalgamation of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a matter of some concern, and perhaps it is fortunate that the matter has not been resolved yet because this could be taken into account. I spoke a week or so ago to the National Secretary of the Australian Drug Free Powerlifting Federation (ADFPF), Mr Ron Williams, who, apart from being the National Secretary, is also involved in blind sport in Australia. It had been his hope that the ADFPF would host the powerlifting section of the 1991 World Blind Games to be held in Australia. To this end he had been in regular contact with the Executive Officer of the Blind Sports Federation, Mr Ian Fowler.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Williams indicated that he had been informed by Mr Fowler that the Australian Powerlifting Federation (APF)-that is the one that got the money rather than the drug free ones who did not-had been granted the right to host the powerlifting section of the 1991 World Blind Games. Mr Fowler had said that the Australian Sports Commission (ASC) had made this recommendation to the Blind Sports Federation over two months ago. At the time of my speaking this would have been back in August.

Obviously I have no reason to doubt the words of these people, but it seems that if that is so it is at odds with assurances given to the ADFPF, as I understand it, by Mr Weir and Mr Crosswhite that neither the APF nor the ADFPF would receive recognition until after the ASC had considered the outcome of the Black inquiry into drugs in sport. I am wondering whether some officers may have pre-empted the decision of the ASC which, as I understand it, was not made until 27 September, and whether that pre-empting would have been by some two months.

In the circumstances I wonder whether the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) might like to make available to me the submissions made by the APF and the ADFPF with a view to our being able to compare them and to look at the accuracy of the information contained in them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Submissions for what?
—Their submissions to the ASC.
—For what?

—For `recognition'. Is this not what it is all about? The ASC has taken the view that it cannot provide funding for both; it must recognise only one. I understand that is exactly correct. I do not know the reason for all the head-shaking opposite. The ASC, as I understand it, recognises only one body as the national body. I would have thought the word `recognition' tended to cover that fairly accurately, but maybe it does not. I believe that in the circumstances it would be useful if we had access to the information used by the ASC in making its decision regarding powerlifting, especially if there is some suggestion-and I cannot vouch for its accuracy-that the decision had been pre-empted and that there was a predisposition to provide funding to the Australian Powerlifting Federation rather than to the Australian Drug Free Powerlifting Federation.

SPEECH.PARA: This is particularly serious to my mind on the grounds of recent experience. In the 1990 Australian open championships the Australian Sports Drug Agency (ASDA) conducted, for the ADFPF, 23 drug tests with no refusals and apparently no positives. This followed the previous year where there were six positive drug tests, the last five having been in the past 12 months when, in accordance with the recommendations of the Black inquiry, the ADFPF attempted to open its membership to persons from the old powerlifters. Two lifters were found to have used anabolic steroids. One was suspended for three years and the other received a lifetime ban for the additional activity of trafficking in the drug. Two lifters tested positive for the use of diuretics and one for grossly excessive use of a stimulant. Those three also received three year suspensions. The key point is that in the 1990 championships there were no refusals and apparently no positives.

This, as I understand it, is unlike the Australian Powerlifting Federation where, I am told, that, at its 1990 national titles, one State team withdrew at the venue prior to the competition commencing when it was alleged that it found that testing would be conducted, where there were a number of refusals to be tested, and apparently some positive tests. It has been suggested to me that there were four. This is all in the only competition that the APF has had tested this year. The ADFPF has also placed all random drug testing of its members in the hands of the ASDA.

It may be that I am receiving information from one side only and perhaps there is an appropriate response, but it seems to me that an enormous problem has emerged in sporting groups. For example, in boxing we have seen rival organisations proceeding. I am beginning to wonder whether the ASC may have to consider taking a different approach to whether `recognition' should be given to only one body. I think that the biggest amateur boxing organisation in Victoria receives no assistance because it has broken away from the Mr Arthur Tunstall body. As a result it is unable to get the support or recognition that it claims it needs, particularly in the context of what I understand to have been some very critical Victorian Government comments on the manner in which that Victorian boxing organisation has been run. That is by the way, but I would like to hear a response on the powerlifting aspect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first point to make is that I would be very strongly against the Australian Sports Commission (ASC) changing its policy and recognising more than one body. To do so would invite chaos. In the case of all these associations the criterion to be observed essentially is that there is a representative body to which it is affiliated in each State and there is an affiliation to an international body. If one looks at what is happening in boxing, I think one has to say that the body which Arthur Tunstall is involved represents far more in many more places. As in politics, you can get breakaways caused by all sorts of arguments, but it ought not to be the ASC's function to fund people who are aggrieved, rightly or wrongly, by a decision taken by a national body.

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of these two powerlifting federations, I am advised that Senator Michael Baume is getting one side of the story that is not entirely correct. I am advised that the allegation of a State team withdrawing is not true. Obviously I have no personal knowledge of this, but that is what I am advised. Having spent a few years in the portfolio, I would say that it does not surprise me at all. I am also advised that athletes from both organisations have tested positive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Numbers of athletes from both organisations?
—Numbers of athletes from both organisations have tested positive.
—I have not asked as to dates.
—That was the point I was making.
—All I can say is that it was during the last financial year, 1989-90, which is still pretty recent.
—But I was talking about the last national championships.

—I am not saying that this is what happened, but if everyone had cleaned up for a national championships in one month and had not been all that clean three months earlier, it would not make a lot of difference. I think that if athletes in both organisations have been tested positive in the past 12 months, that is indicative of a problem across the sport.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is examining the expenditure considered by Estimates Committee C. The question is that the report of Estimates Committee C be adopted.
—Before the suspension of sitting for dinner, I was making some points about drugs in sport. I think the Minister had completed or was completing an answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there are just a few points to add. Because the dinner break intervened, it is difficult to recall exactly the point I had reached. To conduct the world blind sports powerlifting championships, the Australian organisers are required to use officials recognised by the International Powerlifting Federation. The difficulty is that only the one body has that recognition; that is, the body that is not titled `drug free', whether or not `drug free' is the appropriate title. That is the determining factor, and that is something that is beyond our control. I am, therefore, reluctant to go any further because the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) has said that she is reviewing the decision. We will certainly make available to the honourable senator submissions that were made to the Australian Sports Commission (ASC) when it made its original decision. I do not think any submissions have been made since this review; rather, the Commission is conducting a number of meetings. But we will certainly make the initial submissions clear to the honourable senator.

SPEECH.PARA: From talking to officials during the honourable senator's contribution, I believe that he was getting one side of the story-there is another side. I cannot evaluate which side is right or wrong, but hopefully we will come to a position where there is only one body and, hopefully, we can do that fairly soon.

I do not seek to interrupt the honourable senator's discussion on powerlifting. He did ask a number of questions. On that matter I have a couple of pages which have been prepared over the dinner break and which I think will be of assistance. Prior to the dinner break, I was asked a number of questions concerning East German sports coaches. I think they are now Germans from the eastern part of Germany, rather than East Germans.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nice point.
—I am glad that Senator Collins approves; he is improving. On 11 October this year, Senator Michael Baume asked me the following question in the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister for an unequivocal assurance that no East German sports coaches who participated in this organised program of cheating through performance enhancing drugs have been, or will be, used by the Australian Institute of Sport or any other government-funded body in the sports arena.
The question asked by Senator Michael Baume in the Senate Estimates Committee was:
To what extent is the AIS using East German and other East European coaches, who I understand are in surplus supply at the moment?

Obviously there is a difference between the two questions. In responding earlier, I was attempting to point out that difference. There are several programs that the Australian Sports Commission runs that are separate from those of the Australian Institute of Sport (AIS). In the main, I think we are referring to the funding of coaches by national organisations. Obviously those two are quite separate.

The answer to the first question-the Senate Estimates Committee question: What are we using East German and other eastern European coaches for?-is that in 1989-90 there were two eastern European coaches brought to this country. One was Theo Korner, who was East German, and the other was Boris Popov of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Mr Popov has now completed his contract and has popped off.

TALK.START.PARA: —I knew you were going to say that.

—I knew that you knew! What can I say? It was foreshadowed that another coach could be contracted for cycling. In answer to the second question, that asked in the Senate, I said that five East German coaches are currently or are soon to be involved in programs funded by the ASC. The programs are the AIS residential programs in cycling and rowing and the State-based Intensive Training Centre programs in cycling and rowing. The coaches concerned are Michael Hubner, an AIS cycling coach who will undertake a 10-week contract commencing November 1990-I do not think he is here yet, but he is on the way-Theo Korner, a rowing coach currently on a six-month contract which concludes in November; Heiko Salzwedel a coach with the Intensive Training Centre in cycling; and Stefan Muelberg and Harrald Jahling, both with the Intensive Training Centre in rowing. The coaches, other than those employed by the AIS, are contracted to national sporting organisations in cycling and rowing and those sports, of course, are receiving ASC funding.

SPEECH.PARA: What I am saying is that even if one looks at the exact terms of the questions and answers, the answers are still accurate. Obviously, elite coaching is fundamental to performance so it is obviously worth funding by the Sports Commission. At the same time the Australian Institute of Sport is training elite athletes as well. But in either category we have made every inquiry possible as to whether or not any of these people have been involved in the use of drugs in sport. We have no evidence that any are involved and so we have no reason to query their appointment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that last response because that is really the response that I have wanted all along-that the Government has made every inquiry possible to establish that these people have not been involved in any drugs in sport, particularly in East Germany. With respect, Minister, the reason I pressed this was because I had not got that response before. I am grateful to have it and I certainly accept it totally.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make another point in passing about the matters that the Minister raised. I do not want to be too long about it because I think Senator Short wants to make a few remarks about Melbourne's bid for the Olympic Games. The Minister pointed out that powerlifting had an international body. Maybe I am listening to only one side of the case again but, as I understand it, there is a monumental volume of irrelevance about that fact in this context in that, to my knowledge, the powerlifters have not in fact participated in international meets run by that organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not true.
—Unfortunately I do not have my papers before me. I foolishly gave them to Hansard. I am having to rely on my memory of what was in the background papers.

—Madam Temporary Chairman, I take a point of order. I think, in defence of Hansard, it is not foolish to give papers to that organisation. It is in fact necessary for the purposes of carrying on the effective business of this Senate.
—It was foolish, Madam Temporary Chairman, in that rather than giving Hansard photocopies I gave it the original documents, not realising that I would need them later.
-Imprudent, perhaps.

—Thank you; imprudent. While the Minister is in this very benign frame of mind and is prepared to answer my questions in such detail as he did in the case of the last one, I might ask him another question. Mr Haynes made a statement to Estimates Committee C that the Australian Sports Drug Agency is indeed making an input to the decision making process-in other words, the governmental decisionmaking process-by providing information on the harmful effects of anabolic steroid use at a workshop in Perth in October which will precede recommendations going to the ministerial council on drug strategy. I am wondering whether the Committee can be informed of this information. I would think that there would be a great deal of merit in it being made available to us. One would hope that all of us in this chamber, following the report of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts on drugs in sport, would be mindful of the need to communicate as fully as possible the harmful effects of anabolic steroid use. If the workshop was conducted in public, I must say that I would be grateful to receive a copy of the material.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Senator Baume can have the material. It is material presented by doctors on the medical harmful effects that steroids can have on athletes. We will be happy to make that available to the honourable senator.

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the honourable senator's earlier remarks about powerlifting, let me say that the Australian federation was a founding member of the World Games. Three World Games have been held, in 1981, 1985 and 1989. Powerlifters took part in each of them and Australian power-lifters competed in the past two. The World Games are conducted under the auspices of the General Association of International Sports Federations. The International Powerlifting Federation is a member of that and the Australian Powerlifting Federation is the Australian affiliate of the IPF. So I think, as I said, the honourable senator has been getting one side of the story. I am still not making a judgment between the two organisations but there are two sides to the story.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! During the suspension of the sitting for dinner I further examined the reservation by Senator Michael Baume attached to the report of Estimates Committee C. I would like to quote from recommendation 5 of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Legislation Procedures:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Committee recommends that debate on appropriation bills in the committee of the whole be confined to matters referred to in Estimates Committee reports for further examination.

This procedure would ensure that the original intention of Estimates Committees, as implied in paragraph (17) of Standing Order 36AB, is more closely adhered to, namely, that the committees focus the attention of the Senate on particular matters which they believe require further examination. The reference to reports in this recommendation includes any reservations attached to the reports.

The reports of the Estimates Committees should include schedules of questions not answered at the time of reporting, with a recommendation to the effect that those questions are referred to the Senate for further consideration until they are answered. This would allow questions still unanswered at the time of the committee of the whole debate to be referred to at that time.

The Committee considers that the committee of the whole procedures on the appropriation bills should not be regarded as a further opportunity for questions to be put to Ministers and officers, other than the unanswered questions referred to in the previous paragraph. Ministers should not otherwise have officers in attendance, Senators should direct their remarks to the matters contained in the Estimates Committees' reports, and any responses which may be necessary should normally be given by the chairmen of the committees or the authors of any reservations to elucidate or supplement the material contained in the committee reports or reservations.

In reading that quotation, I do not suggest that they are necessarily the procedures that should be used in the Senate. I have read them to indicate what the Committee considered when it brought down that report.

I consider that the reservation of Senator Michael Baume is contrary to the spirit and intention of the new procedures which were intended to focus debate on specific matters in the Committee of the Whole. Consistent with the statement I made yesterday, however, I intend to allow the reservation to be the subject of debate on this occasion but I consider that in future senators ought to adhere strictly to the spirit of the procedures and refer to specific matters in reservations.

There will probably be some matters which have to be referred to the Standing Committee on Procedure as a result of experience gained in this series of Estimates committee hearings. Broad reservations such as that which was listed by Senator Baume may have to be one of the matters referred. In brief, Senator Baume, you may continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Chairman. I also note that on page 25 of the Standing Orders relating to Estimates, standing order 26(14) states:

SPEECH.PARA: The report of a Committee may propose the further consideration of any items.
Mr Chairman, I am dealing with `any items'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, you are, at the discretion of the Chair.
—Mr Chairman, with respect, I am dealing with it under Standing Orders. Until the Committee determines--
—Senator Michael Baume, we have discussed that matter and I would ask you to get on with a consideration of the Estimates.
—Mr Chairman, you have instructed me on a matter-
—You may have misunderstood the Chairman. The Chairman was alluding to what might have to be the procedure at a later date. He invited you to continue.
—I thank the honourable senator for his intervention.
—I am not quite sure that that is what I was referring to.
—I would prefer to believe that it was, Mr Chairman; I would hate to see us in disagreement.
—That would be quite easy, I think. Please continue, Senator Baume.

—On the basis that I first mentioned there are some matters that I wish to raise involving corrections to statements made in Senate Estimates hearings. I draw attention to a comment-a genuine mistake, I assume-by Mr Arnaudon when I asked him about the announcement of the $3m to Western Australia for capital works expenditure associated with the staging of the World Swimming Championships. Mr Arnaudon said:

SPEECH.PARA: It was announced by Senator Richardson in March, I believe, of 1989. A contribution was made by Mrs Kelly in July.
I have since got a written response which corrects that and says that it was announced on 19 February 1990. I acknowledge that that was a slip of the tongue. There was nothing significant--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Arnaudon might think that that was one of the incredibly rare occasions on which Hansard might have made an error. Perhaps Hansard is of the view that he may have. In any event, it was certainly 1990, not 1989.

—It was certainly not in 1989, no. A subsequent response that I have says 1990; it is only that it is repeated twice in the Hansard. That is not the point I am making. The point I am making is that the correct figure, which we have received subsequent to the Estimates discussions, reveals that it was 19 February 1990-five weeks before the Federal election. There are those who say that that is quite remarkable timing. In Western Australia-an area where there was a degree of political sensitivity, where there were suggestions that the opinion polls were showing the possibility of the loss of some seats for the Australian Labor Party-an announcement was magically made five weeks before the election.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise this matter because there is always the fear that the good things that emerge in terms of funding in areas such as sport can at times be used for political benefit to a political party, just as it seems that some politics were involved in the announcements relating to the Melbourne Olympic Games support from the Federal Parliament. I must say that these things cause problems for the Opposition, not because the Government is funding these capital works but because of the nature and timing of them. For example, I draw it to the Committee's attention that there have been only about five capital payments for various events over the last decade, including grants for the World Cup Athletics in Canberra in 1984, grants for the Americas Cup defence in Fremantle in 1987--

TALK.START.PARA: —How much was that?

—That was a contribution of $30m for something which could hardly be described as the working man's sport. There was a grant to the Brisbane Commonwealth Games in 1982 and so on. As Mr Arnaudon told us, an Australian Sports Commission policy states that grants are not to be automatic; they are to be considered by the Cabinet on a one on one case basis. I am asking this genuinely; I cannot remember: What type of capital contribution went to assist the Tasmanian Government in its staging of the World Rowing Championships, which I believe were very well organised, and when was it announced?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were no grants for capital costs but $250,000 was made available to the organisation for the event. I do not seek to comment on everything that Senator Michael Baume has just said; suffice to say that while I was Minister there was no possibility of politics entering into decisions about allocation of money to sport.
—Oh, Senator Richardson, your nose is growing; I can see it from here.

—There was absolutely no possibility. In fact, the two examples which Senator Baume has quoted are classic examples of where they did not. The announcement on the Melbourne Olympics had nothing to do with the timing of an election and had everything to do with a visit to Australia by a number of people which was to coincide with the Australian Open Tennis Championships, I think, but it involved Samaranch, God himself, and a number of the archangels. That being the case, we were under quite considerable pressure from the Victorian Government about an early announcement. In respect of the World Swimming Championships, the Western Australian Government would regard the date of our announcement as very late indeed. In fact, it had been pressing for months-I cannot recall--
—Were you delaying it until just before the election?
—As I have just said, while I was Minister there was not even the possibility of politics entering into it.
—You are from the Government. You are here to help me.

—I was there to help Australian sport; now I am here to help Australian pensioners. A letter had been received from the Western Australian Government some months earlier requesting this assistance. If it is important to Senator Baume, I could get the date of that letter. It was certainly in 1989. We had been pressed, because, had the Western Australian Government not been able to make some announcement about this, it would have found itself in great difficulty in holding the championships.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Sports Commission and the Government regarded the holding of these championships as a very important event in Australian sport. I am quite convinced, therefore, that the Commonwealth involvement was worth while. Quite seriously, it had nothing to do with elections. Whether there had been an election or not, we would still have had to make that announcement. The fact that it came at the time of an election was fortuitous and I do not regret it, but it had nought to do with the decision. We had been working on it for some months. In respect of the decision on the Olympics, the Government would have been remiss in its duty and would have been very roundly criticised had it not made the decision when it did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The points that Senator Michael Baume has been making in relation to grants for sporting functions, of which he has mentioned several, are matters that I wish to touch on briefly in my remarks. The area in which I am particularly interested-as Senator Richardson is no doubt aware-is the Commonwealth's decision on 23 January to grant Victoria a maximum of $125m towards the construction of the Albert Park sports complex should Melbourne be selected as the host city for the Olympic Games.

SPEECH.PARA: I noted with interest the comment of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), which I well understand, that the Government was under pressure from the Victorian Government for an early announcement because important people were coming here in early February. Is that the reason why the decision was announced jointly by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), as I recall, and the then Victorian Premier, John Cain, at the Australian Open Tennis Championships on 25 January?

TALK.START.PARA: —The announcement was made at the time because, as I said, a number of voting delegates from the Olympic Federations of a number of countries were here, including Mr Samaranch. I think that they came for that tennis event. A number of them were going to take the opportunity to look at it as well as evaluate Melbourne. In fact, I recall being introduced to a few of them in Victoria at the time. I do not remember their names now but I can--
—Pretty important at the time.

—I was deferential of course. It was because they were in town. Whether or not other people had been accompanying Mr Samaranch, his presence alone would have been sufficient for the Government to want to take a decision at the time, and that is why it was announced then.

—The decision was announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 28 January and the Cabinet decision was taken on the twenty-third? The first paragraph of the Prime Minister's press release of 28 January-and I think the Victorian Premier put out a very similar one-said that the Federal Government would provide $125m towards the cost of a world standard sporting complex at Albert Park if Melbourne was chosen to host the Olympic Games. Was there any qualification to that statement on the Government's part? As I understand it, the Government needed an unequivocal statement before these dignitaries came out. That seems pretty unequivocal. I assume that was the case. Could the Minister give me confirmation of that?

—I think there were two qualifications. I hasten to add that I do not have the documents in front of me, nor do I recall the exact dates. But as I recall, there were two inbuilt qualifications. One was that we said up to $125m and the other was `if chosen'. We had two qualifications built into the decision.

—But the decision to commit up to $125m, as I understand it, was an unequivocal and unconditional commitment, assuming Melbourne got the Games. That is what I am seeking confirmation of. I accept the point that the grant was up to a maximum of $125m and that, subject to Melbourne being granted the Games, the announcement was unconditional and unequivocal. I presume that is the case; it would appear to be the case. That is really what I am seeking confirmation on. If that were not the case, then the ability to impress the visiting dignitaries would have lost most of its point. Could the Minister confirm that for me?
—In so far as announcements were concerned, there were only two qualifications. As far as those whom Melbourne was trying to impress were concerned, they were the only qualifications that mattered.
—I thank the Minister. From what he has said I take it that the decision that we have just been discussing was not subject to anything else in terms of its unconditionality or unequivocation.

—There have been a number of answers to this from Ministers far senior to me. I do not think that there is anything useful that I can add to the statements made by the Prime Minister or his representative in this chamber, Senator Button. In so far as I can recall, there was going to be an examination by the departmental committee. We wanted to ascertain the veracity of the costings, even though that was irrelevant to the fact that we had set a limit. It would not have mattered whether the costings were right, wrong or indifferent; we still were not going above the figure we had announced. But we were going to make sure of the veracity of those costings. The Commonwealth was quite properly concerned to ensure that it was not put in a position where more than that which it was prepared to promise could have been asked.

—I thank the Minister. I understood the Minister to say that the actual analysis was irrelevant-I think he used the term `irrelevant'-because the terms of the Government's decision, as announced in the Cabinet decision of 23 January, set a maximum of $125m on the Federal Government's commitment. Therefore, as I can see it, there was no way that the Commonwealth could have been committed for more than $125m. It may have been able to get away with a little less if the total cost of the complex was less than $250m because it was a one for one matching basis with the Victorian Government. I think that the Minister is nodding ascent on that point.

—I am nodding ascent to the proposition that the Commonwealth protected its position by nominating an upper limit and that any examination was obviously irrelevant to the upper limit because it could not have been changed. It is quite possible that the examination may have had relevance to a lower limit, but it certainly could not have resulted in an amount of money higher than $125m, no matter what the examination had shown.

—I share the Minister's view on that; it seems to be self-evident. We seem to be agreeing on the fact that the decision to provide up to a maximum of $125m was really conditional only on the basis that Melbourne be granted the Games. If Melbourne were not granted the Games, then the whole thing would be irrelevant. But that being the condition, the only other matter subject to any sort of issue at all was whether the figure would be the maximum of $125m or whether it would be some lesser figure, depending on whether the cost of the complex would be $250m or less in total. That decision was not subject to any other condition. That seems to be absolutely and unequivocally clear. I would like the Minister's concurrence that it is absolutely and unequivocally clear. If it is not, I would appreciate his guidance as to where I may be incorrect in my understanding of the situation.

—I, for one, would concede that Senator Short is in need of guidance. I am just not certain that I am the one who can provide it on this occasion. I have given him the best of my recollection of what happened at the time. It was quite some time ago-about nine months; and a lot can happen in nine months. I am not really prepared to expand upon that which I have already said.

— With respect, at that time Senator Richardson was the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, and was the relevant Minister to whom the interdepartmental committee set up as a result of the Cabinet decision of 23 January was to report. In fact, the committee was to report to him by 16 February. As we all know, four months slipped by and the committee did not report until 12 June. Given his normal grasp of his portfolios and that he was the key Minister involved in this at the time, I am surprised that he is not in a position to confirm that my understanding of this matter is correct. I find that unusual. Could he have another look at it?

—I am quite prepared to examine the papers and have another look at it, but I think I have been fairly forthcoming about my recollections. As I recall, there were two qualifications; the first was `up to' and the second was `if Melbourne gets it'. They were in the announcement, and at the same time the Government decided to examine the costings to make sure that they were valid. I suppose that, at least in part, it implies that the Government wanted to ensure that the Commonwealth could not be hemmed later into a position of offering more, and that was a proper exercise of protection of Commonwealth interest. I will review that and, if I think there is anything that I can add which will be helpful, I will certainly do so.

—I do not think there is much point in pursuing the matter further. I leave it, therefore, on the basis that, as I understand it, we are agreed-unless the Minister comes back to me subsequently-that that decision to provide up to $125m to the Victorian Government for the Olympic Games was conditional on, or subject to, only the question of whether Melbourne was granted the Games and that there was no other conditionality at all surrounding that decision. The Minister has said that he would like to have a look at it. If he does not come back to me on that matter I will assume that my understanding of it, as I have just outlined it, is correct.
—I will look at the matter and get back to Senator Short. We will try to make his understanding of it more perfect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to develop briefly one small point which emerged out of the Estimates inquiries. It was evident that the Department had decided, as a matter of policy, not to have a policy on the merit or otherwise of declaring performance enhancing drugs illegal. I take the opportunity to express the Opposition's unhappiness with that. The Opposition is basically of the view that, in view of the fact that the Australian Sports Drug Agency (ASDA) is part of that structure, the Department would have a capacity to provide valuable policy input on such a matter. Other `performance enhancing drugs' which are listed by the International Olympic Committee (IOC) are drugs which many people regard as social drugs-these being alcohol and marijuana. In the circumstances, does the Department have a view as to whether it is proper for those social drugs to be on the IOC list? I take on board what Mr Blunn said at the time, that they could be performance enhancing because using alcohol and marijuana, for example, could soothe the nerves when shooting.
—Marijuana could. With alcohol and caffeine there is an allowable limit.

—As Senator Crichton-Browne says, there is an allowable limit, but they can be used to calm the nerves. Obviously, as I mentioned at the time, tobacco may well calm the nerves and could be a performance enhancing drug too, but I do not think that it is on the list. Amendments from the Australian Democrats to a Bill relating to the incidental broadcasting on television of tobacco advertising are likely to come before the Senate. Mr Fairbrother noted during the Senate Estimates C hearing:

SPEECH.PARA: We have undertaken some preliminary position papers where we have looked at the level of sponsorship of sport, particularly by the tobacco industry. We have looked at the economic implications of this and are waiting for discussions with the Minister on this particular issue.

I know that Mr Fairbrother said at the time that it was on his work program over the next four or five months but, in view of the fact that this matter is to be debated fairly soon in this chamber, could the Senate be provided with those position papers looking at the level of sponsorship in order to assist the Senate in its discussions of the upcoming broadcasting Bill?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is still considering the matter to which Senator Baume refers. I think it is still to be the subject of Cabinet discussion, and I do not believe we can release any of the documents that might be associated with the Cabinet's discussion. I will add a few points to what Senator Baume has had to say. As far as alcohol and marijuana are concerned, the International Olympic Commission does not ban them; it lists them but does not proscribe them, which means that associations can ask for them to be tested for but they do not have to. It is a matter for the associations.
—There is a limit.
—There is a limit with alcohol.
—That is right. Marijuana is listed and not proscribed-that is what I have been advised. But the point I am making is that it is not banned.
—There are certain limits with alcohol and caffeine; ask Alex Watson.

—We are talking about both. Senator Crichton-Browne is correct in that respect-certain limits of alcohol are certainly banned; but marijuana is in a different category. That is the only point I am trying to make. When it comes to marijuana, it is up to the associations. In respect of the views the Department may have held on these matters, of course it is not the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (DASETT) that counts, but the Department of Community Services and Health. DASETT may have made its views known to the Department of Community Services and Health, but it is not DASETT's responsibility to have a policy on this matter. As Senator Baume will be well aware, we in this Government attempt to leave everybody's patch to him or her and not transgress. The people on my left are not aggressors; these are people who are quite happy to allow the Community Services and Health patch to remain its own.

—I would like to get this matter absolutely clear. Is the Australian Sports Drug Association (ASDA) required to make the tests for marijuana because marijuana is on the International Olympic Committee (IOC) list?
—No.

—Then it is up to each association. For example, when the rugby league in New South Wales asked ASDA to make those tests, did it just ask it to apply the IOC regimen, presumably on the basis that it considered marijuana to be a performance enhancing drug?
—No, in that case they knew it was the opposite. They were trying to get rid of a problem; they knew that the club was full of it.
—If it were a performance--
—Unen- hancing.

—Yes, it was a performance diminishing drug. That is really the point I am trying to get at. If the rugby league, for example, has asked ASDA to test for an item which in this context is a performance diminishing drug, is that in fact what ASDA is supposed to be all about?

—The testing body was complying with the request of the sport. In the case of rugby league, that sport asked that marijuana be included and so the Australian Sports Drug Agency (ASDA) tested for marijuana. The other drug which caused a furore in rugby league was, of course, cocaine, which is already on the list, so ASDA has to test for that anyway. But it does not test for marijuana in the sport unless asked. Of course, when it comes to a sport like rugby league-a professional sport-one can see why it would ask. If there is a widespread belief held by such people as Jack Gibson that marijuana depresses initiative, energy and verve, then professional sports paying big money to their players obviously have a concern, so they ask for it to be included.
—I thought ASDA was supposed to be about performance enhancing drugs.
—No, it is about drugs on the list, and that includes more than performance enhancing drugs. It has to do what its charter tells it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to move to another matter that emerged out of the Senate Estimates hearings, and that was the elite sports program. I do not want to go over all that ground again but simply say that the Government has taken the clear decision to concentrate on the seven sports with a view to enhancing Australia's performance internationally, particularly at the Olympic Games.

SPEECH.PARA: What emerged from discussions in the Senate Estimates hearings was that clearly this is a very high risk policy. If it does not pay off-in other words, if it does not result in lots of gold or other medals at the next Olympic Games-presumably there will be a sense of disappointment and this special funding may well be at risk. Senator Richardson in one of his responses to me said:
Of course, we are trying to back winners, but I do not think there is any shame in that . . . Given that it is this kind of movement on the part of a lot of ordinary Australians-
that is, a popular movement of concern about the bad economic position of some of Australia's leading sporting contenders-
that gives you the impetus to get the money, I think you are betraying that if you do not give at least part of that extra to those Olympic sports where Australia has a real chance.

My concern-and it is a concern that has been reinforced to me very strongly since the Senate Estimates Committee, as people have read the Estimates Hansard-is that, while it is recognised and accepted around the place that if there are sporting heroes who win things there is the prospect of attracting lots of youngsters into those sports, the concentration of funding on the seven or eight elite, depending on which way one looks at it-or the 17, if one looks at it in a different way, but particularly that seven-appears, at least in the view of many Australian sporting people, to be unfair to the non-Olympic elite sports. I use the word `elite' not in the Australian Institute of Sport concept, but in the way in which it is generally accepted.

Because of the dominance of the International Olympic Committee members, it appears, over the AIS, it is the concentration on Olympic sports that gives this indication of unfair treatment of many of the non-Olympic sports where there is exactly the same opportunity for hero worship and for following the excitement of someone who is an outstanding performer, recognising also that the Olympics take place once every four years and there are other heroes who might be more regularly supportable.

The Australian women's netball team-I think this point was made-has been world champion five, six or seven times within the last 10 years and has quite significant status, although there are probably not all that many countries playing that sport. Nonetheless, it is an international sport. Squash has had many Australian champions.

I am just concerned, and many other people in the sporting arena are concerned, about this concentration on the Olympics and the high risk nature of it. As I said, if we do not come up with the medals what is going to happen to the funding? I am particularly concerned when I look at what is happening in other nations, where the trend seems to be away from this kind of concentration on elite sports. I simply make the point that since the Senate Estimates hearings I have received a large volume of concern from other sports which feel they are being unfairly treated, although I take the Minister's point that all sports have received some additional funding. I acknowledge that, but there is no doubt, as the Minister has said repeatedly, there has been a `concentration' of the extra funding on those elite sports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have the Hansard before me but I have a fair idea of what I said at the time of the Estimates Committee hearings. One of the later points which was made by Senator Michael Baume is something upon which I placed great emphasis at the time; that is, that I was able to get a very big increase for funding in sport, which meant that all sports--
—You said there would be enough money for everybody, if I remember correctly.
—There has been. All sports funding went up.
—Have you seen the correspondence from the Aussie swimmers?
—I have seen a lot of correspondence from Australian swimmers thanking us for what we have done. That does not mean that every single--
—I have a couple of hundred pages here you could just run your eye across.
—I think we have a bigger file than Senator Crichton-Browne. He should not get into an `I'll show you mine if you'll show me yours' situation, because I do not think he will go too well on that one.
—Lets stick to files.
—I was only speaking about files, of course.
—Let us stick to Estimates.

—The fact that funding for every sport went up was the main point to make. It is also undeniable that the impetus for change, the impetus for that massive increase in the funding of sport, came from the Olympics; from Duncan Armstrong getting there on the dole; the harrowing tales of those women who had been in the Australian hockey team who had to struggle; Debbie Flintoff-King, and all the rest of them. Every one of those people who had done well had hard luck stories to tell.

SPEECH.PARA: We had to try to address those problems. I do not believe for a second that all the problems have been addressed. It is still the case that the private sector in this country does far less than it does in most of the comparable western European nations or in the United States of America. Given the economic conditions, it is probably unlikely that we are going to get a huge rise in that in the near future, so we are not going to have every problem addressed straight away. The massive increase in funding enabled us to give big increases to all sports, and particularly big increases to seven.

Having said that, it is obvious that a sport which is not in the seven is going to have a complaint and say, `Well, what about us?'. All I can say to those making that statement is that they got looked after as well. Everyone gained, but we have to recognise the purpose of the gain. Australia was looking at the Olympics, at the results achieved and at the conditions which were endured by athletes in achieving those results. Anyone who fails to acknowledge that that was the impetus for change-the impetus for more money-fails to grasp the obvious.

Of course, if the policy does not pay off at the first Olympic Games, some will complain. I would expect that. But I have no doubt that over the course of the next two to six years these policies will pay off. As I sat in Newcastle on Saturday and watched the Australian hockey team beat Great Britain six to one, it becomes obvious that we are a growing power. We are a growing power in the sport because we are spending more money. It is the case right across. We have improved performances already. Let us not knock it. Let us give it a chance. It will work. There is enough money there to make sure it does.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make one last brief point. I asked a question during the Estimates Committee about a body called Sports Marketing and Management. Mr Blunn replied at the time that there was a question on notice and that they would provide the information. I do not think that I have received the information-at least it is not in the mountain of material that I have. I could not find the information and I wondered if and when it might come.
—I think the answer to this question has been provided in the House of Representatives. If it has not been provided to Senator Baume, I apologise, but I think we can provide it tomorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister a couple of questions of which I belatedly gave some prior notice. I ask what funding Athletics Australia has received during the past 12 months. Perhaps I should read them all out now and the Minister can respond to them collectively.
—That might be a good idea.

—Has Mr Maurice Plant been the recipient of any direct or indirect funding from Athletics Australia on either a casual or other basis? Mr Maurice Plant is, as I understand it, the athletes' representative on the International Amateur Athletics Federation (IAAF) for the Grand Prix circuit. The Minister may be able to tell me what the position entails and what Mr Plant's relationship is with young Australian athletes visiting the international Grand Prix circuit.

SPEECH.PARA: At the time of Mr Plant's involvement in the urine substitution incident with Jane Flemming, he was banned by Athletics Australia-as I recall-from further occupying a team position. He holds a significant position with the IAAF, ironically, and I wonder whether the Australian Sports Commission has a view about that; and, if it does, what that view is. Has it conveyed what must be some very grave concerns it has, given the previous history of Mr Plant with the IAAF?

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate Senator Crichton-Browne's giving us some notice of these questions so that answers could be sought. In 1989-90 the sports development program paid $275,000 to Athletics Australia. In 1990-91 the sports development program paid $416,000 to Athletics Australia. That is an example of the increase which I was able to get. Of course, that does not include the assistance that is paid to individual athletes within Athletics Australia.
—That would go essentially to administration?

—Most of it would be going to administration and some would go to coaches. In response to the second part of Senator Crichton-Browne's question, Mr Plant has not received any money directly from Athletics Australia. However, in Melbourne in early 1990, he received payment from a sponsor when he promoted an international athletics event on behalf of Athletics Australia. I am informed that the position of an IAAF supervisor, which is what I understand he is, entails liaison between athletic nations, promoters and sponsors to formulate and establish a list of athletes for each event at each meeting on the European Grand Prix circuit. This is an arrangement between Mr Plant and the IAAF directly. In this regard he is responsible for nominating relevant Australian athletes to the relevant events and meets. He does not have any managerial role in relation to Australian athletes. The Australian Sports Commission has not expressed a view about the desirability of Mr Plant holding his present position in the IAAF.
—Was that Athletes Australia?

—No, I said that the Australian Sports Commission has not expressed a view on the desirability of Mr Plant holding his present position with the IAAF. I am informed that Athletics Australia has communicated with the IAAF regarding Mr Plant and has been advised that, from the IAAF's point of view, it does not intend to take any action with regard to him. We understand that Athletics Australia has written to the honourable senator advising him of the response from the IAAF. It is also understood that the honourable senator subsequently wrote directly to Mr John Holt, the IAAF General Secretary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that answer. I do not want to be sawing sawdust again and I hope that eventually we can put this thing to rest, but I ought to say that the letter I received from Athletics Australia was a letter of the most unsatisfactory type. It sums up the frustrations of those of us that have had a very difficult job in sorting our way through this business. I wrote to Athletics Australia and asked it what action it had taken regarding this incident. I got a letter back telling me that it was not going to tell me anything, and that was virtually the end of the matter. I am happy to table the letter. It did not repeat what had happened in respect of Mr Plant.

SPEECH.PARA: The truth of the matter, in respect of the poor, unfortunate athlete that has been so often mentioned in this matter, is that absolutely nothing was done. She was interviewed, she declined to answer the questions, and that was the end of it. I might say that was months and months after the matter was first raised. As a result of the athlete's response, the rules were changed so as to impose a suspension on future athletes who do not accommodate requests for information from Athletics Australia in such incidents. But for their trouble they did absolutely nothing, except continue writing to me to plead with me to drop the thing because, as far as they were concerned, it was causing problems. That is right; it really is causing problems. The problems were caused by the administration and the officials, not by the athlete, by me or by anybody else. It is sad that it was not dealt with in the way it should have been dealt with in the first place. And still it has not been dealt with in the way it should.

I should just say for the record that I would have thought it was unsatisfactory for Maurie Plant to have any association or connection, whatever devious route the funding that finds its way into his pocket travels, with any of the Australian athletes. I find it pretty unsatisfactory that an assistant team manager sought from a young lady a urine sample for the purpose of providing a mechanism for allowing what he judged to be a potentially positive test to prove negative, so as to cheat. When it was raised with him, Mr Plant admitted that much of his evidence which was necessary, but claimed he had committed a potential error of judgment. He had not committed an error, just a potential error, of judgment. It is almost like the bank robber who goes into a bank and aborts his hold-up. It is only a potential error of judgment because he did not get any money. Athletics Australia wrote to me and told me that, in its view, that was not an unreasonable description of his conduct. I find that a very unreasonable description of his conduct by it and I find it most unhelpful in the long term.

Could the Minister give an indication-or perhaps something more specific than an indication-of when we will see the passage of legislation setting up the Australian Sports Drug Agency as a statutory body? I recognise the difficulties with the legislation. No doubt the Government is waiting with bated breath for our report so that it can implement all the recommendations. With the packages of legislation presently before both Houses there is a difficulty with which I sympathise but I would have thought that there was a great deal of justification for us all wanting to see the legislation on the statute books and the agency in place, with its board appointed, by the end of this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the Bill to which Senator Crichton-Browne refers will be introduced on Thursday. I understand there has been a long time lag but the honourable senator could ask any Minister and he would find that it is very difficult to get legislation in. One really has to have desperation to the fore to get legislation through. We have managed to get this legislation listed for introduction on Thursday in the House of Representatives.

—Given my vague memory of the sessional order of the Senate, it provides that no Bill admitted after 16 November will be proceeded with. Does that mean that this Bill will not have a full passage this year?
—I think we meet the Senate's requirements by bringing it in on 15 November.
—Is it coming into the Senate on 15 November?
—It is going into the House of Representatives.
—I think the Sessional Orders provide-and if I am not correct even a nod from one of the Clerks would be helpful-that it has to come into the Senate.

—I will have an inquiry made as we speak. My understanding is that it was to be in the guillotine that I have heard a rumour about in the other House. If that is the case, it can be here on time. I will make an inquiry about that right now.
—The date is 16 November; this coming Friday. We are not sitting on Friday. The effective date is this Thursday.
—Mr Chairman, you are saying that the Bill must be introduced into the Senate on Thursday evening, otherwise it will be lost until 12 February next year.
—I think it will get here. Have faith.
—I thank the Minister. I understand that the Australian Sports Commission has appointed a Mr Ferguson--
—He is with us tonight.
—I congratulate Mr Ferguson on his appointment. I am sure it will all be up, up, up from now on. Will the Minister tell the chamber what the due processes for Mr Ferguson's appointment were?

—As I understand the situation, Mr Ferguson was interviewed by the Chairman, the Deputy Chairman and one other member of the board of the Australian Sports Commission. They were overwhelmed by his qualifications and capacity to do the job, and recommended accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not certain I understood all the processes, but I was prompted to ask that question after looking at the response from the Minister the last time we discussed this matter, when I asked about the appointment of Mr Robert de Castella as Executive Officer of the Australian Institute of Sport (AIS). I think that is his position. The Minister has provided me with an answer since then which states:
