SPEECH.PARA: Section 31 of the Australian Sports Commission Act empowers the Commission to employ the director of the Institute. The Commission established a subcommittee of the Chairman, Mr A.E. Harris, the Deputy Chairman, Mr J.D.Coates, and Mr H.J. Elliott to undertake initial interviews and to recommend to the full Commission candidates for the position of Executive Director of the ASC and the Director of the AIS. Mr de Castella was first interviewed on 15 January 1990 for the position of Executive Director. A second interview was held with Mr de Castella on 22 March, being for the position of Director of the AIS.
There is nothing exceptional about that. The answer continues:

Mr Coates made contact between 22 March and 25 March with all but one of the other commissioners, seeking their approval of Mr de Castella's appointment. All the commissioners were in agreement with the appointment; one commissioner unable to be contacted was subsequently contacted on 27 March and the full Commission ratified the appointment at its meeting on 3 May.

With the greatest respect, I think that is a sloppy way to make appointments. Not all the Commission knew of the appointment when the announcement was made. The full Commission never, to use vaguely bad English, met prior to the appointment of Mr de Castella being made; Mr Coates contacted the other commissioners between 22 March and 25 March-by telephone, I suspect-seeking their approval for Mr de Castella's appointment. I think the appointment was made on about 24 or 25 March, somewhere around there. It is a remarkable way to make an appointment.

There has been significant controversy at the AIS. There have been a great many problems, and it is imperative that the appropriate and proper person is appointed. I have no doubt that Mr de Castella is the right person. I am not questioning his qualifications. Certainly he has been at the coalface; certainly he understands athletics and has some empathy with athletes. However, after all the difficulties of the AIS and after the hiatus between appointments, to have a sub-committee of three people interview him twice and then, if I might say with respect, ring up with a fait accompli at the last hour, seeking the approval of other commissioners, is not the way that any board, committee or commission can properly and comprehensively consider the applicants. The subcommittee clearly was considering only one applicant; it was only considering Mr de Castella. We do not know what happened after that. To make the announcement, and for the Commission to ratify the appointment on 3 May, seems to me to be a remarkable way of doing business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The board acted the way it did because of the delays. I think every board member desired to have the situation resolved as quickly as possible. Having spoken to a number of board members about the situation, my distinct recollection is that all of them were delighted to have someone of the calibre of Mr de Castella in the field and were very happy indeed to see him appointed. It was not the case that Mr Harris, Mr Coates and Mr Elliott chose him in the face of opposition and used that choice to ram a fait accompli down the throat of an unwilling board. As I recall-and I did speak to quite a few of them-board members were very happy indeed to have Mr de Castella on board. I do not think any of them thought there was any alternative but to have a process which enabled a decision to be made quickly. It is not possible to have a board like this, which has representatives from every State, except Tasmania-we had better watch that one-meet and interview all applicants when necessary.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the board was more than happy to delegate the task to the three people concerned and was really delighted with the result with which it was presented. My recollection is that there was no hesitation in the board at all and they were very happy with the procedure. I know that Senator Crichton-Browne has had an opinion about Mr Harris going back over some time.

TALK.START.PARA: —From my reading of the correspondence, I think he has one of me.
—That is an inference one could draw. But having said that, this is not a time when Mr Harris can be criticised. He did act properly and he did act certainly with the approval of his board.

—I just want to record that I suppose the entrepreneurial spirit still flickers alive, but this `can do' sort of business is not the way that these commissions ought to run. I am quite certain Mr de Castella would not have taken a better job elsewhere in a fortnight or a month's time if it had taken that long for the matter to be considered carefully and properly. I think the sensible thing would have been to invite each member of the Australian Sports Commission to meet the applicant or at least receive a proper written report, which is the way that men and women normally do business in these circumstances, yet this thing was done with great haste and, might I say from my reading of the answer from Senator Richardson, without one of the commissioners even knowing about it. He just happened to be uncontactable and so the matter proceeded. He might have had some devastating information that made it quite wrong, but at least he was judged in his appointment on the Commission as somebody competent and capable of making a contribution to these sort of decisions. Yet he did not even have a voice. I do not want to labour it but I want to say that this sort of approach has not been helpful in solving the sort of problems that the Australian Institute of Sport and the Australian Sports Commission have had.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the executive of the West Australian Liberal Party meets and it is selecting candidates, if one member of the executive cannot turn up, Senator Crichton-Browne does not order that the whole thing be halted and they do not wait until the person absent turns up, unless of course he has not got the numbers at the time. In this case there was no numbers fight and as I understand it the great majority of the board were very happy with the appointment.

SPEECH.PARA: It is possible, I suppose, that one member might have had a devastating argument to undo the views of everybody else. I cannot think of it ever happening on that board or any other, but it is possible. But if one were to hold out that possibility then one wonders how any board would ever work. A board would never be able to make a decision unless everyone was present. I shudder to think how many Australian Sports Commission board meetings would have every single member present on every occasion. I think that is being a bit too restrictive and unnecessarily so. In this case, a very successful attempt was made to get hold of the great majority of the board and they approved the appointment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not suggesting that they all had to be there and cast their vote. What I was suggesting was they should have at least been invited to a meeting so as to make a judgment themselves whether there was sufficient merit for them to bother to attend or not. But one poor soul did not even know that the events were taking place. That is all I am suggesting and the rest of them received advice virtually the day the man was being appointed. I am certain that Senator Richardson would be distressed if a Cabinet meeting was held and he was not invited.
—Whether I am distressed at the prospect is not the argument. The decision on the south-east forests was taken while I was in Greece.
—That was your choice though.

—Heaven perish the thought. I had rather hoped it would not be taken until I got back, but these things happen and one learns to live with it. I am not sure all the trees are going to live with it but I had to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I refer to the Government's response to the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts. I do not want to get off the substance of what we are dealing with, but I do want to refer to the response to the extent that it goes to the heart, in some respects, of the funding of the Australian Drug Sports Agency and the Australian Sports Commission. There was a recommendation relating to an appeals mechanism and a proposed tribunal. The Government response was:

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of hearing and assessing evidence the Committee clearly formed the view that an expanded Tribunal was necessary and should have an investigatory as well as appeals functions. There is, of course, a conflict in one body having both an appeals and an investigatory role, and this was taken into consideration in forming the Government's position on this matter.
We at one stage talked about having an authority which had powers not dissimilar from those of the Senate committee to ensure that it can collect evidence, protect witnesses and inform the public.

Was the Government mindful that we were not simply looking for a mechanism that arbitrated, but rather a body that was capable of collecting information itself in a way that is not necessarily available to the Australian Sports Commission or to any of the sports bodies? In fact, we were proposing something more substantial than that so that there was somewhere for athletes to park their complaints?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) was quite aware of those concerns when making the recommendations for the decision, and she came down another way. It is probably not the first time that she has disagreed with Senator Crichton-Browne, nor will it probably be the last.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not be the first time she is wrong nor the last. Can I take a moment to explain something to the Minister and ask for his response to the recommendation we made? I have to say that perhaps the Government's view is that various sporting bodies and the Australian Sports Commission are the appropriate people to look at complaints from athletes who might want to convey information relating to the use of bad substances by other athletes, or their own harassment, their own intimidation, their own pressures and their own duress by the Maurie Plants of this world but they might want to have somewhere to go to explain the problems they have got and they are very real problems.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not read it myself, but I understand that when Darren Clark retired recently he said he was sick of being beaten by cheats. Darren Clark is not a whinger nor a whiner. He is an excellent athlete who was very competitive and had his wins and had his losses, all with good grace. I find it very sad when people like that retire from their chosen sport because they cannot win because of the cheats.

I find it very sad when we have young girls coming before our Committee, as they did, and telling us that they were so depressed when, for example, they had to compete with East European athletes. They were built like tanks, had deep voices and could have sung Paint your Wagon lower than Lee Marvin and had a 5 o'clock shadow that would put most of the rock stars to shame. Yet our girls knew from the outset, when they lined up against these competitors, that they were running against a cheat that probably had a second or half a second on them before they started. They would train their hearts out for months and months and perhaps years, only to find that by somebody else taking a performance enhancing drug it was all pretty much in vain.

We were seeking a mechanism to give relief to those sorts of people. It is not easy for them to find the mechanism that is necessary. I was distressed, for instance, with the sort of evidence that the Committee received. It is no good going to sports officials because they have a vested interest. I do not say that in an unkind way, but they are bound to be subjective. Half of them are ex-coaches or ex-athletes; they have got an interest in one athlete or another. Without labouring the point, Jane Flemming could hardly go to Maurie Plant and say, `Listen, the athlete next to me is cheating. What do I do about it?'. She is away from home, away from her parents, away from her coach. She has to go to somebody, so she goes to the assistant team manager. Instead of him saying, `I understand, I empathise, I will keep your confidence. This is what we will do about it', he says `By the way, while you are here will you wee in my bottle?'. Where do these athletes go to where they can be certain that they will not be intimidated?

I have had one senior sports official tell me that I am causing some pain because I have raised Maurie Plant's name a few times-do I not know that he decides which athletes from Australia get on to the grand prix circuit, and that is where all the big bucks are? He can make or break these kids. That is true of these other major promoters overseas. Somebody creates the entree. Therefore, these kids cannot afford to squeak.

We took evidence from witnesses who were terrified to tell us about some of those operators-the operators who say, `Yes, come and compete on our circuit, and we will guarantee that you will not be tested positive'. These kids are not going to stand up and tell us that, are they? They will be one darned athlete who will never get another crack at it. It is the make or break of these kids. Who do they tell? They cannot go to the Australian Sports Commission or anywhere else. The Australian Sports Commission does not have the powers. It will pull in a lawyer who will find out that there is no prima facie case. But I shall come to that in a moment. Who do these kids trust? They are terrified of offending anybody because their futures rest on it.

We had two witnesses before us who gave me some heartburn. One was an Australian athlete, a top athlete-and I mean `top athlete'. That particular athlete was to appear before us in camera. On the night before, that athlete got a phone call from a senior sports official, gravely concerned that that athlete was to give us evidence about the use by another Australian athlete of illegal performance enhancing drugs. When the athlete came before us and was sworn in, there was no way in the world that that athlete was going to tell us in camera, out of camera or anywhere else, because that elite athlete was terrified of the ramifications. The athlete told us afterwards the whole story and explained why she could not give us the evidence in camera or anywhere else; she just could not talk about it. I found that absolutely tragic, but that is the reality of where we are at.

One of our witnesses was in Queensland when she was contacted by a person and was intimidated against giving us evidence. That particular person has been mentioned unfavourably in the report, and I know that there are those in this chamber now who think that I have been unkind to that particular person and harsh on another matter. But I would remind the Committee that Al Capone did not go to gaol for anything else except taxation fraud. There is more than one way to skin a cat. Do honourable senators think that the athlete would come before us and tell us that Mr X had got her at a sports meeting and told her how unwise it was to give evidence because of the implications and ramifications for her future? Of course not. So where do they go?

I am not suggesting that that problem is endemic in Australia, but there has to be an independent body. It is pretty tough. I had the audacity to raise the matter of the Australian Olympic Federation (AOF) giving, first of all, six weeks' notice-and then I discovered that it was six months' notice-to the Australian athletes going off to Seoul of its drug testing timetable. Even the dumbest of athletes would not get tested with that notice, all being equal. I was not suggesting anything sinister or improper. I was making the point that, because of the mechanism in place at the time, we are exposing ourselves to the allegation that we are assisting the cheats. One could reasonably draw the conclusion that we are more concerned to make sure that our athletes were clean when they went than we were to make sure that they were not cheats.

What did I get for my efforts? Mr Kevan Gosper, the President of the AOF, put out a press statement pouring one over me. I understand that he is now the Vice-President of the OIC-he has been promoted. Instead of Mr Gosper saying, `Listen, that was never intended and I am sure you will understand that, but that is the effect of what we did. We have learnt from our mistake. We now recognise with hindsight that it was not wise and we had not thought that that would be the effect. We will not let it happen again', he was so defensive and aggressive that he put out a press statement attacking somebody who was just raising a matter-and I might tell the Committee that as a result of its being raised it will not happen again. How would honourable senators like to be young athletes going along and raising some of the problems that these athletes can have?

I wish that it were just restricted to a few. We received evidence from one rather brave soul who wrote to us and told us about problems with boxing. Mr Zammataro wrote and told us about problems with drugs in boxing and he got a letter from Mr Arthur Tunstall for his trouble-a very angry Mr Tunstall. Correct me if I am wrong, but Mr Tunstall was the Secretary of the Commonwealth Games Association and also the Secretary-General of the Amateur Boxing Union of Australia Inc. Of the sporting bodies we wrote to who were invited to make submissions to our Committee outlining any problems they might have with drugs in their sport or any potential problems they might have, the only person to write back to us said that he had no intention of giving us a submission because they had no problems.

At this very time last year I asked a question of Senator Richardson. It was not a flier or a blind shot. I asked Senator Richardson whether boxing was a sport with potential for drug abuse, and he answered me yes. Of course it is, because it is a weight sport so there are diuretics. It is a sport requiring power so there are anabolic steroids. It is a sport that requires quick reflexes so there are all sorts of other implications. Yet Mr Tunstall would not appear before us. But poor old Mr Zammataro wrote to us and told us about some problems, and he got a nasty letter from Mr Tunstall for his trouble. When he did not respond to the first letter, he got another one. I am happy to table this correspondence, if it be the Committee's wish.

The Committee was then required as a result of Mr Zammataro writing to us and pleading protection-which is the point I am making-to write to Mr Tunstall to advise him that there was a small problem with intimidating witnesses. It brings a penalty of six months in gaol or a fine of $5,000, or $25,000 for a non-person. Mr Tunstall was pretty impressed with the correspondence. He wrote back and told us that we were intimidating him. It is pretty classy stuff. It can bring a smile to one's lips and is a good yarn to tell over a beer, but the tragedy is that it is an everyday event in sport in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—I am sorry; it is. For everybody who stands up, speaks up and is counted, there is somebody there to sink the slipper into him. The problem is that we are not prepared to address that matter. I seek leave to table the correspondence if the Minister has no objection. I am sorry that I did not show him before.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason we were looking for a body quite removed from the Australian Sports Commission was that we wanted a body which was independent and divorced and which in no way could be tainted with subjectivity. I do not mean that in the classic sense, but simply because of its connection with the various athletes. The Australian Sports Commission is not an appropriate body because of its connections. If I were to make any new appointments on the board of the Australian Sports Commission, I would be tempted to put on some of these kids who have had to compete against other athletes. Yet we find that the Government chooses to ignore the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: We are looking for a mechanism which provides an opportunity for athletes to come along and clear their problems-in camera if necessary-in some way in which they can feel safe and comfortable. That is not presently available to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order or a point of clarification.
—You are a marathon runner, you should not have to puff.
—I have just run a marathon. I am afraid I have only partly listened to what Senator Crichton-Browne has been talking about. I understand that he sought leave to table documents.
—Leave was sought, and leave was granted by the Committee.

—Quite so. I would like to be clear about the status of the documents tabled. I understand that they are letters of private correspondence to the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. Notwithstanding that leave has been granted, I raise a point of order about the status of that correspondence and seek your guidance, Mr Temporary Chairman.
—I hear Senator Crowley's question about the status of the letters. The Committee considered the request for leave, leave was granted, and the letters are tabled.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, on the point of order, I could have saved Senator Crowley losing her breath. The documents have been published. In my normal, inimitable, impeccable way, I checked with the Secretary of the Committee before I came into the chamber.
—I hear Senator Crichton-Browne's statement. There is no point of order on the question that Senator Crowley raises, but she is free to speak as a member of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note Senator Crichton-Browne's comments that he has sought guidance from the Secretary. I understand that the status of these letters may be in some doubt. Discussion is still proceeding in the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts about the status of correspondence of this sort. We have, in effect, two conflicting decisions taken by the Committee. One is that correspondence entered into with regard to the drugs in sport inquiry should be presumed to be understood as evidence, and the other is the subsequent ruling that evidence before that inquiry could properly be made public.

SPEECH.PARA: One letter, which was received very close to the decision to complete the reference, is strictly no longer part of that inquiry. Quite clearly, it is a piece of correspondence to the Committee and not to the inquiry. It was certainly received subsequent to the inquiry. One would have to say that the standing of that letter is in doubt.

I do not wish to refer to the matters of substance talked about by Senator Crichton-Browne. I think it is perfectly reasonable and proper for him to raise issues of concern about those matters, but when he seeks permission to table documents, even when permission is given, it may be that the people giving permission for that leave are not fully cognisant of the facts about the correspondence. I simply say on the record that it is my understanding that at least one of those documents is a private piece of correspondence to the Committee. I think the precedent established here is a matter of some grave concern. I would just like that placed on the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not the slightest idea what Senator Crowley is talking about. I am not aware of any dispute about the status of any correspondence to the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. There has been a dispute in the mind of Senator Crowley about the status of certain in camera evidence, but that is a debate she is having with herself, not with me, the Clerk of the Senate, or the rest of the Committee other than one or two senators who I do not think are up to date.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know what Senator Crowley is on about. Quite frankly, I would have read the correspondence if I thought it was such a hot issue for Senator Crowley. She can untable the stuff, for all I care; it is no big deal to me. As for some debate going on in the Committee, perhaps I am a bit like the Australian Sports Commissioner-I did not get a notice. I do not have the slightest idea about the dispute that is going on about the correspondence.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, we have advice from the Clerk about the status of this correspondence. The letter from the Clerk has been received by the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts but has not yet been discussed by the Committee. I would have thought that as Senator Crichton-Browne sought that advice from the Clerk he would have a fairly good idea of what we are talking about.

—I would like to know where these letters have been published or reported. To my understanding these are recent letters to the Committee after all the reports have been tabled and are public documents only inasmuch as they are documents that are available to the Committee. I was not aware of them being public documents in any other sense.

—I hear what you say. The Chair is not in a position to answer any such questions that are the business of a standing committee of the Senate. Statements have been made by one senator in the course of considering the report of Estimates Committee C. In the honourable senator's speech some papers were tabled. They are tabled and I have already responded to the point of order. In fact, I now remind the Committee that the question before us is that the report of Estimates Committee C be adopted. We are in the midst of considering matters arising from the report of Estimates Committee C that are related to the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories.

—I was happy to grant leave to have these documents tabled. I wonder what will happen if we are, in fact, breaking some sort of rule. I have asked the Clerk for advice on this matter. I am told that there is a resolution of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts which covers the correspondence and says that it can be published; at least that is what the Clerk believes. I am at a loss to know what occurred in the Committee. I would not have a clue, but I make the point that it would obviously be a very difficult situation if correspondence which was considered by the Committee to be in camera and therefore not available for publication was published. I think we would be in strife. If we have given the wrong decision, we ought to revoke it. We need clarification as to the status of the correspondence. That is what I do not know. I am sure that Senator Crichton-Browne believes that he is quite in order, so I am not having a shot at him over it. I would just like to know what the status is. If the Clerk could inform the Committee, then we will all be the better for our knowledge.

—I have already said, with advice, that as Chairman of this Committee I am not in a position to make any judgment about the standing of or decisions on correspondence before a standing committee of the Senate. We have heard speeches from Senator Crowley and Senator Crichton-Browne. I do not wish to make any further statement, and I say this with advice.

—I thank you, Mr Temporary Chairman, for your comments. This is a matter which quite clearly our Committee will have to pursue. I note the Minister's comments. I also have a concern, as he has, that if in fact this Senate actually drifts into changes of practice and longstanding precedent, it not only may be a matter that is of grave concern for our Senate Standing Committee, let alone other committees, but may be something that the full Senate might have to give further attention to at some time so that there will be no dispute or doubt about the status of such correspondence or other matters at a future time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to Senator Crichton-Browne's contribution. I cannot actually remember all the things he said-it seems so long ago. He began with a reference to the decision by Darren Clark to quit athletics and suggested that this was because he was tired of competing against cheats. That is certainly what Darren Clark said and is at least, in part, perhaps one of the reasons. But I do not think we can dismiss the lure of Balmain dollars having some effect on his decision.
—That is a bit uncharitable, Senator.

—It is not being uncharitable-half his luck. I am one who in the past has always wished Darren Clark great success. I do not think I can do that in the future if he is playing for Balmain. But I am convinced that the offer that Alan Jones made him must have had some effect on the decision.

SPEECH.PARA: In so far as the general position of drugs in sport is concerned, though, there has been a tremendous change in the culture in the last few years. I have said in this chamber before in response to a question, I think, from Senator Crichton-Browne, that even if one went back to 1986 or 1987 and looked at the attitudes taken by athletes and officials here in Australia, let alone anywhere else in the world, we would find that their attitude to the use of drugs in sport would be radically different now.

We now have a situation where all elite athletes in this country know that they are going to be tested. But none of them knows when. Whatever they knew two years ago about the schedules of tests and all the rest of it, now none of them knows when Haynes will descend upon them. That is going to have a tremendous effect in moderating their behaviour.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is providing you have a mechanism so that whenever they disappear in the bush there is a penalty.

—No, it certainly does not. As the honourable senator would be well aware, the Australian Sports Drug Agency has developed a set of procedures which make the tampering with or the destruction of evidence in regard to these drug tests virtually impossible. I am a great believer in that. I do, however, have bad news for Senator CrichtonBrowne and, indeed, for the Committee. I am told that in the last couple of days, in an event of which I was completely unaware--
—I thought you were going to say in an event you were competing in.

—No, there are not too many of those. Senator Ray, my very close colleague, has come up with an agreement with, I think, the honourable senator's Party, to drop the Sports Drug Agency Bill from the list for this year and it will come back in February.
—With our approval?

—As I understand it. I am not trying to shed blame. But that is the advice I have just received. If I am doing the Opposition an injustice, I will apologise. But, as I understand it, there is some agreement that it is off.
—If you do your best to get it back on, so will I.
—The honourable senator may have more influence than I do but I will certainly be trying. I was under the impression that it was on. But I will do what I can.

SPEECH.PARA: In any event, I am of the view that the change in culture which we have brought about in the last few years means that what athletes may have felt about coming forward a few years ago will not be relevant in future. I believe that every single sport is desperate to prove that it is not involved in drugs. Every sport will be encouraging athletes to come forward if they even hear of anything. Of course, they would be running a risk that if they did not and the Sports Drug Agency or the Australian Sports Commission received a report, their funding would be in doubt. So all athletes in every sport now have on them an imperative that they did not have before to come forward. With that change in culture, they will come forward. I do not now believe that athletes are being intimidated into silence.

I am not at all surprised by the tenor of correspondence between the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts and Arthur Tunstall, nor his response. I have known Arthur for quite some time. I consider Arthur Tunstall to be a very fine Australian. I am absolutely certain that he has not had, nor ever will have, any involvement in drugs. Arthur is the kind of person who decries that behaviour with vigour. In fact, Arthur does most things with vigour and that includes the writing of letters.

I can assure the Committee that he is a very difficult person to intimidate. I think Arthur, like many others, had concerns about the Committee. This does not mean that those concerns were right; it does not mean that there was an attempt to intimidate. But obviously many sports had concerns about the way the Committee proceeded. I think they had been thrust into the parliamentary arena for the first time and did not understand procedures. I think that created a fair bit of confusion and fear. Perhaps some of them overreacted.

I have not read the correspondence with Mr Tunstall. Maybe he did and maybe he did not. But I do know that many sports were concerned and some of them did not understand what Senate procedures were like. They had views that the Committee had overstepped the mark when in fact all the Committee was doing was observing the Standing Orders of the Senate. I think whenever there is confusion and fear we can sometimes get overreactions and we all regret them.

Boxing is one sport that will not tolerate even a whiff of drugs. I am not aware of any evidence that drugs have ever been used in boxing. I cannot recall anybody testing positive or any suggestion of drugs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think they tested them until very recently.

—No, but they are in it now. I just do not believe that we have had any suggestion of boxers being involved. I think it is a sport that is clean and drug free. At least, so far as I am aware, this is the case.

SPEECH.PARA: While I think the situations of which the honourable senator spoke existed even a few years ago, they do not exist now. I do not believe that people now have a fear of coming forward and I believe that all sports will encourage them to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling Senator Michael Baume, I remind the Committee of the Whole that we are considering the report of Estimates Committee C. We are dealing with those remaining matters that require information from the Minister or which honourable senators wish to address directly relating to the adoption of the report or of any amendments to it by the Committee of the Whole. I call Senator Michael Baume.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My comments will be very brief. I wish to ask a question which relates to the Australian Sports Drug Agency (ASDA). In view of the Minister's comment that perhaps the legislation may be dropped for this year, I want to express my concern that it is one of 66 Bills which at present are being attempted to be bulldozed through this place, having been bulldozed through the other chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very important Bill. It seems to me that exactly the wrong message will be conveyed to some people in the sporting community if this Parliament considers this Bill not important enough to be passed before Christmas. I think that message is totally inappropriate. I would like the Minister, in these circumstances, to outline to the Committee why this Bill was not prepared and was not ready to come before this chamber before now. As I understand it, the outline of what was required of the Bill has been known for months and months. Drug testing has been proceeding under the ASDA for some time.

If this Bill does not go through, the Government should not try to fit that on the Opposition. That is what really worried me about Senator Richardson's remarks. I know that he was not really trying to fit us. He was saying that he has heard there are problems. We are not in charge of the legislation before this chamber. I want to say with some vigour that we have not delayed the process of legislation in this place.

Today we heard some incredible comments that somehow the procedures of the Estimates Committees had delayed the process of legislation. That is bunkum. The Estimates Committees sit on different days from those on which the Senate sits to deal with legislation. The Minister should not try to fit us with the incompetence and failure of the Government to come up with appropriate volumes of legislation at appropriate times of the year. The House of Representatives has only on one occasion sat on fewer days than it has this year. We are being inundated with legislation at the end of the year. It is intolerable. If you give a message, Minister--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask senators not to address other senators but to address the Chair.

—If the Minister is to be party to sending a message to Australian sporting communities that the Parliament does not think highly enough of this matter to pass this legislation before Christmas, I tell the Minister that the Opposition dissociates itself entirely from that position. We wish the Government could get its act together and have a decent legislative program so that important measures such as the ASDA legislation could be dealt with properly and expeditiously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first point to make is that whether the legislation goes through the Senate this year will have no effect on the sports or the athletes. The reality is that testing goes on whether or not the legislation is passed. Any athletes caught will be disciplined whether or not the legislation goes through and funding for the sports will be taken away whether or not the legislation goes through. Obviously, like Senator Baume, I want to see this given legislative force. Whether or not the legislation has been passed will have no practical effect on the use of drugs in sport, which we have been stamping out for the past 12 months without this legislation. I think we can manage for another four. To suggest that there is some incompetence involved here is nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the rest of Senator Baume's contribution, I have been, as is always the case, a model of tolerance and patience this evening, but they are running out. The disgraceful abuse of Senate procedures by a range of senators, including Senator Baume, when it comes to Estimates Committees is on record in this chamber. I have spoken about it before. When you hold up Estimates Committees you think that it is not a problem because it is a day that is not a Senate sitting day. You and some of your colleagues have never understood that the tying up of departments for hours, days and months in chasing every rat hole has come up with nothing. For all the questions you have asked, you have not got one headline, let alone one line in any paper. Why? Because the way you use the Estimates committees--

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! I ask the Minister, as I asked Senator Baume, to address the Chair and not to address other senators.
—I apologise, Mr Temporary Chairman. It is late.
—Is that the criteria of success? What a criteria. He equates success with headlines. How pathetic.

—Were Senator Baume ever to be judged, he would be a total failure. I am appalled at the way in which we have this abuse of Estimates committees and the abuse of departments' time and resources. I have heard honourable senators in this place even this evening complain about $848 for a consultant's letter prepared for the Department of Social Security, while at the same time the Department spends hundreds of thousands of dollars chasing up stupid questions at Estimates committees. Why? Because Estimates committees are no longer used for their purpose but are used for briefings of incompetent shadow Ministers who are not across their portfolios. Tonight is another classic example of the same process being repeated. It has nought to do with the Estimates and everything to do with the briefing of incompetent clowns who ought to get other jobs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might inject a touch of non-controversial comment into this debate. I understand what the Minister was saying about the Arthur Tunstalls of this world coming before a committee- actually he did not, but for those who did--
—I was making a general point.

—The Minister is quite right. Sports officials are not used to the procedures and the implications for not complying with the procedures, and they were not aware of the cohesive powers of the Committee. I suspect that in some respects it was intimidating. Notwithstanding that everyone tried to be relaxed about it, it is not an issue about which one can stay thoroughly relaxed.

SPEECH.PARA: I say with sincerity that the problem with some sports officials in Australia is that they have been receiving taxpayers' money for so long and they imagine that they get it by right. They take offence at having to be accountable and scrutinised by those who ultimately have to pass the legislation that makes the funding possible. I had to make the point very frankly today about Athletics Australia when it wrote me a bland letter. I said, `I regret having to do it, but I will pursue this matter, the questions and the information until I am satisfied that I have the answers relevant to the funding'. I did not say that in an aggressive way. One gets the clear impression that the officials see themselves, their sporting associations and their sporting bodies as having the money by right and get on with the job without understanding that there has to be a scrutiny somewhere. Perhaps they are not used to being scrutinised except by an auditor's report to say that the money has been spent where they say it is being spent.

It is important that there are those who can make valued judgments as to whether the money is being spent on elite sport properly, whether it should be spent at the other end of the sporting spectrum, or where it should be spent. That is half the problem. If we have done nothing else-I suspect that we have failed from my observation-we have focused the sporting officials on the realisation that they are accountable to the Parliament at the end of the day for their conduct, for their management, for their guidance and for the expenditure of the funding.

There may not have been a problem with drugs in boxing. I do not know whether there has been. I would be very surprised if boxing was outside the mainstream average of drug use in those sports which are likely to be enhanced by the use of these performance enhancing drugs. It is similar to the mother-perhaps more the father-saying that every daughter is a virgin when she marries. There is just an incapacity to imagine that that particular sport is tainted by drugs. I suspect that I am not incorrect when I say that every single sports person who came before us came to persuade us-and, I suspect in his or her own mind was persuaded-that that sport was the one sport that did not have a drug problem, whether it was the rowers, the basketballers, the rugby players or the Australian league footballers.

The Australian rules people gave very good evidence. The Australian rules sporting organisations have been very effective as have the Rugby people. They told us all the reasons why drugs did not fit their sport. Of course they do. Of course Australian football players have used them. The rugby people could not imagine that was a problem for them. I give them absolute marks. As I have said before in this chamber, I have always been persuaded to the view since I first took some interest in this matter-which I might tell honourable senators is about to terminate and which I am sure Senator Richardson will be pleased to know-that the professional sporting officials have been quicker to grasp the problem, to deal with it and not to justify it.

Senator Baume raised the question of use of marijuana. I can think of no better example than the South Sydney Rugby Leagues Club Ltd. Clearly those officials did not just guess there might be a marijuana problem. I am certain they must have known that the club had a problem among its players. They wanted it fixed. They probably realised that the athletes were playing below their performance. They understood that the players were bad role models for their followers. They understood that one day the news would get out. They grasped the nettle. They did not hide it. They did not have private counselling. They got it out on the table. All those fellows were found for their sins.

I am certain that they are now better athletes and that it is a better club, and those officials ought to take the credit. If that was the attitude of all sports, sport in Australia would be better. But without exception they said to us, `There is not a problem with our sport and, if we were able to give an example of an athlete, it would be the only one'. The so-called amateur sports in particular have been very slow to accept that there is a serious problem and that Australia is in the mainstream in terms of the amount of drug abuse.

I have been disappointed. That is why I got angry, perhaps unfairly, with the Harrises of this world and the others who, instead of getting on with it, want to argue with me about it. I pay some credit to the Government for its recent response. There is much of it that I do not agree with, but that does not make it wrong. The tone in which it is written is much more acknowledging, accepting and seeking to solve the problems than this hairy chested, confrontationist, rude and bombastic correspondence, which everybody finds offensive and which I respond to. It is a big improvement.

While I am on my feet, I ask the Minister what the status of weightlifting in Australia is. It is referred to briefly. I think a subcommittee has been set up. Weightlifting is one of the sadnesses of the use and abuse of drugs in sport in Australia. The Coffa brothers were proud to tell us that there had never been a positive. But if one reads this report, one sees correspondence to us from Mr Bruce Walsh, the Executive Director of the Australian Weightlifting Federation Inc., in which he sets out categorically, in writing, one clear case of a cover-up in respect of Nick Voukelatos in the 1984 Olympics. We then had the Satry Ma case. There were a number of other cases. Because they had not been dealt with honestly, properly and frankly, it was reported that there had not been a positive. They said that there had never been a positive. They were pretty keen to attack us. That is not unnatural-it is unreasonable but not unnatural. I hope that something is now being done about that.

If I had my way, I would not have weightlifting as an Olympic sport and I would not fund powerlifting. Until such time as we have a proper profile in place, the cheats in those sorts of sports will never be stopped. There has been no serious attempt by the Weightlifting Federation to come to grips with the problem. I hope that this part of our report, which is frank and factual, is not just pushed out the door and that the Australian Sports Commission looks at it in a positive and constructive way, because-and I say this with the greatest of respect-this matter will not be cleaned up by the present officials of the Australian Weightlifting Federation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crichton-Browne has again raised a number of points. The only part of what Senator Crichton-Browne was saying with which I disagreed was the beginning of his speech. Many of the officials about whom he is speaking have not really been earning large lumps of money from the Australian Sports Commission or from their sport. Many, if not most of them, have of course worked voluntarily.
—But you must understand that I was not talking about funding for themselves.

—No, but the point that many of these officials would be trying to make is, `I have worked for 30 years in a voluntary capacity. I give up all my time for this sport. I have broken my back for it, et cetera, yet here they are picking on me'. I understood that feeling. Many of them complained to me. Whenever I got that sort of complaint I explained to them why the Committee had to proceed. I explained to them that it was not breaking any standing orders and that, if they had matters of real gravity, they could be presented in camera. I attempted to explain to as many officials as I possibly could the way that the Committee would proceed and the correctness of it. But many of them undoubtedly had that feeling. I think that that will now change, because over the next few years we will be putting more money into administration, so more administrators will be on the payroll full time.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with a further point that Senator Crichton-Browne made. When I was the Minister I insisted that, as a condition of that extra funding, there be auditing of the sports concerned. We had to make sure that that money was being spent properly. As Senator Crichton-Browne would be aware, a number of sports have not performed satisfactorily in terms of their administration in the last few years. We had considerable concerns about their administrative performance. Accordingly, at the time of the big announcement on the increase in sports funding, we said that we would be having performance audits of the administration of these sports to make sure that they were performing properly. We will continue to do that.

One of the sports with which Senator Crichton-Browne has been having a celebrated disagreement was one where perhaps administration was not all that it should have been in the past. Having said that, I cannot be too critical of what happened four years ago. A new team is trying hard. They cannot really undo what happened four years ago, even if they wanted to. I appeal to Senator Crichton-Browne to be relaxed about that. The new people are better than their predecessors and are trying very hard.

Senator Crichton-Browne also talked about weightlifting. There is one aspect of this that I will check overnight. I will make sure that we can inform Senator Crichton-Browne exactly. Weightlifting had been offered funding on the basis that it accepted the doping policy. I think it has accepted it, but I am not certain that we have the correspondence yet. I will have that checked before we resume at 10 o'clock in the morning so that we can let Senator Crichton-Browne know. I agree that question marks have hung over the sport in the past. Certainly, the late withdrawal of competitors on a number of occasions was open to question. I do not have any evidence about it but, like Senator Crichton-Browne and many others, I have heard stories.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can give you evidence.

—I do not have any evidence. In any event, I am not the Minister now, so if Senator CrichtonBrowne has evidence, he should give it to somebody else. I believe that under our new arrangements we will be able to detect athletes who have been doing the wrong thing. I think that that will help us eliminate it from the sport.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that weightlifting will remain in the Olympics in the foreseeable future, even though there were a few embarrassments in that sport in the last Olympics, particularly with a Bulgarian. But it will still be on the list. Therefore, there is every reason for Australia to still be in it. Mind you, we will have to be absolutely satisfied about the running of the sport in Australia now. My understanding is that it is not yet back in the Australian Institute of Sport programs. We are still conducting an examination to determine whether it should be brought back. Honourable senators will recall that we put it in the sin-bin some time back. I am not yet certain of how long we put it in the sin-bin for, but I think there will be a response fairly soon. I hope that we can give Senator Crichton-Browne a response by the end of the year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very sympathetic to those long-suffering, hard-working voluntary sports officials whose only reward is to wear a blazer or get a buzz from success, or perhaps ultimately see some rewards for their endeavours by the achievements of the athletes with whom they are associated. Of course, that begs the question, which is perhaps a debate for another time-whether we have so socialised sport in Australia that we have crossed the Rubicon in that sporting officials now have to get used to the idea that if they are going to take government money there are new rules. There is a new system and there is a new responsibility. The good old days of rattling the tin and having a chook raffle in the local pub to give an athlete a new pair of shoes or to send an athlete to compete in Sydney are over-and thank goodness for that in some respects.

SPEECH.PARA: It really begs the question as to whether the officials have come to grips with the fact that they are now in a different era with a different form of funding which requires a great deal more accountability than the money from the chook raffle did. No doubt they will be offended when Crichton-Browne has the impertinence to ask them what they have done with the money. That is only natural; I understand that. I hope that they are all fast track learners so that they can understand why the questions are being asked. That will make them better and more accountable officials.

I have one other matter before me. That is the difficulty I was talking about earlier. I received privately some complaints from people and then I received an anonymous letter, which I will not table because it names somebody who is alleged to have acted in what I judge to be an improper way. Following a discussion which we had at the last Estimates Committee C hearing when we discussed the matter of the Australian Olympic Federation (AOF) distributing funding for Olympic sports, I expressed to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) my grave concern that this organisation, in a sort of incestuous way, had the capacity to pull the strings and run the show. I thought it was an abrogation of responsibility that the Government, through the Australian Sports Commission or whatever, ought to be funding Olympic sports in the same way as all other sports.

That begs the question: should the Confederation of Australian Sport, for instance, be allocating funding for non-Olympic sports? I do not want to get into a philosophical discussion now about the virtue of the level of funding for Olympic sports or the selection of the big seven and the justification for and the merits of that and the relationship between those in the AOF and the sports that get the money. It makes interesting reading and one can wonder whether the money has been given in a thoroughly objective way and whether the measures and tests used for the allocation are objective and fair. One will always have complaints that they are not from those who do not receive it and accolades from those who do receive it. The letter I received stated:

Are you aware, that on May 19, at the AOF annual general meeting, a number of olympic sports, including two of the super seven were told . . . that if they continued their membership of the Confederation of Australian Sport, that their funding would be in jeopardy?

The Minister knows what I am asking. That is very worrying for me and it takes me back to the argument I put to the Minister when it was decided to allow the AOF to allocate the funds. It gives it an enormous and unique influence. I have to say, with respect, that that is why I think it is wrong. It has the potential and the capacity to decapitate people and compromise them; to cause them to become obsequious when they should be saying something. It really takes them out of the mainstream of contribution to sport in terms of how it is run and their having a view about it.

I hope that the Minister is able to give me a commitment about this. He will presumably be resting only on the reputation of those on the AOF when he does give me a commitment. I hope that the Minister will pursue that matter so that I can have an assurance that it is not hinted to people, by implication indirectly or directly or in any way by innuendo, that if they cause problems-`they' being people associated with the Confederation of Australian Sport-they will get into trouble.

It is clear that there is some politics involved. I am sorry that I do not understand the politics, but there is some politics between the AOF and the Confederation of Australian Sport. I have not spoken to either body so I do not know, but clearly politics is involved and I would hate to think that any sporting body which is associated with the Confederation of Australian Sport is being threatened. I understood through another source-I am not being secretive about this; I cannot remember who it was-that there was a suggestion indirectly to Athletics Australia that it had a problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been tension between the Confederation of Australian Sport and the Australian Olympic Federation (AOF). If we are being honest, we have to concede that there has been some tension between the Confederation and the Australian Sports Commission at times in the last few years, let alone with just the AOF. When there are those periods of tension there are all sorts of allegations about who said what to whom. I will certainly take up with the Olympic Federation the allegation that Senator Crichton-Browne has made, which the Sports Commission knows about but has no evidence of.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that the Sports Commission has a contract with the Olympic Federation as to the allocation of funds and the rules to be observed. One will not find in that contract a rule that says that a member of the Confederation will not receive funding. I will ensure that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and the Sports Commission make it absolutely clear to the Olympic Federation that we will simply not tolerate any attempt by it to have the influence of the Confederation reduced.

I spent quite a bit of time ensuring that the Confederation got a kick along. It had been in the doldrums; I think it had been hijacked by some unworthy people at times. Three or four years ago it was not worth much. It has improved its situation dramatically since then. In fact, if my memory serves me correctly, within a couple of years it will be self-funding through the efforts that it has made. So while it might receive government funding now it will not have to very shortly. This body has really got hold of itself and kicked on, and I want to encourage it. I think having a lobbying body for sport outside the AOF, the Commonwealth Games Association or the Sports Commission is a good idea. I will certainly take up Senator Crichton-Browne's suggestion.

However, I do not accept the criticism about the Olympic Federation having an influence on the allocation of funds. One of the complaints made consistently to me while I was Minister was that it was very difficult for sport to know where money was coming from. We had all sorts of people allocating it, with all sorts of different criteria in mind. Obviously, when we are talking about millions of dollars of government expenditure-and we are here-it is a far better means of service delivery if we can have the decision made by fewer people under one set of rules rather than by lots of people all over the place with different sets of rules. I think that is better for sport because there is more certainty involved for the sporting bodies themselves. In setting up a new board for the Australian Sports Commission I tried, therefore, to have a balance with representatives of the Olympic Federation, athletes and some State institutes. I tried to get a whole range of people involved-from disabled sport as well. If we can get that kind of spread across the sports, we ought to get the right balance at the Sports Commission level.

We ought not to be ashamed or afraid of people such as John Coates, who will be the Manager of the Olympic team again in Barcelona. He is an incredibly popular figure in sport in Australia and perhaps the most efficient sporting administrator that I have come across. I think he is a first class Australian. I do not mind Senator Crichton-Browne strengthening the hand of people such as Mr Coates.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
The Chairman having reported accordingly--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not my intention to delay the Senate very much tonight. However, it is my sad task to report to the Senate on the sad departure from this world of one of our former loved attendants in this place, Barry Sargeant. Barry passed away earlier this week, and his funeral was held today. He was a long term employee of the Department of the Senate, working in this place some 15 years. He retired only this year on 25 March and, unfortunately, has not thoroughly enjoyed his year in retirement. He passed away quite suddenly.

SPEECH.PARA: Upon his retirement he held the position of Grade 3 as an attendant. He was a very popular individual around the Parliament and is, indeed, sadly missed not only by his immediate workmates-the other attendants and security people in this place-but also by the staff of senators and senators themselves. He is survived by his wife, Betty, three children and a number of grandchildren. On behalf of the Government I pass on our sincere condolences to Betty and the family.

TALK.START.PARA: —I and the Opposition would like to be associated with the condolence motion for Barry. Certainly those of us in the old building knew him well. I think we saw more of him there than here, but perhaps that is the nature of this building. It always strikes me as very sad when people die fairly soon after retirement. One feels they have missed out on something they have worked for for a very long time. We remember him well and with affection. As I say, we offer our condolences to his wife and children and wish to be associated with the motion.

—Of course the Australian Democrats join others in this chamber in expressing our condolences under these sad circumstances, and we do wish to be associated with the sentiments that have been expressed by Senator McKiernan and Senator Reid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 August the Auditor-General presented to the Presiding Officers of this Parliament Audit Report No. 3 1990-91, Department of Defence, into Australia's Army Reserve. The findings of the report have been accepted without question. No-one has stood up in public, to the best of my knowledge, and challenged those findings.

SPEECH.PARA: Most people who quote this report have only read the list of recommendations. Had they taken the time to read the report carefully to become aware of the scholarship and the methodology, they would have reached conclusions very different from those reached by the Auditor-General. It is because of the impact that the Auditor-General's report is having on the current defence debate in Australia-an impact based on incorrect conclusions-that I take the time of the Senate to analyse it in some detail.

At the outset I want to defend both the importance and the independence of the office of the Auditor-General. Accountability, particularly in handling public funds, is a fundamental for democratic government. One of the means of ensuring accountability of government is through an agency answerable not to the executive government, but to the parliament. Unless there is the facility for independent surveillance of the financial actions of government, then abuses and malpractices will occur.

Perhaps out of ignorance, the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) operated in an area where it had little or no expertise. Having read numerous audit reports on the Department of Defence it is apparent that the approaches adopted by the ANAO, while correct from a professional accounting point of view, are sometimes inappropriate in the case of this Department.

Defence is unlike other departments of state. Many of its capabilities cannot be readily quantified or demonstrated short of a real emergency. Many of its activities are directed towards future potential. While that is so, the most scrupulous accountability must still be maintained over the spending of public moneys. Those activities must be beyond reproach, and comprehensive audit procedures applied. Problems come at the next stage-whether some piece of equipment or some capability represents value for money.
The first point to be made relates to the objectives as outlined in chapter 2, Audit Objectives and Scope. The opening statement in paragraph 2.1.1 states that the objectives are as follows:
. . . to evaluate the efficiency and effectiveness of the ARES in terms of the role and objectives set out in 1987 Defence White Paper and associated high level Defence papers.
The report then lists its first detailed objective in paragraph 2.1.2 as follows:
. . . the organisation and management of operational activity of the ARES . . .

With the best will in the world, that task is simply beyond the Auditor- General. It takes time and a great deal of money to develop a good analytical capability. The Australian Department of Defence went down this path once with the Central Studies Establishment (CSE). The Central Studies Establishment was set up to look objectively at military capability in the Australian Defence Force (ADF) as a whole, not from a single service point of view.

It did much more than that. It analysed carefully what capabilities were required and how they might be provided. It looked not only at the purchase price but also at the total resources that would have to be committed to operate the system throughout its life, and the benefits and disadvantages of that system in comparison with others. This sort of detailed analysis often produces a result different from what might be expected when items of equipment or weapons systems are selected on one or more superficial attributes.

The Central Studies Establishment was too professional for its own good. Some of its findings did not accord with the prejudices of some of the generals in the services and some of the public servants, so it was quietly done away with. Since then, we have had a number of major capital acquisitions-the submarine program and the Anzac ship program-which have totally committed the defence budget for the next decade or more, and which have not been subjected to the rigorous analysis that CSE would have given them. The Department of Defence needs this critical analysis. To carry out analysis at this level takes vastly more resources than those in existence at the ANAO.

As well as this capability the Australian Defence Force needs another independent assessing capability. How the Australian Defence Force is meeting the objectives set by the Government must be measured. This is best done by an independent authority which has the resources for the task, particularly with respect to training procedures and equipment. What is required is the creation of the post of Inspector-General of the ADF. The role model for this is already in existence in the post of the Inspector General of Intelligence and Security.

Clearly, the duties of an Inspector General of Defence would be very different, but the principle of an informed, independent person or organisation having access to the innermost workings of the whole of the Department of Defence, and required to report without fear or favour, is the same. I will develop that in a future speech.

The next point is that the ANAO has a mistaken view of what the 1987 Defence White Paper has to say about the purposes of the A Reserve (ARES). The ANAO appears to have a conceptual image of the A Reserve as a fully manned and equipped military force trained for specific vital asset protection tasks, with the role of the ANAO being to judge the efficiency of their training. A more careful and informed reading of the White Paper shows that it sees the Reserves primarily as an expansion base. The 1987 White Paper does introduce, for the first time, specific tasking for the Reserves, particularly for the now disbanded 3rd Division.

I read the Defence White Paper carefully when it was published in 1987, which may have been some little while before anyone in the ANAO read it. The White Paper has little detailed discussion on the role of the Reserves, but the heart of what it has to say is in paragraph 4.106, where it says:

Our requirement for land warfare cannot be achieved without extensive Reserve participation. Accordingly the Army Reserve structure is being reviewed and changes will be implemented progressively. Since World War II the Reserve has provided the expansion base for the Army. It will now in addition be required to contribute to operations which might arise in the shorter term . . .

That clearly spells out the expansion role and the phrase `in addition it will be required' is a qualification to that basic directive. Whatever the ANAO sees as the correct interpretation of the White Paper, it must not be taken as the absolute prescription for Australia's defence. White Papers and strategic basis papers change as circumstances change. Like a railway timetable, at best they are a guide only. Papers change but the services endure. The purpose of the Australian Army Reserve (ARA) is to provide an expansion base for all contingencies ranging from limited support for the Regular Army and low level contingencies through to full scale mobilisation in a major emergency. One of its most important functions is to provide a pool of trained officers. While we have an overproduction of officers in the peacetime Regular Army, that surplus would be quickly exhausted in any serious emergency.

The reason for the existence of the Army Reserve lies in its potential. In this, the Army Reserve differs from the Air Force and Navy reserves. The fact that one of the main reasons for the Army Reserve is officer production means that it cannot exist in entirely the same form as a normal fighting force. Any assessment based on a comparison, for example, between the second and third Reserve divisions and the first division will not only show the second and third divisions in an unfavourable light, but also that it is incompatible with one of the central purposes in having the Reserve.

One very important point, unknown or overlooked by the ANAO, is that the ARES is forbidden by policy directive to train to the level of the ARA. It cannot train past sub-unit level so it is further disadvantaged. It is against this background that the reserves must be judged. To be fair to the ANAO report, the expansion base role is explored in the final part of chapter 3. It is weakly discussed with the stated interpretation that expansion would occur only after `the threat of more substantial conflict' and long lead times would be involved. It fails to understand the significance of this and therefore fails to censure the Department of Defence when it discovers in paragraph 3.5.3 that there are no plans for expansion-only the prospect that `concept papers would consider the extent to which expansion of the ADF or increased rates of effort might be required'.

In response, in paragraph 3.5.8, the Department shrugs this off when it says, `The Department advised it is not intended to develop operational concept papers on the ADF expansion base'. The fact that the Department of Defence has no plans for expansion in an emergency has not been commented on by any reviewers of the report. It is probably the most significant and certainly the most worrying statement in the entire report. Nevertheless, the questions which the ANAO attempts to answer are vitally important. They must be asked.

Let me now turn to the major failure of the report, the assessment of the cost of the Army Reserve. No-one knows what the reserves cost, certainly not the Auditor-General with his methodology. But then no-one knows what any capability costs in any of the Services. One has only to read the Hansards of Senate Estimates committees for the Department of Defence to know that. There is an inadequate cost accounting system in the Department of Defence. The last thing I want to see in the Department is cheeseparing accountants saying what can or cannot be afforded. That is to put the argument the wrong way round. The correct approach must be to decide on the best evidence what Australia's national security needs are and then fund that accordingly. What happens now is that the Government decides what the minimum amount of money is that it can get away with for the defence vote, and the defence requirements and the threat scenarios are tailored accordingly.

At the same time, a small nation has to know what it costs to maintain the capability of an element in the Defence Force in addition to what it costs to buy the equipment. It is for people other than accountants to decide whether that capability is required or not. Having said all that, while I think we can do a great deal better, at the end of the day costing figures may well be impossible to obtain with absolute precision.

The ANAO correctly makes the point that neither Army Office nor the Department had any estimate other than salaries paid for training days of what the reserves cost. Despite its reference in the appendix to the Government Accounting Office (GAO) of the United States, the ANAO did not apparently explore overseas experience in any depth. The GAO is far better endowed for this task than the ANAO, and it supports the view that the costs of the reserves are about 60 per cent of the costs of the regulars.

The ANAO proceeded to develop its own estimate of cost of the reserves. This led it to the conclusion that a Reserve soldier costs 50 per cent per day more than a regular. This conclusion is now widely disseminated and believed. How did it get this figure? The steps it followed were these: the ANAO started from the proposition that apart from those ARA personnel assigned as cadre to ARES units and those in specific combat units, the remainder of the ARA supported the needs of both the ARA and the ARES.

The ANAO accepted a figure from the Army that in the State of South Australia the ratio of effort from the Regular Army in support was 65 : 35-that is, reserves to regulars. In other words, 65 per cent of the activities of the ARA in South Australia, apart from combat units and ARES cadre, was spent on the reserves. The ratio of 65 : 35 was not substantiated in any way. It may be true; it may be false. No-one knows. But what we can say is that there is no justification for transferring that figure to the whole of Australia. Even the Department of Defence protested about that flight of fancy.

What the ANAO did was to multiply the number of these ARA support personnel in South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania by an average salary paid to the ARA in each of these States. From these three figures a cost attribution was worked out on the basis of 65 per cent of the cost going to the Reserve in South Australia and Western Australia. For Tasmania the fraction was 80 per cent. These three figures were added together and divided by the ARES numbers in the three States. This then gave an average cost of the support by the ARA to each Reserve member. This figure was then multiplied by the total number of reserves in Australia which produced a figure of around $100m. This is of course over and above those cadre normally provided to Reserve units such as COs, adjutants and instructors. To anyone with any mathematical understanding, this methodology is quite incredible. In the first place, the Army figure is not substantiated in any way. The principal role of the regulars is as the force in being, but among a number of other roles is the requirement to train and support the reserves.

It is perfectly reasonable to ask how much effort goes into supporting the reserves. At the same time, it is reasonable to ask the Reserve, as the customer, if it thinks it is getting value for money, particularly if 65 per cent of the support troops in the whole Army are supporting it. The Auditor-General's figures are that a reservist trains for about 40 days per year-most do far less-versus 220 days for a regular; a ratio of 1 : 6. To support one reserve training day compared with six training days for a regular apparently takes nearly twice the effort throughout a whole year. Clearly this is an untenable proposition.

Secondly, those ratios-65 per cent in South Australia and Western Australia and 80 per cent in Tasmania-apply to States which have small Regular units. From the ANAO's own report, the total ARA strength in Tasmania, South Australia and Western Australia was only 2,654 out of a total figure of 31,465. Mathematically, there is no correlation between these three small States and Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria where the numbers are very different both for the regulars and reservists. The Department of Defence in paragraph 5.2.4 is quoted by the ANAO as saying that it cannot accept the reasoning behind this approach.

Thirdly, a clear assumption is that the ARA gets nothing out of the reserves. At all levels, Reserve activities do provide training and experience for the ARA, training which they may not otherwise get. One example of this is the tendency to replace reserve COs with regulars. In a contracting environment for the regulars, Reserve units do provide useful career opportunities.

Finally, the attribution of effort completely overlooks the fact that support personnel are necessary for combat units. It may well be that they cannot be used 100 per cent of the time but their existence is essential to the Regular unit. In this case, if the Reserve can use this unused capability, it should get it for nothing or at least a heavily discounted figure. Having developed this methodology, the ANAO then takes the same flawed thinking and applies it to the equipment, materiel and accommodation used by the reserves.

The Regular Army lacks some basic equipment and there is absolutely no excuse for this. The Reserve is very much worse off. Despite having authorised entitlements for equipment for rifles, radios and the rest-entitlements which on average are 25 per cent of what they need-most reserve units have less than their authorised level. The ANAO report records the shortages of equipment in paragraph 3.4.6 where it draws attention to significant shortages of equipment, increased demands on regional equipment pools and excessive holdings, absence of information on age and condition to provide management information and a properly managed equipment repair program.

The system whereby a reserve battalion has only 25 per cent of its equipment is reasonable so long as it has enough for training purposes through the year.
