When these units undergo continuous training in their annual camps, they are supposed to be able to draw 100 per cent of what they need from a regional pool. These pools were set up for reserve use. The report shows these pools to be inadequate where it says that less than 50 per cent of requests for equipment made to regional training pools can be satisfied.

Added to this insufficiency is the fact that ARA units are now drawing on these pools although they were not set up for regulars. Despite having shown that there were gross deficiencies in ARES equipment, the ANAO looked at the capital and equipment account of the Army, divided it up on the same ratio as is used to ascribe manpower costs from the regulars and added that to the cost of the reserves. In this way a figure of $475m was claimed to be the cost of the Army Reserve. It is claimed to be a conservative estimate because several other costs were not included. One of those qualifications, that no consideration is given to income tax forgone because Reserve pay is tax free, is quite silly. This Government tried to tax Reserve pay and failed. Reservists are paid much less than regulars and in nearly all cases less than they earn in civilian employment.

On the other side, claims can be made that the reservists are more efficient in some ways than regulars. The equipment pooling system means that equipment assigned to reservists can be used far more intensively than in regular units. All training days can be used for reservists, while the regulars have guard duties, ceremonials and about 40 days stand-down a year. None of these points is important to me, but I mention them in passing.

The other major shortcoming of the report arises from its concept of what the Reserve should be. The report does not understand what the Army is in both its regular and reserve components. Relying on a strictly cost benefit approach, it has led to some wrong conclusions. The report's treatment of understrength units provides a very good example of this. The ANAO uses the term viability and in its eyes a viable unit is one which has 70 per cent of its authorised strength. It states:

. . . in order to reallocate equipment from non viable units or those assigned lower priority tasks, to the high priority and viable units so as to match needs and resources in accord with army priorities . . .

Nothing drives reservists away faster than poor or non-existent equipment. If a unit is weak and is stripped of its meagre resources, it will cease to exist. The answer is to fund the Reserve adequately for these basic requirements-rifles, webbing, uniforms, compasses, et cetera. The Defence Department can afford billions of dollars for submarines and frigates, but it cannot find a few million that would solve all the basic equipment problems for both the reserves and the regular Army.

It is important that reasons are found for the problems of understrength units and those problems dealt with. The Reserve must be spread throughout the whole Australian community. That is absolutely fundamental. It is dangerous to accept the proposition that those strong units, which are mainly in Queensland and New South Wales, should prosper and the weak be eliminated.

One final point on viability. The report sees university regiments as not cost effective because they do not produce enough officers. That is a central role, but it is not their most important one. For the information of the Audit Office, an important fact is that reserve officers from university regiments serve for longer than officers recruited from other sources. It is essential that in peacetime the Defence Force has a presence on the campus. To do otherwise is to isolate the Defence Force from the higher educated sections of the community, presumably the future community leaders, with potential and important sociological divisions or misunderstandings in the longer term. Furthermore, the Defence Force is entitled to have access to the talent on campus. There are numerous other examples of a lack of understanding by the ANAO. For example, paragraph 4.2.2:

The retention of the two ARES divisions did not appear to have any efficiency and effectiveness gains flowing from it and there was evidence to indicate more concern to retain promotion positions than in priority structural efficiency and effectiveness.
That charge can be laid on some regular units. Within reason, in peacetime excess positions provide both training and experience.
Paragraph 4.2.5 recommends:
. . . a simplified command and control chain to reflect the part time nature of the ARES.

Again it misses the point that the Reserve is not an end in itself but a means to an end. We certainly do not want a Reserve structured like a State emergency service. It is wrong to allow vital asset protection to dominate and simplify training. Army units are not trained for a single task. The only way an asset like an airfield can be protected is by having troops skilled in all arms who can dominate the surrounding area and deny its use to the enemy. That takes real trained soldiers, not civilian security guards.

Quite apart from the foregoing comments, there are some factual errors in the report which detract from its scholarship. Time does not permit me to enumerate them. Having made those unfavourable criticisms, it should be recorded that the report has some valid points. It highlights the shortages of basic equipment. We are not talking here about exotic helicopters or ships, but the absolute basics-boots, uniforms, webbing, and the tools of trade for a soldier, rifles, compasses and radios. There is no excuse for those items to be short. In both regular and reserve forces the greatest depressants of morale are poor equipment and poor training. If basic equipment cannot be provided for the limited peacetime numbers, how will it ever be supplied in an emergency?

The report comments on the quite incredible paper war that Army administration finds essential and has for centuries. Everything must be signed for, and in triplicate. Again, administratively all three services, not only the ARES, are back in the Boer War from the point of view of communications. When the use of car phones, mobile phones, hand-held radios and facsimile machines are universal in the civilian world-not only in private industry, but in all government departments-I have yet to see one fax machine in any service office or headquarters. Cumulatively, the time lost across the whole of the Australian Defence Force by not providing adequate numbers of these basic essentials is incalculable.

Despite the ANAO's claims, it costs more to keep regulars then reserves. Not all personnel are required 365 days a year. Even if the figures of the Auditor-General are accepted, in this context the real significance is not that a reservist costs 50 per cent more than a regular. The argument can be inverted. The country can buy two-thirds the numbers of regulars for about only one-fifth of their cost. Except for those cases where an immediate capability is required, and that is a very real requirement, much greater potential capability can be bought for the same amount of money through the reserves.

The argument should not be expressed in those adversarial terms for we need both regulars and reservists. The truth of the matter is that the level of training determines the cost. I want to say quite emphatically that I am not arguing for the reserves, least of all an entire Reserve Army for Australia or a Wrigley plan. For the purposes of this speech I am accepting the status quo in ratios between the reserves and the regulars. The point is that the Auditor-General's report is into reserves, so they become the central point. At the present time three major inquiries relating to the reserves are under way or on hand. The Department of Defence is doing a major force review study which will be completed in the first half of next year. The Wrigley report, which proposes a much enhanced role for the reserves, has been presented. The Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee of this Parliament is completing a major inquiry also.

What has been the effect of this report? First of all, the figures quoted by the Office have been accepted as fact and people who should know better quote them. Secondly, these figures have been used to undermine the Reserve within the defence community. It is not only the Regular Army but also some regulars in the other two services who are now saying that the reserves are a waste of money. The countervailing view among some in the Reserve is that the regulars are not supporting them and indeed see the continued existence of the Reserve as unnecessary competition for scarce resources. It is wrong that this dichotomy should exist within the Australian Army, which is in fact made up of both a regular and a reserve component. The reservists believe there is some justification for their view.

Conducted between March and December 1989, the Audit Office report was published in August 1990. Through the 14 chapters of the report, the Department of Defence makes written comment on the recommendations. Indeed the report was circulated widely through the Army asking for comments. Anyone outside Defence who had an interest in the report knew of its findings at least six months before the report was tabled in Parliament.

A further point that troubles the Reserve is the timing of the release of the report. I do not know whether it was a coincidence. My views do not matter. The views that do matter are those of the reservists. A couple of weeks after the ANAO report was released, the decision to disband the headquarters of the 3rd Division was taken, having been public knowledge for some time prior to this.

It is pointed out that the disbanding of the Construction Squadron, a Regular unit, was announced in the Budget in August, yet the 3rd Division announcement was not made until 8 October. In paragraph 4.2.4 the Department of Defence argues strongly against closure of the Reserve Divisional Headquarters because they are essential. It is very disturbing that matters which are essential to the Department of Defence can be changed so readily. Rightly or wrongly, there are those in the Reserves who believe they were treated less than honourably by their colleagues in arms, their brother officers, in the Regular Army.

The important point is the devastating effect that this report has on the morale of the Reservists, particularly in Victoria. They feel very strongly that the report is inaccurate. The Reserve has been dealt a crippling blow in one of the two great population centres in Australia, where the nation must tap the huge range of skills and personnel available.

The Reserves in Australia often get treated badly. Few members of the general public recognise the sacrifices made by those who conscientiously serve this nation's interests in a voluntary part time capacity. There are very big sacrifices made by a Reservist and his or her family in time, money, career advancement and often, sadly, in family welfare. Reservists do leave after 30 or 37 years of dedicated service feeling their time and effort has not been valued.

Australia must have a Defence Force. We must have a highly professional Regular Force as a counter to any immediate threat. We must have a Reserve Force to back that up. It is quite proper for the the state of both the Regular and the Reserve forces to be subject to continuous and objective reviews. What the Auditor-General has done is look at the Reserves and decide that the nation is not getting value for money. Implicit in the report is that, since this is so, the Reserves should be done away with. Surely a more intelligent approach is for the Auditor-General to look for the reasons why this is so, if indeed it is true.

I personally think we could get a great deal more out of the Reserves. The reason why the Reserve is in the state it is in is that it has been denied the sinews of war-materiel and resource. Give it the basic equipment it must have; give it good instructors from the ARA; give it realistic training programs; and then judge its worth. That is what is starting to happen with the Reserve units in 6 Brigade, where a number of Queensland Reserve units-49 RQR, 2/14 Cav, to name but two-have been integrated with Regular units. The results, a year or two after integration, are very promising and point the way to the future.

Mr President, I have taken the time of the Senate to deal with what I believe is an important report. I do not agree with the central findings of this report and I believe that this report does a disservice to the national interest. There are certainly problems with the Reserve, but a more perceptive approach is required to overcome those problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to the fact that I have already spoken in this adjournment debate in offering condolences. I seek leave to make the adjournment speech that I was scheduled to make.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. I will be brief. In the year 1215 AD, King John of England signed an agreement with his subjects. The agreement is commonly known as Magna Carta and it is acknowledged as being an important document. It is displayed in the public areas, of course, of this Parliament for all of the public to see and absorb its significance. It is significant because it is the document upon which our system of parliamentary representation and indeed the whole of our judicial system are based. It is a pompous document, but it is agreed that it is also significant. I would like to quote from the commencement:

SPEECH.PARA: John, by grace of God, king of England . . . to . . . all of his officials and faithful subjects greeting. Know that we, out of reverence for God and for the salvation of our soul and those of all of our ancestors and heirs, for the honour of God . . . and the reform of our Kingdom, on the advice of our . . . faithful subjects.
We have . . . granted to all the freemen of our kingdom, for ourselves and our heirs for ever, all the liberties written below, to be had and held by them and their heirs from us and our heirs.

What this means is that Magna Carta binds our Sovereign Lady Queen Elizabeth. It binds the Queen in the Parliament at Westminster; it binds the Queen in the Parliament of Sydney; it binds the Queen's Ministers of State for the Commonwealth of Australia and for New South Wales; and it binds Her Majesty's Justices in the courts of this land. The agreement concludes as follows:

Wherefore we wish and firmly order that . . . the men in our kingdom shall have and hold all the aforesaid privileges, rights and concessions . . . for themselves and their heirs from us and our heirs in all things and places for ever . . .

That is quite an extraordinary promise. What this means is that the rights conferred by Magna Carta ensure the benefits of the subjects of our Sovereign Lady the Queen throughout Britain and the British Commonwealth of Nations. That trust is placed in us as a parliament and in the courts of the land. I would like, with leave, to table a translation in modern English of Magna Carta for the information of honourable senators who perhaps have not seen it in modern English.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of those subjects referred to is Mr Wilfred Taylor of Cambewarra. I have described in this place the dealings between Mr Taylor and an officer of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia and Mr Taylor's attempts before courts in Australia to obtain what he considers to be the promised justice of Magna Carta. In March 1988, Mr Taylor issued proceedings against the bank and the officer, claiming damages. On 11 May 1990, Mr Taylor applied to the Supreme Court of New South Wales by way of notice of motion-and I seek leave to table a copy of that notice of motion-to have the hearing of the proceedings be expedited.
—Senator McLean has not shown the Opposition any of the documents he has been referring to. I feel it is a courtesy.
—You wouldn't want to see the Magna Carta, would you?
—I would have liked to see the Magna Carta at 11 o'clock at night, but I thought it was a courtesy that was normally observed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not for me to rule on.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The application was supported by an affidavit by Mr Taylor's medical practitioner, Dr Russell Butler. I would seek leave to table the affidavit of Mr Taylor's medical practitioner.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The affidavit sworn on 11 April 1990 includes paragraph 4, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . coronary arteriography was performed on Mr Taylor on 26 April 1989 which showed moderately severe coronary artery disease.
Then paragraph 7 says:
. . . I am concerned that delays in his legal proceedings will produce a continuing, and perhaps accelerated, deterioration of Mr Taylor's coronary arteries.
And paragraph 10 says:

It is possible that if he were to wait longer than a few months for the proceedings to be dealt with his health would deteriorate to the extent that he would no longer be able to continue the proceedings and may even die before they are eventually dealt with.
I suggest that, in refusing the application for expedition, the judge was in fact contravening the principles enunciated from the Magna Carta that I read earlier.
King John entered into a covenant with his subjects and their heirs forever. That is a very pompous statement but that is what Magna Carta actually says. The covenant is:
To no one will we sell, to no one will we refuse or delay right or justice.
It is my contention that, by refusing expedition, the judge breached that covenant. The judge breached an ancient covenant that guarantees that justice shall not be delayed.

It is in the interests of the people of Australia that Mr Taylor's proceedings go to trial almost immediately. I have disclosed in this place, by reference to affidavits sworn by managing directors of four separate companies, the evidence against the bank officer. In April 1988, a senior officer of the New South Wales police fraud squad informed Mr Taylor and others that he, Taylor, had a strong prima facie case against the bank officer.

In April 1988, an officer of the Australian Federal Police informed Mr Taylor and, separately, Mr Tony Rigg of Nowra that the bank officer would be charged on summonses and a warrant issued to seize the bank files. That was in April 1988 and nothing has happened. Mr Taylor is a man who has served the nation well. During the Second World War, he used his engineering skills to develop a new form of altimeter for aircraft. That altimeter was fitted to aircraft of the Royal Australian Air Force and the United States Air Force, and made a tangible contribution to the war effort in Europe.

During the war the United States Navy urgently needed new instrument lathes. Mr Taylor developed those lathes. Also during the war troops fighting in jungle warfare in New Guinea and Borneo needed an optical instrument to measure vertical angles. Mr Taylor developed that optical instrument. In more recent times Mr Taylor designed the dies for the Mighty Chef range of microwave cookware, together with a secret manufacturing process incorporated into the machinery. The Mighty Chef range was recognised as a world leader, and it became the subject of the action between Mr Taylor and the banks.

It would be a grave travesty of the justice outlined in the Magna Carta if Mr Taylor were unable to continue with his proceedings. A great issue is raised by Mr Taylor's predicament. That issue is whether ancient rights guaranteed to us down the years of our constitutional history prevail to this day, 1990.

The Premier of New South Wales, Mr Greiner, is Mr Taylor's State member of Parliament. I advise the Senate that I will call upon Mr Greiner to affirm to the people of Australia that those ancient rights do prevail to this day. I advise the Senate that I intend to call upon Mr Greiner to use his good offices to cause Mr Taylor's proceedings to be set down for trial within one month.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.12 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following documents were tabled by the Clerk:
107, Amendments, dated 23 October, 30 October and 5 November 1990.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer upon notice, on 19 July 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Ministerial councils or similar forums exist for the meeting of State, Federal and other Ministers.
(2) What are their names and general objectives.
(3) How many times per year do(es) the council(s)/forum(s) meet.
(4) What is the membership (including officials) of each council/forum, and who chairs the meetings.
(5) Is(are) the council(s)/forum(s) served by a secretariat; if so, in each case, what is its composition, who is responsible for financing it, and what does it cost.
(6) What meetings of the council(s)/forum(s) were held for the last three financial years and how many persons attended the meetings, including officials and private ministerial staff.
(7) What were the costs of each of these meetings to the Commonwealth including travel, entertainment or dinners/lunches, accommodation, etc.
(8) Where were the meetings held and what was the venue.
(9) Are there records of the meetings available to the public; if so, where can they be obtained; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) One for which the Treasurer is responsible.

(2) The Australian Loan Council, established under the Financial Agreement of 1927. Loan Council controls and coordinates public sector borrowing in Australia in terms of both Government and semi-government debt. The main agreements under which it fulfils this role are the Financial Agreement and the Global Approach Resolution.

(3) In recent years, Loan Council meetings have been held annually, in conjunction with the Premiers' Conference. Members have the ability to convene on a more regular basis, if they feel this is necessary.
(4) Members comprise the Commonwealth Treasurer (Chairman) and the Treasurer of each of the six States. The Chief Ministers of the ACT and the Northern Territory attend as observers.

(5) The Loan Council Section, Fiscal Policy Division, Treasury, serves as Secretariat to the Loan Council, and is currently comprised of two officials who perform other functions in addition to their Secretariat duties.

(6) Attendance at recent Loan Council meetings was the same as for the conjoint Premiers' Conference. The response on 22 December 1989 to the honourable senator's almost identical question to the Prime Minister on this subject (Question No. 1421, Hansard, pages 5227-5229) provided a response in relation to the 1987, 1988 and 1989 Premiers' Conferences. In view of the considerable time and expense involved in the preparation of that reply, I am not prepared to authorise the work and expenditure required to prepare an answer to this question in relation to the 1990 Premiers' Conference/Loan Council meeting.

(7) There are no additional costs arising from the Loan Council meetings over and above the Premiers' Conference with which each meeting is held. The response on 22 December 1989 to the honourable senator's almost identical question to the Prime Minister on this subject (Question No. 1421, Hansard, pages 5227-5229) provided a response in relation to the 1987, 1988 and 1989 Premiers' Conferences. In view of the consider- able time and expense involved in the preparation of that reply, I am not prepared to authorise the work and expenditure required to prepare an answer to this question in relation to the 1990 Premiers' Conference/Loan Council meeting.
(8) The meetings were held at Parliament House.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice on 13 September 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With the increasing amount of corporate crime has the Government retained the services of more auditors to check the business of companies.
(2) How many auditors work for the Federal Government in this capacity.
(3) Is there a problem retaining the services of highly trained auditors.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I have assumed that the honourable senator's question is not intended to refer to the public servants whose work at the Australian National Audit Office includes the audit of Government enterprises. I have assumed he is only concerned with the business of private companies incorporated under the companies legislation.

Auditors of private companies are appointed by members of companies rather than by the corporate regulatory authorities. The role of the company auditor is to report to the members on company financial statements, accounting records and practices, and other finance related matters.

The closest equivalents to auditors in the corporate regulatory apparatus are the investigators employed by the State and Territory Corporate Affairs Commissions to investigate suspected breaches of the companies legislation by companies and those connected with companies. Such officers are not auditors, but usually hold accounting and/or legal qualifications.

The Market Supervision Division in the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) is also concerned with supervising the activities of companies, although that Division also has other functions. Further, the practice is that the NCSC does not conduct prosecutions, but rather refers these matters to the Corporate Affairs Commissions.

Of the various Corporate Affairs Commissions, the Commonwealth Government administers only the Australian Capital Territory Commission. The Commonwealth has no role in relation to the State and Northern Territory Corporate Affairs Commissions.

There have not been recent increases in the number of investigators employed in the ACT Commission. However, with the establishment of the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) as a single national corporate regulator, the Commonwealth Government intends to effect a substantial increase in the resources devoted to corporate regulation, not just in the ACT but throughout Australia. It is currently envisaged that, over the next 4 years, an additional $210m will be spent, representing an increase of 60% over current cooperative scheme funding.

(2) In the ACT Corporate Affairs Commission, 12 investigators were employed on 12 October 1990. The total number of staff in the NCSC's Market Supervision Division on that day was 26.5 (though as mentioned above, that Division has a range of functions).

(3) It can be difficult to retain the services of officers experienced in corporate finance because such skills are of considerable value in many areas of the economy. So far, however, this difficulty has not prevented the Commonwealth from employing and retaining sufficient numbers of competent investigators for its purposes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 11 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Once the Department of Social Security is informed by a family allowance allowee that his or her income has changed, but his or her employer has not, is it the usual practice of the department to immediately adjust the family allowance paid; if not, what triggers the adjustment.

(2) What is the average time period after which a household in receipt of the family allowance has advised the department that although a household member has not changed his or her employer but has experienced an increase in his or her wages that the household either has their family allowance entitlement reduced or ended altogether.

(3) How many families currently receiving the family allowance and which have advised the department of a change in their circumstances have not as yet had their allowance entitlements adjusted accordingly.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Immediate adjustments are not necessarily made in this situation. For most clients, increases in income received while working for the same employer are unlikely to satisfy the requirements for reassessments set out in the Social Security Act 1947.
In broad terms, the law requires family allowance entitlements to be adjusted only where taxable income for a current financial year is more than 125% of both:
* the family allowance income test threshold relevant to that family; and
* the family's taxable income for the financial year ended in the previous calendar year.

It is also necessary that the increase in income be linked to a ``notifiable event''. For all but a small number of people, whose entitlements are based on an estimate of current financial year income, employees are not required to notify an increase in wages while with the same employer.

The number of family allowance recipients is about 1.9 million and it would not be productive to require notification of every change in income during the course of the entitlement year. Such a requirement would necessitate, for example, millions of unnecessary contacts each year because of National Wage Case increases. In all but a few cases they would not increase household income over the family allowance income test limits. The administrative overheads of such an arrangement would be significant.
All entitlements are reviewed towards the end of each calendar year to determine whether payment should continue in the next year and, if so, at what rate.

(2) An increase in wages which is not accompanied by a change of employer could take, on average, about nine months before it was subjected to the family allowance income test provided there was no other change in the family's income situation. In only a small minority of cases, however, the rate of family allowance payable would be affected because of the level of the family allowance income test limits and because the limits are indexed for movements in the Consumer Price Index each January.

(3) This information is not readily available because, for the reasons set out in (l) and (2), most such advices are not relevant to current entitlements. I am not prepared to authorise the considerable expenditure of resources required to collect the data by way of manual inspection of documentation held for 1.9 million clients.
